reviews.author: ur35635716

reviews.content: For as long as Game of Thrones waits to pay story lines and plot points off, it sure is satisfying when it's done right. Tonight just about went down the way I thought it would, but that didn't take away from the brilliance of the episode on all fronts.I didn't think we would get anything besides the battle brewing in the North, but we got a decent amount of Meereen material. We saw Daenerys ride her Drogon again a few weeks back, but seeing her tear right through any hopes The Masters had of taking down Meereen was just awesome. Throw in the appearance of all 3 dragons together in one continuous shot sent chills down my spine.It's hard to come out of the episode not thinking about that final shot in Winterfell, but the Greyjoys meeting with Tyrion and Dany deserves some attention as well. Not only was it nice to hear some more history behind these two families, but I believed every word coming from both sides. For once it seems this house alliance makes sense and won't end in tragedy.But onto the North, I think the battle went down pretty much the way people speculated, but I dug every second of it. Everything from the devastation in Jon Snow's eyes when he sees his brother die to the sweeping long shots of swords, arrows, and horses flying all over the place made 'Battle of the Bastards' one for history books. Everyone behind the scenes deserves a ton of credit for this one.Even the stuff that went past the battlefield like the Jon and Sansa conflict was well done. Over the course of the show they haven't had the lengthy screen time that other duos have, but they are now consistently one of the best acted and written parts of the show. Same goes for the back and forth between Tormund and Daavos and even Ramsay and Jon. Absolutely loved it.It's only fitting Ramsay gets eaten by his own dogs. Of course, he had to get his final tragic game in by killing Rickon. That was unfortunate. But I've been pulling for Ghost to get the kill for quite some time now, but I think I can settle for Ramsay's hounds. Goes right next to Joffrey as probably the most satisfying death in the show's history. Sansa's final smirk though? Perfect.There were a few things here and there that didn't work as well though. Daavos conveniently finding Shireen's little toy in the wood felt a little forced, but it will certainly have an impact going forward. There were also times the editing and cuts inside the battlefield that made it difficult to see what was going on. But nitpicks for sure. 'Battle of the Bastards' is one of the best pieces of art this show has given us in its 6 year run, and I can only hope next week has a similar effect.+Goodbye Ramsay+That battle tho+Sansa's subtle smile+Greyjoy and Targaryen alliance makes sense10/10
reviews.author: ur39517558

reviews.content: Greetings from Lithuania."Battle of the Bastards" is hands down the most intense and spectacular episode this show produced ever (period). Directing by Miguel Sapochnik was perfect. Cinematograpfy reminded my of "Braveheart" especially in the battle sequence. Acting was more then solid. Special effect were outstanding - never have seen quite anything like that on a small screen - this episode should be witnessed on the biggest screen possible. Especially big kudos for HBO for producing (probably) the most spectacular episode in TV history. There wasn't a single flow in this episode - Miguel Sapochnik should start doing big movies right away, because "Battle of the Bastards" is as good as it gets.
reviews.author: ur4405474

reviews.content: As an old Klingon Proverb goes "Revenge is a dish best served cold." It is very cold in Winterfell.This is my favorite episode of the show; this was something we've all waited so very long for and finally that wait has finally paid off.Both Jon and Sansa are now about to retake their kingdom but of course the only obstacle in the way is the scum king Lord Bolton. Really like some of that negotiation scene where Bolton is practically taunting, trying to intimidate, just simply talking crap toward both. We see both of them aren't bending toward it, I really like how both of them don't say too much toward him and they don't need to as we just see both of them just give Bolton this cold stare, from that you already know the negotiation is over as both of them have already made up their minds even before they says what they say to him; from that moment I thought "Prepare to die, blowhole!"Despite how good a strategist Bolton is I know his weakness, he's full of arrogance, he's much to sure of himself always thinking people are going to do exactly what he expects them to do like his dogs; but human nature is never predicable. Even like that final conversation scene both Jon and Sansa have about the battle, which I thought really shows how much both have grown as characters and despite how long it's been the brother and sister bond still exists and is stronger than ever. It's emotional in that conversation as both know the risks of this battle, both also know they have to do what must be done to not just honor their kingdom but their love for their family.The beginning of the battle was really suspenseful as we are both unsure of how it will begin but also if victory for Jon's army is possible, despite the stratagem they planned in the strategy session the possibility of success is slim as Bolton unfortunately has higher numbers so yeah the odds are sadly against the Northern Army.We see Bolton play a game with one of the Jon's youngest brothers making him run to Jon, but this isn't a game as it's just a form of execution as we see Bolton is firing arrows toward him. I couldn't help but be on the edge of my seat hopping Jon will ride fast enough toward his brother and just when Jon gets close enough, the arrow drops.Once that arrow fell on Jon's brother, that moment was heart sinking and at the same time just made the blood in both Jon and I explode into a volcanic eruption as he then charges in alone head on into battle, that moment I thought "That's it, the chainsaw is coming out!" The battle is just beautifully choreographed, not too fanciful which makes it all the better making the battle feel slightly realistic. Also like the cinematography, one shot I really like was seeing Jon standing alone on the battlefield seeing the Bolton army charge toward him and he simply goes into a stance with his sword drawn, it is such a beautiful shot, simply one standing against evil.It's awesome seeing Jon just kicking butt and taking names, we see as he is going forward, he is just cutting down any of Bolton scum army that dare frak with him. But then round two begins when we see Jon's company entrapped in Bolton's phalanx maneuver along with that pile of bodies behind them with more of Bolton's army on top. Really like how we see Jon and company constantly fighting, for a little while it looks like they could possibly break though the Phalanx and turn things around, one really good kill was seeing a giant take one of Bolton's men and then just ripping the scum sucker in half like a toy figurine. But despite their efforts it's to no avail and so the North Army tries to escape up the bodied hill despite the opposition above, but then we see Jon in another bad situation which is another suspenseful moment which actually put me on edge and even had me gasping for breath as we see he is getting buried in bodies, but also shows a little of the awful reality of war how ugly it can truly get.Everything seems almost hopeless for the Northern Company and Bolton's strategy seems like Bolton is about to win. But unfortunately, there was one huge detail Bolton failed to consider and that is Sansa. Sansa we see rides in with back up for the Northern Army and then we see they're practically plowing the road of Bolton's army. There is another good cinematography shot of Jon whom is just bloody, dirty covered in grime and sut which reflects his state of mind as we see him look a Bolton from a distance just pissed as hell, which just puts the fear in Bolton as he knows he next on Jon kill list. It's poetic justice as Bolton has always ruled and attained power though fear, but now that very thing has turned against him.The final scene in this were just beautiful, really like that face off both Jon Snow and Bolton have. Is firing arrow but each arrow Jon block with the Shield, it's just great seeing how Jon continually advance on Bolton, like Jason Vorhees zeroing in on the kill. And when Jon gets close enough, he just beats the living crap out of him, I honestly couldn't help but cheer and pretend I was joining in on that beating. Jon just really unleashes all inferno hell into that beating in a way that reflect my own and everyone else's feelings toward that character, how much pain, misery, and death he has caused toward Sonsa and all other unfortunate souls. There is another little beautiful scene as we see Bolton's sick flag has been taken down and now the Stark flag flies once more on their house, seeing that you know the Starks are finally back in business.The ending is just satisfying as once again poetic justice is delivered, really loved that final monologue Sansa delivers at the end which in a way was exactly what I had in mind for him it was just beautiful sort of her way of delivering the finishing blow, showing he could not break her spirit it's stronger than ever before. Jon and Sansa have served Bolton his cold dish so bone appetite in hell.Rating: 4 stars
reviews.author: ur24931284

reviews.content: If anyone told me when I was watching Game of Thrones Season 1 that Sophie Turner's character was going to emerge as the best one on the show down the line, I'd have scoffed at the thought of that.
reviews.author: ur91222832

reviews.content: This episode is to the series what Goodbye Farewell, and Amen was to Mash, and Ozymandias to Breaking Bad...a classic series episode that prepares the viewer for what's next in the future. The battle scenes in this episode are the best ever made for television, and at a big cost. The locations where this show is filmed is very exotic, and the characters and dragons rule the show. The music is amazing as well as the pace of the show. If you have to see just one episode of GOT, this is the one.
reviews.author: ur18723110

reviews.content: 'Battle of the Bastards' has not only raised the bar for Game of Thrones, and not only is it one of HBO's finest productions to date, but this episode might be one of the greatest television episodes of all time. It's certainly one of the best television episodes of the decade.'Battle of the Bastards' is truly the culmination of everything that's been working like a charm on Game of Thrones so far and it's all cranked up to the next level. The cast does a spectacular job, particularly the performances of Kit Harington and Iwan Rheon; for me they both steal the show right here.Game of Thrones has done the near-impossible and has outdone itself yet again. The script, the direction, the music and the cinematography: nothing's sidelined in this episode. Everything, from the arcs of Jon Snow, Tyrion, Daenerys and Ramsey, all adds up to one of the brand-new touchstones of television. This episode is basically art; the series shows that television is an art form comparable to film.'Battle of the Bastards' is as ruthless and relentless as the title suggests, and full of genuine moments of awe that will stay with you long after the episode's over.
reviews.author: ur24085266

reviews.content: When the episode ended, it lived up to my expectations and delivered what was promised. The battle between Jon Snow and Ramsay Bolton is the best action sequence I've ever seen and it's right up there with the battle sequences in Season 4.The sets are still lavish especially the castle of Ramsay Bolton and the costumes and scenery are still beautiful. The writing is solid as it delivers the stakes for Jon Snow to try and bring justice to Ramsay Bolton and keeps you invested. The directing is brilliant, the editing is really good, and Ramin Djawadi delivers some of the most brilliant action music with suspense and intensity. The characters are still believable and Ramsay Bolton continues to be really effective as the villain. Iwan Rheon, who played him in season 3, did a fantastic job in making him so despicable much like Jack Gleeson did as King Joffrey.Since it's been two days, I like to say that Ramsay Bolton is finally gone. He tortured Theon Greyjoy and when he killed Rickon Stark before the battle started, it made me hate him even more.That being said, the highlights of the episode are the performances and the battle sequences. Kit Harington and Sophie Turner delivers some of their solid lines together and so does Iwan Rheon, who brings menace to Ramsay perfectly as he did when he was first introduced. Peter Dinklage and Emilia Clarke along with Alfie Allen and Gemma Whelan are also good in the conversation scene at the palace in Meereen with Daenerys agreeing to use the Iron Fleet for battle if the two promise not to pillage anymore.Overall, Battle of the ******** is an epic episode and delivered what it promised. Good character development, solid writing, some of the best battle sequences since season 4, and excellent acting. Thumbs up :). Can't wait for the season finale.
reviews.author: ur26083589

reviews.content: A great episode featuring one of the greatest battles and Ramsay's death healing the trick
reviews.author: ur118977607

reviews.content: The Battle is here and it is so damn good. A lots of surprises. Probably the best episode of Game of Thrones. so many feel in this episode. sad, anger, surprise. I am not good at descripting, so all i can say is this is probably the best episode in the entire show.
reviews.author: ur69956152

reviews.content: This is my review of Game of Thrones season 6 episode 9 (spoiler free).The most challenging and beautifully well made episode of all time, there were plenty of brilliant parts in fact I think you could probably say this is the best episode in the entire season, if in fact the entire show. What I really liked was the camera angles got closer than any other camera angle would be, also the goriest battle scene ever seen. It had the feeling of claustrophobia at one specific part also the dragons were looking exceptionally gorgeous today, in fact I actually think that is the best CGI ever done in TV. Well the budget for the entire show now is $10 million and it looks like they are making that money worth it. Imagine if this were to break a World Record for most deaths in one episode if not the entire season. Anyway season 6 is the bloodiest and the best season out there, this will remain the greatest TV show on the planet especially after that brilliant episode. 10/10
reviews.author: ur53918492

reviews.content: The episode that everyone was waiting for has arrived. Suppression of humanoid monsters will be in this episode. Awesome episode, awesome writing, awesome acting to all the actors-actresses. The episode taught me that war can be won not only by the strength of the army but also by the strength of intellect, unity, courage. Another thing taught is to give a person as much pain as you can bear. Don't do anything to him that will kill you. No girl forgets to hurt her honor. Somehow, by doing something, he keeps on avenging the loss of his self-esteem. And no queen should think less. I think once in a while at the right time. One thing to always remember is that as shown in this episode, all things have a limit. Exceeding the limit is bound to cause the downfall of any human being. Speaking of episodes, I would say this is the best episode of season 6 and the whole series I saw. Let's see how good or bad the next episodes will be.
reviews.author: ur115597639

reviews.content: Holy hell! What a battle! This episode contained the single greatest battle sequence ever made for television, and I would even say it ranks high compared to movies. Miguel Sapochnik is now officially the best director on Game of Thrones (he also did last year's Hardhome). The pacing, the cinematography, the acting, the writing; everything in here was perfect. It depicts the horrors of war in such a brutal and stunning way. It feels like they've finally got the budget to take the series to the scale they've always wanted it at. Just an all around epic episode. It also plays sharp contrast to last week's episode, which I personally found slightly disappointing.Surprisingly, the episode isn't just set in one location (although it almost is). We also check in with Meereen, which is good because I thought the cliffhanger they were left on last episode would stretch for two weeks. It didn't. The episode leaps right into it. This was quite a smart pacing decision; by opening the episode with a battle, you prevent people from getting fed up with the long stretch of character scenes that precedes the other battle. Just the right amount of time was spent in Meereen this episode.But then, of course, it's on to the main event. The Battle of the Bastards. As with all the other big battle episodes in Game of Thrones, we check in with all the characters who will be fighting in the battle. It reminds us of the stakes, develops character, and builds anticipation.In this episode, we see that Ramsay is in fact a brilliant strategist. His battle plan is horrifying, manipulative, and very well thought out. The effects on the ground are very well portrayed. There is one tracking shot that follows a character through the battle that absolutely blew me away. It captures the sheer senselessness, the pure chaos of battle in such a mind-blowing way. The only thing I found even marginally disappointing about this episode was the character deaths; I wish there were more of them! But that's probably just me being masochistic.What an absolutely fantastic ride of an episode, I hope the finale delivers.
reviews.author: ur52832854

reviews.content: Even with a few writing flaws, it's the greatest war episode ever made.
reviews.author: ur85917776

reviews.content: Simply the best filmed battle of all time in any form of media. You can live a lifetime and not see art like this.
reviews.author: ur66041360

reviews.content: To say it first: I don't give very much about battles and battlefields, even if they are so-called 'realistic'.It seems that lately such stories are widely admired, where the heroes are basically not very bright (to say it mildly), and not very responsible, too. But very lucky. In this episode the "deus ex machina" had to do hard work twice. First time was OK so far, second time was not. I feel frustrated about this episode, because it could have been so much better than your average slaughter-fest. Is it really this, what so many are expecting from GOT ? I can't believe that, even seeing so many applauding here.It's almost a pity that Ramsey Bolton, who was indeed depicted as an outrageous person, also was one of the only two good strategists in this season, along with the High Septon. The others were merely driven by the circumstances or their wrong decisions, not by real initiative, and not by bigger plans. To see one declared schemer leading the cavalry was not an easy thing to swallow. It had a stale taste, which added to the mostly foreseeable and therefore somewhere boring processes of this episode. As a counter-example I recall the episode where Daenerys burns the complete leadership of the Dothrakis. That was an unexpected twist (of course announced with hints, but, well, not at such a scale).Even if it shines there and then, I think that GOT has story-wise quite outlived itself since the end of season 4. The only ray of hope this season was the reactivation of Sandor Clegane, but after we didn't see anything about him in this episode, he seems, for now, to be rather irrelevant. At least until mid-season 7 (given the ordinary pacing of GOT).
reviews.author: ur17731534

reviews.content: Let me just start by expressing shock at the reviews. What people might actually like in this episode is a complete mystery to me. Do audiences want happy endings so much that they don't give a damn how you get there? Anyway, allow me to elaborate in the form of a rant.Last we heard, Meereen was under attack by submarines, or some other kind of ship that approaches unseen. Daenerys had just returned on her somehow now trained dragon and is now looking at Tyrion with all the obnoxiousness she can muster. They then proceed to defeat the invading fleet with the aid of dragons (and well, nothing else), since the attackers had apparently never considered that dragons may be used against them in the event of a battle. Immediately after that, the teleporting Ironborn arrive at the most convenient of times (Samwell Tarly has almost reached the front door of his father's estate), and offer to help her take the seven kingdoms in exchange of independence for the iron islands with Yara as queen. Daenerys is easily convinced because a) female ruler b) she can't count, so repeatedly fails to realise that this only leaves her six kingdoms. As always, Gladstone Gander gets everything her way in unconvincing manner. Based on the speed of the iron fleet, Daenerys should arrive at the 7 kingdoms 4 episodes ago, just as Samwell Tarly arrives at his father's estate.Meanwhile, Jon prepares to attack Winterfell. Somewhere along the battle preparations, D&D take the time to use Davos in order to remind us just how much they messed up last year, as the man who once said "King Stannis is my god" now says "oh well, Stannis' death was his own fault because he listened to Melissandre, the woman I hate but also implored to resurrect some guy I barely knew, and who, as I am just now remembering? realising?, burned Sireen" (seriously, when I realised he probably doesn't even know what happened to Sireen I flipped out. His so far complete indifference towards Stannis' death is even more outrageous). We get a lot of "oh, no, the odds are against us", peppered with some "why don't you ask for my advice", "what is your advice", "I DON'T KNOW JON, JUST LEAVE ME ALONE" (should I tell him about the massive reinforcements that may be arriving? Nah). We get Rickon's death, which only says "we have no idea what to do with yet another character whose story we ignored", we get small reminders that no one has yet understood why the Umbers and the Karstarks thought disposing of Roose Bolton was a decent idea, we get to wonder how, with the addition of two of the biggest Northern Houses, Ramsay has a fifth of the laughably large army he had last season.But you know what, at least they knew. D&D knew how idiotic their resolution was. They knew, deep down, they are polluting a fictional universe with ideas that come from another (where they weren't too welcome either). So they showed the banner just so everybody watching could mock them in unison with a resounding "The eagles! The eagles are coming!". Yet again, the impeccably ludicrous timing of poor storytelling makes its appearance in the shape of Lord Baelish.Of course, some of us have been paying attention to the story. Some of us remember. Some of us know that no army from the south can cross into the north except through the almost impregnable Moat Cailin. Which is.....correct, controlled by the Boltons. Remember how Ramsay had sent Theon to trick the ironborn into leaving? In fact, some of us can deduce that much like not realising a fleet has docked in your harbour until it starts raining fire, not realising an army is marching through your lands is also a little unlikely. So, for once, everything goes as expected. For once the good guys win. And for the second season in a row, Game of Thrones gives us an outrageously bad 9th episode, all because its writers can't even imitate a poor imitator of George Martin.I know. Someone will surely say that in game of thrones, when everything turn out predictably, that's unpredictable - a reasoning which makes some sense, so you can imagine the magnitude of the failure when you are not the least surprised by the "happy" ending - or anything else in this episode. But you see, the fault lies elsewhere: "tragic" outcomes were never there (merely) for the sake of shocking the reader/viewer. They were a plausible, or probable even, consequence of the plot. In this case, it's the consequence of a sad array of bad clichés. They made a plot which relied on everything going in Ramsay's favour without explanation or feasibility, just to build up the tension for the final confrontation. But that's the way to make a Rocky sequel. Or an episode of Batman with Adam West.Last season I felt betrayed because the writers had committed an unforgivable sin by murdering (the character and whole story line of) Stannis. This year they, above all else, insult my intelligence.
reviews.author: ur22398091

reviews.content: Came to 'Game of Thrones' fairly late in the game and due to being so busy the binge-watching was gradual. Have found myself truly loving the show, very quickly becoming one of my favourites. It totally lives up to the hype and not only does it do the brilliant source material justice (a rarity in television) it is on its own merits one of the finest, most addictive and consistently compelling shows in recent years and quality-wise it puts a lot of films in recent years to shame.The previous episode is a mind-blowing experience and one would naturally think it would be impossible to top by anything that was to follow. "The Winds of Winter" actually does this impossible feat. It is an exceptional episode, what 'Game of Thrones' is all about and how to do a season finale for anything. Would go as far to say it's the best season finale of 'Game of Thrones', with the previous seasons for me the penultimate episode of each season made more of an impression than the finale whereas here the finale is on the same level of the penultimate episode and even exceeds it.Season 6 for me has had all but one episode ranging from good to brilliant, the exception being "No One", the only episode of the first six seasons to receive a less than decent rating and review (personal opinion and most likely not a popular opinion with the show having some controversial episodes and not all fans liking Season 5). Didn't hate it, but it did leave me underwhelmed. "The Winds of Winter" is the season's best.It made me truly excited for the next season. Character development and plot progression move forward and advance more than any other episode before, things are answered, some questions are raised from things being introduced and put into place and there are major shocking revelations that are game changing.Nothing can be faulted with the acting, where nobody is bad and everybody is great or more. Lena Headey being a revelation.Visually, it looks amazing, as one would expect for 'Game of Thrones'. The scenery is throughout spectacular, the sets are hugely atmospheric and beautiful on the eyes with a real meticulous eye for detail and the costumes suit the characters to a tee. The make-up is beautifully done. As well the cinematography and editing, which are cinematic quality as well.One cannot not mention the thematically, orchestrally and atmospherically multi-layered music scoring and the unforgettable main theme. Again, worthy of a high-budget fantasy/action/drama film.Writing is layered, passionate and sensitive throughout.Summing up, brilliant. 10/10 Bethany Cox
reviews.author: ur20552756

reviews.content: THE WINDS OF WINTER is a well-remembered GAME OF THRONES episode for that extended opening sequence, which ties together all of the King's Landing plots into a more than satisfying whole. The direction, from a returning Miguel Sapochnik, is inspired and beautiful and the piano score complements the on-screen action perfectly. It seems inevitable now that things would build to this moment, but what an oddly satisfying moment it is! It feels like all of the boring old sub-plots have been swept aside in readiness for the end game. A shame about Margery, but then good characters always die with bad. The rest of the episode isn't quite so profound, more talky than anything else, and the scenes with Sam and Tyrion ring a little hollow given what's come before. This is still excellent stuff, however.
reviews.author: ur0482513

reviews.content: Another season; another series of amazing episodes (not all perfect but damned good, nevertheless). We get to see Cersei's final solution. I had had my fill of the sparrows and their gods and their muscle flexing. The Queen Mother lies in the weeds and waits for her opportunity, though it ultimately is not without consequences. Once again, her offspring prove to be lacking. Alliances have been solidified and now John Snow will see the rewards for what he has sacrificed over and over. Dany and Tyrion are set to move ahead. Littlefinger professes love for Sansa. She is drawn to him, but..... For the first time, we can put together the jigsaw puzzle that is the Seven Kingdoms. Next year could be the best of all.
reviews.author: ur0278527

reviews.content: Each episode, in my modest opinion, has as axis a death. In this case - Tommen's. End of a house, in essence, it is the kick for the movements of the other characters. And the end of appearences. It is the episode of growing up tension. And the good start for a long , direct war. A young king. An open window. The only reasonable answer to the fall of his world and the end of illusions of innocence.One of pillars of bridge. The other - the presence of Samwell Tarly in Citadel. The bridge itself - new king of the North .
reviews.author: ur61197531

reviews.content: In King's Landing, Loras Tyrell and Cersei are summoned by the High Sparrow to be judged by the gods. Loras confesses, repents his sins and promises to serve the seven gods. However Cersei does not appear to the trial and Gregor Clegane does not let Tommen go to the ceremony. Margaery Tyrell finds strange their absences and warns High Sparrow to immediately leave the place. However his army does not allow Margaery, Loras and the worshipers to go. What will happen to them? Jaime and Lord Frey are celebrating victory with a feast; later Lord Frey meets an unexpected servant and learns where his sons are. Sam and Gilly arrive in Oldtown and has a cold reception. Jon Snow is having a conversation with Melisandre, and Davos arrives and confronts her about the fate of Princess Shireen. Jon Snow takes an attitude toward Melisandre. Then he meets Sansa and tells that they need to trust each other with the war that is coming. Daenerys says farewell to her lover Daario following Tyrion's advice and promotes him to Hand of the Queen; then she travels to Westeros with the fleet of Yara and Theon and her three dragons. Little Finger proposes to marry Sansa and she refuses. Bran has another vision and discovers Jon Snow's parents. Jon Snow is claimed King of the North by the other families after the speech of Lyanna Mormont."The Winds of Winter" is another excellent episode of Game of Thrones. Cersei finally shows her claws and shows no mercy to her enemies. Her vengeance is amazing and very cruel. Arya's revenge is also very creepy. The Machievellian Tyrion forces the separation of Daenerys and her love to fulfill her ambition. But Lyanna Mormont steals the show with her speech to the families from the North. My vote is nine.Title (Brazil): "The Winds of Winter"
reviews.author: ur2488512

reviews.content: The sixth season returns with more and more story than ever, and a lot of ground to cover. Previous seasons had managed this very well, and this season does it almost as well. The difference here is that the story-telling and characters do feel a lot more on the surface than before. This is seen in some specific characters but also generally across the board there is a lot less time/detail which speaks to the characters themselves. We also have some odd decisions regarding where to slow things down and spend a bit more time than in other areas – eg time spent with Tyrion drinking and joking did not seem to add as much time as it needed.Mostly the show is driven forward by the events though, and in this regard it is mostly strong. This benefits from the investment of the audience (nobody is trying to jump in fresh at this point) and this buys it some forgiveness for its weaker elements. There are plenty of dramatic moments/sequences/threads, and lots of resolutions and movement to be held by. These are delivered as professionally as the high quality we have come to expect, and there is an intensity to all of it which engages – consequences feel very real, even in this fantasy world. Some threads did not work as well; Arya's thread never really worked for me, and it felt like Daenerys has basically spent the last few seasons in a loop of similar plotting even if it is moving forward each time.Production values, performances, and dramatic spectacle all make this a season which is of the usual high standards. It continues to grip and engage, even if elements of this season were weaker and a little disappointing as to what they could have been.
reviews.author: ur1002035

reviews.content: This longer than usual episode opens with the trial of Cersei and Loras by the High Sparrow and his followers. Loras confesses his sins but Cersei declines to attend and prevents Tommen from attending; Margaery Tyrell realises that something is terribly wrong and tries to evacuate the sept; she is too late. This supporting Cersei detonate a cache of wildfire, destroying the building. On learning what has happened Tommen jumps from the keep. In Winterfell the northern families rally round Jon Snow; the new 'King in the North' and Melisandre is ordered to leave the north and never return because of her murder of Stannis Baratheon's daughter. At Riverrun the Lannisters and the Frey's celebrate their victory Walder Frey doesn't celebrate for long as Arya Stark is back in Westeros and is swift to take her revenge against him. Across the Narrow Sea Daenerys makes Tyrion her 'Hand of the Queen' shortly before her fleet finally sets sail for Westeros.After all the excitement of the previous episode I wasn't expecting this to be as dramatic as it was. It was fairly obvious that something would happen at the trial but I certainly didn't expect anything as dramatic as the destruction of the sept by Cersei, nor did I expect that by the end of the episode she would be sitting on the Iron Throne. Lena Headey was as good as ever as she coldly destroyed those who had opposed her. The fate of Walder Frey at the hands of Arya was most satisfactory and gave a delightful nod to 'Titus Andronicus' as he is served his less than appetising final meal. The events elsewhere may not have been as dramatic but they set things up nicely for things to come; notably Daenerys's return to Westeros, Olenna Tyrell's determination to get revenge for the loss of her family in Cersei's action and the families of the north rallying behind Jon before the long promised war against the White Walkers. There was also a surprising revelation concerning the identity of Jon's mother. Overall this was a great conclusion to the series; I can't wait to see how season seven turns out.
reviews.author: ur13977076

reviews.content: Great episode to end the season. Really sets it up for the next season
reviews.author: ur76062573

reviews.content: The Winds of Winter is a solid season finale, starting slow but holding weight.Cersei has everyone killed, while keeping Tommen guarded. Though he takes his own life, after he sees what's been done. This part goes on for quite a while unnecessarily, though still effective. Davos confronts Melisandre about taking Shireen's life and Jon has her banished. Daenerys, Tyrion and company sail to Westeros. Arya in disguise kills Water Frey. Sam and Tilly arrive in the Citadel. Young Bella Ramsay steals the show again, as everybody pledges their house to Jon Snow and his future endeavors.Cersei, Jon, Lyanna and Daenerys the standouts.
reviews.author: ur25775215

reviews.content: Season 6, episode 10. It is Cersei and Loras Tyrell's trial day. Cersei will get her revenge. Davos confronts Melisandre about Stannis Baratheon's daughter death in front of Jon Snow. Jon Snow is declared King of the North by several houses supporting him. Sam and Gilly make it to the Citadel. Bran learns a Stark secret. Lord Frey ends up with Arya as a surprise guest. Daenerys sets sail to Westeros - finally!10/10
reviews.author: ur35635716

reviews.content: Coming off one of the best episodes of any show of all time with last week's 'Battle of the Bastards', it was going to be hard for Game of Thrones to create something even remotely as great. To me, 'The Winds of Winter' may be even better. Not only did it give us the final shot we wanted (Daenerys riding to Westeros), but it also concluded just about every major season 6 arc in the most satisfying way possible. I don't often praise the writing and directing in TV Shows, but if there was ever a time, it is now.As episode 9's central conflict was the battle for the North, the trial in King's Landing was the big event in episode 10. And boy did it not disappoint. I think just about everyone was getting fed up with the High Sparrow, so to see him go up in the flames of wildfire was extremely overdue. With that said, Cersei's descend into madness didn't go without its unfortunate consequences as both the king and the queen met their end. Tommen's suicide seemed like a fitting way for a coward like him to go out. On the other hand, I was definitely sad to see Margaery go. I always figured if she were to meet her end it would be at the hands of Cersei, but I thought there was going to be more to her story. Luckily, we still have a few Tyrell's laying around.At first, I was confused as to why we were getting any sort of Sand Snake/Dorne scene in the finale, but when I saw Lady Olenna Tyrell, it all started to make sense. It makes perfect sense that the Tyrell's and Sand's would combine their armies, with the help of Varys, alongside Dany's to take on the Lannister's. Is there really any question Dany will have no issue taking on the Lannister's army now? Some of the Ironborn, Dothraki, Unsullied, Tyrell's, Dorne, and let's not forget 3 dragons. Come on now.Mixed in with plenty of big momentum shifters were some small but important scenes with Sam at the Citadel and Arya checking someone off her list. The somewhat comedic scene where Sam discovers the library after struggling to get past the so called gatekeeper wasn't entirely necessary, but it was nonetheless cool to see the vastness of knowledge that place holds. However, the Arya scene was easily one of my favorite moments of the night. I was glad to see the Starks finally got some sort of redemption for the Red Wedding even if it was Arya taking her murderousness one step further.The next big Stark reveal came from another one of Bran's vision, as he finally got to see the conclusion of the Tower of Joy sequence. Not that Jon Snow's mother being Lyanna Stark came as a surprise to anyone, but it finally set those theories straight. Sure, we didn't get to hear all of what Lyanna said to Ned that day in the tower, but if the not-so-subtle transition from the baby to Snow's face meant anything, I think we have another Targaryen on the loose.Speaking of which, that brings me to the ever-so-satisfying second "King of the North" moment with the North finally embracing (and remembering) who the true leader of Winterfell is, and their name is Stark. It would have been nice for that moment to feature Sansa as well, especially after all she's been through, but both are deserving. I also shouldn't forget just how good that scene between Daavos, Melisandre, and Jon was. Well written, acted (particularly from Liam Cunningham), and directed. Seems like the theme of tonight.Of course, it's not a great Thrones episode without Tyrion, who now serves as the hand of the *Queen*. Or how about watching Maester Pycelle meet his deserved end. Or Cersei torturing Septa Unella AKA the same lady? Or even the look of disgust on the face of Jaime as he watched his beloved Cersei take the throne. This episode featured just about every major character from this show and gave them each a fitting end to their arcs this season. I honestly can't speak high enough about the direction from Miguel Sapochnik and writing from David and Dan. Even just looking at the flawless transitions from scene to scene deserve tons of credit. It will go down as one of my favorite episodes of the series thus far, and certainly most important.+Impeccable direction+Winter is here+Cersei goes mad+Arya checks Frey off her list+King of the North+Tyrell's and Sand's team up+Dany rides towards the throne+Daavos10/10
reviews.author: ur39517558

reviews.content: Greetings from Lithuania.Second week in a row "Game Of Thrones" delivers a spellbinding episode. This was the best season ending of "Game Of Thrones" ever (period).As a one who haven't read books and don't like to read any theories or listen to these theories, i can safely say - i was stunned by the story and how it moved here. There were so many meaningful events, so many jaw-dropping moments in terms of storytelling and craftsmanship that it is hard not to spoil anything - but i won't and i encourage you not to read any synopsis or reviews - anything, just let this story carry you away for a magnificent 67 minutes. It's wort every second.

reviews.content: This episode was simply perfect, beautifully directed, acted and great soundtrack. It gave fans so much and gave us great shocks this show excels at. No other show in history has mastered the twist, shift or cliffhanger like Game of Thrones. I didn't think Battle of the Bastards could be topped but this episode sure did it. An iconic episode that just everything you would dream it to be. I noticed this episode was rated a 10 for a while before becoming a 9.9 and quite a few ones given probably by Breaking Bad fanboys who don't want Ozymandias to be dethroned. Well kids I got news for you, GOT has already dethroned Breaking Bad in the top TV ratings and its greatest episodes shall do the same, GOT has outclassed BB.I have said this before, Game of Thrones as a show has no equal in modern times.

reviews.content: After a pretty good first episode, the later episodes became better with strong character depth, excellent writing, and some really intense moments. The Winds of Winter continues the high standards. The directing is great, the editing is really neat, Ramin Djawadi continues to make some more beautiful music, and the script is well-written. The writing is really good, the characters are still believable, the relationships continue to shine, the pacing is really good and never drags. The story-arcs have been advanced perfectly, but since I just saw the episode, I'm not going to spoil anything.Season 6 has been a great year for Game of Thrones so far. What started out as a slow, but still good beginning, became better thanks to emotional performances from the Stark and Lannister people, strong writing, and did I forget to mention that the action sequences are the best I've seen since the fourth season? Also, with Ramsay Bolton gone, if we see the White Walkers and their leader again in the next season, things might get interesting.Overall, The Winds of Winter is another classic episode and a solid season finale. Can't wait for the seventh season! Thumbs up! :)

reviews.author: ur69956152

reviews.content: This is my review of Game of thrones Season 6 episode 10 (spoiler free)***** (5/5I just want to start by saying what a season this has been with Hodor sacrificing himself to the bumpy episodes 7 and 8 and finally with the glorious masterpiece that was the Battle of the Bastards. Usually the finale is basically cool down and just finishing off points from the season as it has been since season 1, however this ending is the best ending to a season. I mean wow when D.B Weiss and David Benioff announced that this would be the best season and also the bloodiest they were right because this was literally drenched in blood. However a few of the episodes could have been done better but it was that real clincher from episode 5 that showed us that this is the best TV show on Earth. Now that winter is here there are going to be a lot more battles and glimpses of the white walkers. I think there will also be some very big battles especially the Battle of Ice and Fire yet to come. Unfortunately there were no white walkers this episode but an amazing end, start off with that music by Ramin Djawadi which was beautifully done and from that music you expect a lot and it delivered.This episode did stick with the tradition of the usual season endings but with the first ten minutes it went okay-ish to excellent in just that short time. In conclusion with season fives ending it left little doubt that season 6 would've been an okay season but it got past that doubt and terrific style I might add, will it "hold the door?" or will it reveal it's darkest secrets in season seven to come next year. Bring it on it is going to be a long 10 months but it's going to be worth it. Best ending ever. 10/10

reviews.content: An episode where everything changed in minutes. Needless to say, this is the most popular, most thrilling, thrilling episode of the whole season. The best episode is this episode. The loss of honor was avenged, all enemies were removed from their path, some innocent people had to sacrifice their lives, some people found the place of their dreams. Some got back the truth that was so important to know. Everyone found the real king. After losing everyone, the queen of the king's court had to come. One of the girls found her name. And most importantly, decades later, the Queen of the World set out on her journey back home. Along with all this we got to see some awesome acting performances. Moreover, the identity of a great story and great writing has been found in the episode. If anyone asks me which is the most favorite episode in this whole series, I will say the most popular favorite episode in my opinion is Season Six Episode Ten.
reviews.author: ur115597639

reviews.content: What a fantastic season finale. It had everything I could have hoped for and more (except maybe Cleganebowl and Lady Stoneheart... you can't have everything). I was admittedly quite nervous going into this episode; there was so much they had to stuff in. There was the distinct possibility of this episode becoming way too crammed with things and coming across rushed, like last season's finale did. Well, I can now safely say that I need not have worried. This episode balanced everything marvellously. There were massive violent twists and big moments, but they were laced in equally with touching little character interactions. In fact, the sequence that I had assumed would be the climax of this episode ended up being at the very beginning. And what a wonderful sequence it was. Ramin Djawadi did excellent work with the score accompanying the scene; it really helped to draw out the tension.During the first three seasons, there were certainly a lot of story lines, but they all tied back into one central story-line for the most part; the war of the five kings. The Red Wedding changed all if that; sent everyone their separate ways. As a result, the story lines drifted farther and farther apart from each other as time went on. That was fine in season 4, when they were all very eventful. But in season 5, when we were in a slower stage of the story, some people felt understandably frustrated. There was no sense of general momentum running through the whole of the show. D&D knew this, and so they were anxious to get through it as quickly as possible which led to some of it coming across rushed. People started saying that the show had lost its edge. But I don't think that's what it was. I think it was just in the middle chapter. The "Two Towers" of the Song of Ice and Fire saga. What this season has done is brought things back together. These characters, with their new experiences, are put back into the game. The middle chapter is over, and that has never been clearer than it was at the end of this episode. Three sides have emerged. All the houses have rallied to one side or another. Every story-line comes into play at the end of this episode and it is thrilling (except for Gendry... I guess he's still rowing). Things are in place for the final two seasons. Here we go.One last note; I'm pretty sure that thing suspended from the ceiling in the Oldtown library is the sun thing from the opening credits. That's a pretty cool detail.
reviews.author: ur52832854

reviews.content: It's got everything action/score/politics/terrific writing/brilliant cinematography. All-around the greatest Game of Thrones episode ever made.
reviews.author: ur85917776

reviews.content: After all this time, Game of Thrones has finally corrected its many faults and paved the way for its (eventual) ending. This season did not go in the way that I had expected (given the last horrific way the last season ended) and I was very glad of it. In true Game of Thrones fashion, both beloved and hated characters die and story lines I hoped would developed more delivered well, and more. Cersei burns all her enemies, including the Tyrell children, which causes her son Tommen to rightfully commit suicide. But, disturbingly, Cersei is not as devastated as she should be, as she is proclaimed The Queen afterwards, just as her brother Jaime walks, horrified. Selling one's soul to the devil for success only brings you enemies after all. Arya Stark is back in Westeros and crosses another name off her list. Jon Snow is proclaimed King of The North after taking back Winterfell, but there is a catch: Bran reveals through a flashback that he has another highborn title as well as Stark.And, after making speech after speech of how she will conquer Westeros, Daenerys FINALLY sets sail with her boats from the Greyjoys off to the land where she once came. The abused and victimized women take back the power that was stolen from them and finally get rid of the nasty lords who try to rule over and intimidate people for power. About bloody time, indeed.Now we wait to see where these actions will take the next season.
reviews.author: ur22066568

reviews.content: Another year, another Game of Thrones season over. Season 6 of Game of Thrones is potentially one of the best season of television ever made. I thought that this season brought together all the best parts of Game of Thrones that we have started to love the past 6 years and put it into turbo mode. I think full credit to the writers being able to take this characters that George R Martin has sculpted and taken them to a whole new level.Onto the finale itself, Game of Thrones finales are always a really different format to what we are use to for normal TV finales. Normally we have to big dramatic ending with the last 10 or so minutes setting up for the next season to follow. What Game of Thrones does each and every season is have the big showstopper episode 9 and they do those last minute tip offs and set ups for the next season. Yet again we got the same amazing format this year. After the amazing Battle of the Bastards episode last week, we knew that this episode was going to be more of an all round episode that had a bit of everything.By far the biggest surprise of the episode was Cersi as the Mad Queen. I had strong vibes like many other people that this episode was going to be the end for Tommen and of course it was. What was the biggest surprise though was the end for so many other characters, most importantly, The High Sparrow and Margery. I never really took a moment to thought what the future of these characters would be for the end of the show. I just always kind of assumed they were going to just be around. But that is Game of Thrones for you. You think someone is safe, then they are gone. I have to say full credit to the director for the opening of this episode. The sequence with no words being spoken for the most part and the piano in the background just built the tone of the episode and I thought it was amazing. That can also be said with the work on the Wildfire destroying the church. I thought that scene looked amazing. Capping off everything at Kings Landing, I never thought Cersi would actually get the throne at any point. I always thought that it would go through a few hands but always be just out of reach of her. Now she is officially the Mad Queen.The other big moment of the episode was the final resolution to a point of R + L = J. While I really loved everything with Bran and how we got a sort of prequel sequence, I was waiting for it to have a overall meaning for the show as a whole. In this episode we got it. We got to see Bran follow Ned up to the Tower of Joy and get to see a little baby Jon. Anyone who was following this theory knew straight away it what was going on and knew it was Jon. For those who don't know the theory however, I thought the episode did a great transition between baby Jon and Jon now which let us easily connect the two together. What needs to be addressed next season though is that now we have the L = J part of the theory confirmed, we just have to wait to see if we get the R side of it.The last big part of the episode that I have to touch on is Daenarys. I got to say that the scene with her and Tyrion where she gave him the pin to name him Hand of the Queen was amazing. The amount of emotion that was in the scene was one of the most emotional scenes I have seen this year in television. Moving on from that scene itself, Daenarys finally is heading to Westeros. That scene at the end with all the ships and the dragons was THE scene we have been waiting for since the end of season 4. Daenarys really hit a momentum stop last season and it was finally great to have her ruling yet again and back on track of taking the thrones.The way it is heading, after this finale, I'm counting on Daenarys as Queen of the 7 Kingdoms, Sansa the Queen of Winterfell as she is the most elder Stark, Jon Targaryen is a strong force next to her cousin Daenarys in Kings Landing and good old Tyrion is acting as the Hand of the Queen with his loyal brother Jaymie head of the Kings Guard.10/10
reviews.author: ur63772799

reviews.content: Surprise. An episode even worse than the previous one. I understand lots of people loved it. I saw the ratings. In disbelief. Because it was unthinkably bad. Unthinkably. Before I attack every single part of it (save the music), let me single out two scenes:One, we finally get little needed confirmation that Jon Snow is Lyanna's son. This is made clear to anyone who had doubts in Bran's vision. Afterwards, the camera zooms in on the baby's face. And zooms out on Jon's, directly, shamelessly saying "we think fans are complete morons and may need this visual confirmation". Now, it would bother me less, if not for the fact that the entire story, every single thread of it, is written as if aimed at an audience that is composed of idiots who need this sort of visual aid.Two, Varys. He conveniently appears in Dorne in time to know already about what JUST happened in King's Landing. At the end of the episode, he's on the ship with Daenerys. If you noticed that and didn't think that the writers are far, far worse than Ed Wood, well, I give up.I had expectations from GoT. Not because it is based on a series of books that doesn't consider the reader a fool, but because the show itself lived up to these standards for four and a half seasons. Now, Chuck Norris films are more coherent.But let's take it from the top:Cersei decides to blow up the Sept and everyone in it. She has been repeatedly been described as a selfish, cruel woman who would however do anything for her children. So, logically, she kills everything and everyone her last living son loves. Then he kills himself, but life goes on apparently. Nobody cares, not for the fact she blew up the city, not for the fact she took the throne (how?). Her plan of course relied on her not being taken to the Sept earlier, on one of Qyburn's sparrows luring Lancel directly to the source of the wildfire (why) and then not killing him so he can have a chance to prevent it. Murdering all allies, check. Being left with no support from anyone, check. Make son hate me for the rest of eternity, check. Oh, wait, he killed himself. Boo-hoo. To be fair, Cersei does stupid things in the books too. Just not quite that stupid. Lest we forget, that is exactly how D&D treated Stannis. Go on and on about how much he loves his daughter, then kills her. Cersei does the same, then doesn't really care all that much. Exactly like with Stannis, D&D once again exhibit their abysmal lack of understanding of what a plot twist is. That it needs to make sense, rather than just go against what you spent much time establishing.Meanwhile, Jaime dines with Walder Frey. Then Walder Frey is confronted by Arya, who has easily teleported back to Riverrun, and using the skills she spent much time mostly failing to acquire, she kills him. Hooray, said fans who don't care if that made sense.Towards the end, Jaime teleports himself back to King's Landing.Speaking of teleportation, the queen of thorns has teleported to Dorne, invited by the Sand Snakes and Elaria, who apparently called her a minute after the explosion. Varys is there, but also super- positioned in a ship with Daenerys, who is now best friends with fan favourite *hint* Tyrion, because the show has decided to suddenly become the wet dream of those fans it thinks it's addressing. Which translates to "suddenly, le wild convenience appeared, and everything goes the ludicrous Daenerys way". Teleporting Varys, teleporting ironborn, last episode's joke of a battle, Daenerys moving to Westeros where, conveniently ( when has anything gone wrong for her?) no one is left to challenge her. Hooray, said Daenerys fans, who have long lost any demands for things to make sense.In the North, we learn two things that shed more humiliating light to previous goofy scripts: Sansa admits she knew about the teleporting knights of the Vale, but...said nothing...because....uh......uhmm.Also, Davos really didn't know what had happened to Shireen. Which means his complete indifference towards Stannis' fate makes even less sense. The northern banner-men proclaim Jon Snow king in the north (it's getting real easy). After Petyr has told Sansa every decision he makes is towards an end that sees him on the iron throne with Sansa at his side. Even, apparently, giving her to Ramsay Snow. Hooray, said fans who don't care if anything in that story-line ever made any sense.I'll admit I was wrong about Sam - he did reach Oldtown this season. Just quickly enough to ascertain that all this teleporting nonsense is not because a long time passes between scenes, but because Benioff and Weiss really don't have a clue.Lastly. Cersei's coronation was framed as a season finale. But these people are so sick, so deranged, they couldn't resist. They HAD to close in exactly the same way they closed most seasons and a bunch of mid-season episodes. With a scene that's meant to portray their favourite character in epic light. But instead causes explosive diarrhea.I really don't understand who likes the direction the show has taken. Anyone who was watching closely, anyone who was paying attention, whether they read the books or not, can see that there is no coherence, no continuity, no logic left.I understand the conventions of TV shows, but not in this case. It wasn't the way GoT was. Not for a while. If Daenerys sailing west with her buddy Tyrion, Jon being proclaimed king in the north, and Arya taking revenge makes you happy regardless of the fact that for these things to happen you watched a dreadful mess of a show, I'm sorry. You don't deserve what GoT was. You deserve what it has become.

reviews.author: ur68052788

reviews.content: Came to 'Game of Thrones' fairly late in the game and due to being so busy the binge-watching was gradual. Have found myself truly loving the show, very quickly becoming one of my favourites. It totally lives up to the hype and not only does it do the brilliant source material justice (a rarity in television) it is on its own merits one of the finest, most addictive and consistently compelling shows in recent years and quality-wise it puts a lot of films in recent years to shame.The seventh, and penultimate, season begins promisingly if also somewhat unsatisfyingly with "Dragonstone". After Season 6 finished so mightily with "The Winds of Winter", "Dragonstone" was somewhat disappointing while still being decent. As far as 'Game of Thrones' season openers go, for me it's not the best or among the best despite the numerous praise from the critics. Instead am siding more with the more divisive (with a good deal of negativity) fan reaction, leaning towards the "like it with some reservations" camp. "Dragonstone" does well putting things into place, introducing new ideas and characters and doing its best maintaining the intrigue for the existing characters. What it doesn't do so well is the lack of answers and the character and story progression, very little moves forward and can definitely understand the extended filler and uneventful complaint.Other episodes fare much better with the momentum. Most episodes are tight and do so well not feeling over-crowded despite so many characters and plot strands, while also successful in the quieter and more reflective episodes and spectacular action-packed ones. "Dragonstone" is not really either of those, and one of the not many 'Game of Thrones' episodes where some of it feels dull due to a couple too many overlong scenes that stretch the momentum too much. This would have been achieved by tightening the Brotherhood scenes and having a little less of Sam.As well as completely cutting Ed Sheeran's cameo, which was completely unnecessary and didn't gel with the rest of the episode at all. In fact, it took me out of the atmosphere completely and had too much of a felt like it came from somewhere else entirely. Euron is also very poorly written here, a real waste of space and some of the episode is on the talky side. However there are things that are very well done here. The highlights being Arya's revenge, Daenerys' homecoming and especially Sandor's atonement. With the character relationships, which 'Game of Thrones' always excels in, Jon and Sansa and Jaime and Cersei come off the most interestingly.Acting, apart from Sheeran and Peter Dinklage is wasted, is generally fine. Though it's not one of the best-acted episodes, with nobody standing out in a tour-De-force way but Rory McCann comes close. Maisie Williams, Kit Harrington and especially Rory McCann (in a powerful performance) come over best.Visually, it looks amazing, as one would expect for 'Game of Thrones'. The scenery is throughout spectacular, the sets are hugely atmospheric and beautiful on the eyes with a real meticulous eye for detail and the costumes suit the characters to a tee. The make-up is beautifully done. As well the cinematography and editing, which are cinematic quality as well.One cannot not mention the thematically, orchestrally and atmospherically multi-layered music scoring and the unforgettable main theme. Again, worthy of a high-budget fantasy/action/drama film.There are enough layers, passion and sensitivity in the writing despite all the talk. In summation, promising start but not completely satisfying. 7/10 Bethany Cox
reviews.author: ur20552756

reviews.content: DRAGONSTONE is a pretty decent opener for season seven, not without its problems but generally retaining the quality of the previous seasons. The pre-credit sequence with Arya and the Freys is pure crowd-pleasing and works very well, severing the ties of the past before getting on with the new sub-plots. These generally work, although there are two significant missteps: the scene with a cameoing Ed Sheeran is excruciating, pure self-indulgence on the part of the showrunners, and only would have worked had Arya gone on a Lannister soldier killing spree. The scenes of Sam at the Citadel are also unnecessary, toilet humour at its worst, as if the vomiting scenes in the last season weren't bad enough. Still, the material with the Hound and the Brotherhood is sensitively handled, and the rest sets the scene for what's to come.
reviews.author: ur0482513

reviews.content: With the opening scene with Arya Stark putting it over on the multitude, we are brought into the endgame. Granted, there is another season after this, but it appears that this is like a Part 1 & 2. We are given an update on as many characters as feasible with a few little twists along the way. Winter is here and the final moves to win the "Game," have begun. Being somewhat forgetful and never really studying the series, I'm never really sure who has the advantage. Or does anyone. Are the dragons the final solution? What are the alliances and who will come forward to make the difference. There are supernatural elements that could factor in as well. I am proud of myself. When Arya comes across the soldier who invite her to share their food. I said to myself, "They've got a guy that looks just like Ed Sheeran." I guess they are singing a new song that has just been written. I was captivated by the first episode and am so excited to see it through.

Nothing surprising, at the first sigh. But well crafted. And that is the source of seduction for this serie , in which power and embroideries of illusions are the lead tools for create the big story.

reviews.content: After more than one year waiting for "Game of Thrones" (the last episode was on 26 Jun 2016) and the beginning of a seven-episode season, the slow-paced "Dragonstone" is deceptive. With the exception of Arya's revenge and Samwell's discovery of the "dragonstones", the rest of the episode is boring and practically pointless going nowhere. Anyway the expectation of watching "Game of Thrones" gathering family and friends was worthwhile. My vote is seven.Title (Brazil): "Dragonstone"

reviews.content: The opening scene with Arya was awesome. She's been my favorite since the beginning and this only further proved why.But the rest of the episode was a little average, if I am going to be honest. I just don't care about the Sam character of his struggles at all. The block with House Lannister seemed to go on forever and didn't accomplish much either.I am glad to have Game of Thrones back, but people need to cool the hype for this premiere.
reviews.author: ur62702709

reviews.content: This episode largely serves to remind viewers where each of the protagonists are and where they hope to go. In the opening scene we see that Arya's revenge against the Freys didn't end with the killing of Walder. Meanwhile her brother Brandon reaches The Wall, warning of the approaching threat while their siblings Jon and Sansa disagree on how to proceed after the defeat on Ramsey Bolton and his forces. Back in King's Landing Cersei, now the Queen, is seeking new allies for the coming fight against Daenerys's forces as well as against the Armies of the North and the Sand Sisters to the south. Elsewhere Sam is trying to find a source of dragon glass and Daenerys finally returns to Westeros.I really enjoyed this episode; it started well with Arya making it abundantly clear that she has lots of people to kill. It then proceeds to remind us what other characters are up to while setting things up for future episodes. The tension between Sansa and Jon hints at possible problems to come and the meeting between Cersei and Euron Greyjoy suggests the possibility of an interesting alliance. Apart from the opening scene there is little in the way of violence; even that involved poison rather than action; that didn't bother me though as the more talky elements served to remind me of the various characters after some time away from the series. I know some people weren't keen with having singer Ed Sheeran appear as a Lannister soldier but it didn't bother me; if I hadn't heard about his appearance before watching I doubt I'd have thought anything of it. As expected the cast are all on fine form and the effects are impressive. Overall a long season opener that immediately brought me back into the story after a gap of almost two years.
reviews.author: ur13977076

reviews.content: Great episode. Lots of action and adventure and a great story
