reviews.content: Eastwatch is a bit of a filler episode, but solid nevertheless with all the best characters present.Daenerys has those of the surviving Lannister army bend the knee and join her and the Tarly's who won't executed. Samwell leaves the Citadel, to make more of a difference. Tyrion convinces Jon and Daenerys that a Wight needs to be retrieved, to prove that the Army of the Dead exists and he meets with Jaime to discuss it. Jon, Jorah and Tormund join up with Sandor Clegane and company and they set out to retrieve the Wight.Jon, Daenerys, Tyrion and Davos the standouts.
reviews.author: ur25775215

reviews.content: Season 7, episode 5. Daenerys wants the Lannister Soldiers to "bend the knee" to her. Jon heeds the warning of his brother Bran about the White Walkers. Cersei vows, as usual, to let no one or nothing stand in her way. 6.5/10
reviews.author: ur35635716

reviews.content: Wow. I'm really trying to appreciate the last episodes we have of this show because I don't believe there will ever be another show like it. For most of its run, Thrones has been a pleasantly slow-paced series. Part of its charm was seeing the show build out character arcs and plots so that when they finally paid off, it would have immense rewards. This season is an entirely different animal. Characters all of a sudden have teleportation abilities going from one side of the map to the other in merely an episode. Some people may be turned off by such a thing, I myself am just enjoying this ride. Things needed to happen faster this season and next, and the pace hasn't slowed down since the season 7 premiere. 'Eastwatch' was perhaps the least eventful episode in terms of action, but it nonetheless was full of goodies from beginning to end.There's so much to dig into, so I'll try to keep everything brief. Let's begin with Jon and Daenerys, because obviously. Let's just establish the fact that this show is ACTUALLY going there with them romantically. Don't tell me nobody else noticed how enamored Dany looked when Jon started talking about how he put his trust in her a few episodes back. I mean, wow, talk about a look. Putting aside the heritage issue, I'm all for this relationship. Which, brings me to Sam because him and Gilly literally came across the biggest bombshell of the show's history, and just swept it under the rug. I guess it's not technically official just yet, but Rhaegar and Lyanna apparently did have a secret marriage that only one maester knows about. So, in other words, Jon is a legitimate Targaryen!Speaking of bastards, Gendry finally made his return to the show tonight as he all of a sudden joined the main story thread. I would say it felt random and out of place, but his weapon is just too damn cool to say anything bad about him. This all lead to Jon, Gendry, Tormund, Jorah (yes, he returned too!), Beric, Thoros, and the flipping Hound heading to Eastwatch to try and capture a white walker to provide Cersei with proof of who the real enemy is. I'm sorry, but we just have to appreciate the Magnificent Seven of Game of Thrones taking on the army of the dead by themselves. We may not have gotten a battle this episode, but ending with them walking out into the abyss was good enough for me.I guess this brings me to Winterfell, where Bran had the vision of the army and Littlefinger plotted a little more. It seems fitting that Arya will eventually kill Littlefinger, but I'm enjoying just watching them two spy-each other-out for now. Having him set her up with the message Sansa wrote to Winterfell back in season 1 is frustrating (because who the heck would care about that at this point?) but it will provide enough weight for the tension between sisters to result in a bada** Littlefinger death scene, I just know it.There were a few Lannister reunions this week. Jaime returned to Cersei with bad news and Tyrion tried to convince Jaime to agree to talk to Cersei about a meeting between Dany and her. I almost highly doubt that meeting will ever get to face-face, wildfire is sure to play some sort of factor, but the direction they're going with this war is intriguing to say the least. To make things even more complicated, Cersei claims she is pregnant with her and Jaime's 4th child. I say claims because this could just be another ploy for her to gain Jaime's trust back, but it could also very well be real. If it is, doesn't it seem fitting that someone kills her through the gut just like the Lannister's did to Robb and Talisa back at the red wedding? Brutal, yes, but this show often provides great payback.Among other things, some great tidbits include: Jon petting Drogon! The combinations of Tyrion & Davos, and Jon & Gendry. Loved seeing a Stark and Baratheon reunion. And I'm glad Sam is finally leaving the Citadel, too bad he never found out about the fate of his father and brother. Overall, not as monumental as I thought it might be, but so dang effective. Game of Thrones has perhaps never been better than it is right now. Everything is hitting on all cylinders.+All these great dynamics+The Magnificent Seven of the North+More surprises+Jon and Dany potential romance+Gendry is back10/10
reviews.author: ur39517558

reviews.content: A scattershot clockwork of updates and minor machinations, paltry plot pivots and pirouettes that had our heads spinning. Nothing happened, yet somehow everything changed.
reviews.author: ur91222832

reviews.content: Eastwatch was a decent and reasonably high quality episode. It had some great moments scattered through the whole hour. Despite its great moments there were also some issues. The biggest being the length and even pace of the episode. We are given 7 episodes this season and I feel many fans expected the events and intensity to be taken up a notch. However this episode and probably the earlier ones were somewhat slow and maybe even not too eventful. Also I think it would be very hard to follow from last week's Spoil of War episode which was what fans have been begging for. Now don't mistake me, this was a great episode with big moments such as Jon Snow petting the Dragon and the Night King scene. I think this episode and perhaps some of the first ones could have been shortened to 50 or so minutes so we could have additional episodes to make it 8 or even 10! I think many fans might feel the same where we could have had more episodes and more enjoyment if episodes were condensed and less scattered and more focused. Take the last episode which is supposedly the shortest and one of the most acclaimed episodes. I feel next week could be a big episode so I will wait in anticipation. 8.5/10
reviews.author: ur51094543

reviews.content: Bran Stark's Reconnaissance Drones (Ravens) fly to the North and see the Huge White Walker Army.British Queen Cersei Lannister does not believe there is a threat coming from the North, the White Walkers, nor do most of her Allies they believe that this is a ploy to have their Armies moved from Strategic Defenses against Dragon Queen Daenerys Targaryen's Army. Note, Fact, British Law, to keep the Royal Lineage intact is still in effect as "Incest", "Inbreeding" but not enforced according to current British Queen Elizabeth. In recent News, 2017, current British Queen Elizabeth announced she would not rescind this British Law, regardless of the opinions of the British House of Commons.U.S. Army Special Forces Team lead by King of the North Jon Snow conducts U.S. Army Special Forces Arctic Warfare as a Direct Action "Snatch and Grab" Mission of a White Walker. Personally, I would have had Dragon Queen Daenerys Targaryen armed with Dragon Glass Weapons flying on a Dragon go look for herself, grab a White Walker, and dump the White Walker at Cersei Lannister's door step.Meanwhile CIA Operative Arya Stark conducts Intelligence and Counter Intelligence Operations and discovers a possible internal threat as Petyr 'Littlefinger' Baelish.Intelligence Analyst and Bureaucrat Samwell Tarly as one of the only people to kill White Walkers finally decides to join the fight to the North. Hoping that he stole critical information to finally defeat the White Walker's King from the CIA Database he travels North with his Wife and Child.
reviews.author: ur75193729

reviews.content: Eastwatch isn't a terrible episode. Far from it. But after a promising start and three solid episodes, this is my least favorite. Unbowed Unbent Unbroken wasn't my favorite episode too but at the very least it had some intensity and atmosphere. Sadly that's not the case here. The pacing did dragged, there are some scenes that are rushed and other scenes that lacked logic. Also the writing wasn't as strong as the previous episodes and the previous seasons as well with dialog that lacks the pathos of the previous seasons. That being said, everything was fine. The acting is still great with everyone still giving superb performances and characters still be interesting the best coming from Tyrion and Cersei. The directing/editing is neat and the music score from Ramon Djawadinis still beautiful. Overall not terrible and quite decent but my least favorite episode of the seventh season sadly.
reviews.author: ur26083589

reviews.content: The story-telling is really fast. this episode set the direction of the next two episodes. the meeting at Kingslanding and the mission to capture the zombie.
reviews.author: ur69956152

reviews.content: I can't say that this episode is one of my favorite episodes but yes I can't say that it is one of the worst episodes. It's something that took the story a little further. There are some new twists in this story that the viewers may not have been expecting in any way. Evidence is needed to determine if a monster really exists or to let people know. Finding evidence requires courage in such a horrible place. The story of this courage is narrated in this episode. When one's family has moved far away from one's homeland by mistake, then many years later one has to come back to that place and stand in front of one of the members of the family. That courage is spoken of in this episode. And when it comes to acting, everyone's performance in this episode has been really great from all the other episodes. The directors and writers have done a great job and have been shooting in some great locations.
reviews.author: ur115597639

reviews.content: The fan theories floating around are more developed when they are leaked and I think the director/writer should respect the audience's IQ. Alan Taylor who directed some episodes of Season 1 and 2 should be bought back in the helm. His direction was fantastic and I still remember him, can't say if the North remembers him or not!After Joffrey's fate, the series is going in a downhill. The library reading session was quite lame and boring. Every character is travelling like they are using a helicopter. Come on writers, everything seems a bit rushed and forced!With the concentration on narrative, we're left with an outing that can't help but feel like it's lacking where it really counts. In short, old wine in a new bottle!
reviews.author: ur21054934

reviews.content: After the collosal that was last week's episode, I wasn't sure where they were going to take this episode. Part of my wanted them to keep pushing on towards the end with spectial after spectial, but at the same time, it is those smaller set up moment of Game of Thrones that makes me enjoy this show the most.This episode turned out the be the second option and I'm happy it did because this is my favourite episode of the season so far. This episode was all set up for what is coming but still had some massive moments that stood out.As usual, this episode was so wonderfully written. There were some terrific exchanges of dialog throughout the episode as well as some well laid out story beats. Some personal moments that stood out for me this episode would have to be Little Finger planting the note of Arya and Tyrion having a meeting with Jamie.OWn the first one, while Little Finger is a character many love to hate, there is no doubting that he is playing this game for the throne better than anyone. He is the Palpatine of this universe and he is constantly pulling the strings from behind the curtain. It's not hard to see why he has lasted so long in this world and part of me wants him to last as long as possible.Onto the Tyrion and Jamie and their meeting, I thought this was a big stepping stone towards what might come in the final season and a half. For me I believe the White Walkers are the end goal and they are starting to hint at that more and more. I think if the Lannister army is going to get on board with the fight against the White Walkers, the relationship between Jamie and Tyrion will be key.Overall, while there isn't too much to say about this episode, I loved it. Everything that happened felt like it is setting up for something and there was no fat that had me bored at any point. Look forward, I'm really excited to see what is going to happen with Jon and his small pack heading beyond the wall. I imagine it is not going to end too well for some but end very well for others so we will have to wait and see.10/10
reviews.author: ur63772799

reviews.content: I actually liked this episode, probably for a bit different reasons than many. Of course, nothing makes much sense anymore, but that's been going on for a while now.After being thrown into an abyss three centimetres away from where his horse was galloping, Jaime is drawn out of the river by Bronn. The battle is over, and they are really far away from it, leading to all sorts of hilarious conclusions about their ability to travel underwater while in full armor. Just the sort of terrible writing you've come to expect in the show's latest seasons. But then comes the good part, as Hitlaerys Targaryen gathers up the remaining Lannisters and gives them Sophie's choice: Submit to her, Hitler, first of her name, Fuhrer of the Andals, the Rhoynar and the First Men and bend the knee, of be burned alive. Randyll Tarly and his son, whose knees do not bend easily, become the first martyrs in Daenerys' reign of terror. Now now, wait a minute. I think I got carried away a little: Tyrion and Varys are seen worried about the Mad Queen, but we all know D&D do not have the mental capacity to actually make this happen - it's just some temporary sub-plot to later "relieve" the audience by reassuring them Daenerys is actually good. Nonetheless: offering a glimpse of Daenerys' true repulsing self is very satisfying, even if her illiterate fans who are actually thrilled at the hint of a romance with Jon (for pity's sake) will still justify it.At Winterfell, Arya offers some terrible advice to the usual bad- advice giver, Sansa, and is then easily tricked by Petyr into discovering something meant to cause strife between the sisters. At least Littlefinger did something remotely devious for the first time in many a season.Back in Oldtown, the ancient cliché of "grey old wise men are wrong and young enthusiastic Sam is right" continues, as Sam simply ditches them, which is a bit silly, as the entire plot in Oldtown appeared useful in discovering something Stannis had already told him and that idiotic cure of greyscale - they sent him there, but ignoring the whole magic subplot of the books, he had little business to do. Anyway, Sam is a likable character, so not a total waste.On Dragonstone, they decide to send Tyrion to negotiate with Jaime a meeting so that Jon can bring a zombie and convince the Lannisters of the threat in the North. Join is joined in this quest by Mormont, who apparently simply took the first ship to Dragonstone. Naturally, Tyrion, smuggled by Davos, is in sunny King's Landing within the hour, as such a meeting is really easy to arrange. Meeting is over before you know it, Davos retrieves Gendry and they are on their way. Meanwhile Cersei seems to imply that meeting with the enemy is a good chance to dispose of the enemy, but I can already see a Jaime disagreement when he sees evidence of white walkers. The Gendry retrieval is just another case of fan service (complete with meme reference...), which has been the doom of the show and half the reason for its downward spiral in plot quality - however, I will admit I liked how he is modelled after Robert Baratheon, that was a good touch.Jon and his companions leave Dragonstone and are back at Eastwatch- by-the-sea instantaneously, taking the superluminal travels of the show to a whole new level. Indeed, it is buffling that they still send ravens, when everyone can simply walk a letter across at least one continent in half a day. There they find the Hound, Beric and Thoros who strolled across all of Westeros and were captured just around the corner. They pick them up to go to this rather ill-advised quest, which will probably already be over in the next episode, and they may still have time to go to King's Landing for coffee.
reviews.author: ur22398091

reviews.content: It was a great episode and great sense of story with the great thrilling but Danerays shouldn't have killed those two men with the fire who showed a Danerays little mercy less.
reviews.author: ur68052788

reviews.content: This episode along with this season and the last episodes of season 6 is the perfect example of when Script writers are left to their own imagination to write the story of a progressing series.With the first seasons, we get to see amazing television show, with some of the most gripping and twisting story telling. The show showed us that every action has a repercussion. Ned Stark wanted to be noble and Honorable, got captured and killed, Rob betrayed Frey's and we know what happened to him.But now that the show has surpassed the books, the writers are back to writing just typical television where the main characters are invulnerable from their stupid choices. Jaime rides against a dragon, and miraculously escapes not just the fire but capture as well. How does he swim underwater for miles while wearing chain mail, armor and his 20 pound hand? how did he not drown? or get caught by the dothraki? But fine, what about the easy way out that they show Little finger leading Arya? in the past it was done very subtle and not to in the audience face. If you didn't see it, well to bad you missed it. Now its "Hey, look at this. Do you like how we connect the dots for you?"Why bother watching if everything is put on a plate for you? where the characters travel thousand miles in 5 minutes. Do you remember how first season, you would have 2 episodes of just Brann, and Arya and you are just waiting to see what happens to the others one, but they don't show everyone in the same episode? yeah me too.
reviews.author: ur65362228

reviews.content: The opening scene means something. Not that Jamie lives – that was obvious. But we are strongly reminded than Bronn has no real loyalty. Any betrayal he may do later on has been sensibly foreshadowed.We are fed rival ideas about Daenerys – torn between her father's madness and decency. We see that Jon can make friends with a dragon, the first after Tyrion to get close and live. But she can also be alarmingly ruthless.Plot hole – the monarch can order someone to 'take the black' or die, but anyone can also do it without the monarch's permission. Why won't Randyll Tarly do this, which would also let his son survive? Sam Tarly never notices evidence that will prove that Jon is the legitimate son of Rhaegar Targaryen. He is also the last Tarly, though still vowed to the Night Watch and does not know it yet. He might put forward his supposed son – whom I suspect is another Targaryen, Maester Aemon Targaryen having been Caster's unnamed father. Regardless, he is 'back in play'.Another plot hole – Sam should suggest that the Maesters send someone north to investigate the Dead, and interview those who have seen them. But in a US series, one would expect intellectual to be treated as learned fools.Then the big surprise – the two Queens may actually make peace to deal with the Army of the Dead. Most of us expected the final battle against them to happen in Season 8, after Daenerys destroyed Cersei. But it's hard to believe that even George R. R. Martin would let the dead be the victors, so this as the final battle would have lacked tension. Instead we may see the Night King fall, possibly with one White Walker surviving to rebuild for another try in some future winter. Meantime the Iron Throne may remain an issue for the final season. Cersei as victor is not impossible, and Gendry is back in play.Meantime Arya mistrusts Sansa and spies on Littlefinger. But Littlefinger somehow knows about her. May be playing a deeper game than we've been led to believe, possibly an ally of the Night King. Regardless, we are probably building up to a grand confrontation among the surviving Starks.
reviews.author: ur1980731

reviews.content: Season 7 has to be one of the best seasons so far of Game of Thrones, despite moving remarkably fast. Eastwatch allows us to breathe after the epic episode last week, and does so in a very character driven way.We open with a brilliant scene between Bronn and Jamie, then are taken to another visually breathtaking scene of Tyrion walking through the ashes of burnt Lannister bodies. Peter Dinklage is truly a master actor, he didn't even have to say a word in this short scene, because his face says it all. He's torn, you know he wants to stand by Dany, but also doesn't want to see his family ruined. The meeting between Jamie and Tyrion was very brief, I would loved to have seen a little more of that, hell even a good scene between Tyrion and Bronn. I sorely missed their on screen duo. The scenes in the North were great also, I loved that not everyone is getting along, as it should be. Arya is calling Sansa on her bulls***, and conducting her own little investigation on Littlefinger. I also loved seeing Baelish doing his sneaking things again.Sam's scenes were more or less the same, but this time he's gotten sick of being told what to do and takes a stand, which I really liked, it shows how much his character has come from the punching bag from season 1. And am I the only one that caught that sneaky line with Gilly reading the marriage certificate? We know what your doing D&D you smart bastards.We get a brilliant meeting between all our favourite characters towards the end of this episode, and I can't wait to see them in action. You know that some of them are going to die, and please I hope the Hound, Jon and Jorah survive. I won't be Game of Thrones without them.Eastwatch is a very character episode, with great production designs, as always, great acting, and a fantastic build-up, to a next episode that is most likely going to be freaking mind-blowing.I can see some people having an issue with this episode, and that would be all the time jumps. Throughout this whole series, things have moved reasonably slow. Characters would take seasons to get from one place to the other, but in this episode, they transport here and there within just a view scenes. But all this is understandable. Things are ending now, the Game is nearly over, and things are moving fast. 9.6/10
reviews.author: ur65076361

reviews.content: Game of Thrones remains a masterpiece, as always !!! Best Serie ever!!!
reviews.author: ur105190054

reviews.content: Came to 'Game of Thrones' fairly late in the game and due to being so busy the binge-watching was gradual. Have found myself truly loving the show, very quickly becoming one of my favourites. It totally lives up to the hype and not only does it do the brilliant source material justice (a rarity in television) it is on its own merits one of the finest, most addictive and consistently compelling shows in recent years and quality-wise it puts a lot of films in recent years to shame.Was admittedly expecting a big improvement over the disappointing "Eastwatch" Unfortunately, "Beyond the Wall" is even more of a major disappointment. After much debate (after re-watching), have decided that it replaces "Eastwatch" as the worst episode of the seventh season, and for me it's one of my least favourite episodes of 'Game of Thrones' episodes along with "Eastwatch" and Season 6's "No One". It's not an abomination, but for such a great show like 'Game of Thrones' a barely average episode feels nowhere near good enough.Of course "Beyond the Wall" certainly has good things. Visually, it looks amazing, as one would expect for 'Game of Thrones'. The scenery is throughout spectacular, the sets are hugely atmospheric and beautiful on the eyes with a real meticulous eye for detail and the costumes suit the characters to a tee. The make-up is beautifully done. As well the cinematography and editing, which are cinematic quality as well, while the special effects are among the best of the latter season episodes.One cannot not mention the thematically, orchestrally and atmospherically multi-layered music scoring and the unforgettable main theme. Again, worthy of a high-budget fantasy/action/drama film. The acting is, considering the material, quite good, though no tour-De-force performances. Like with all episodes, there are good scenes in "Beyond the Wall". The best being the battle between the White Rangers and the dragons, with thrilling epic spectacle and particularly incredible special effects. There is some good character interaction, with the standout (one of the best things of the episode and one of the most interesting and entertaining elements of it) being the northern raiding party interactions. Jon swearing fealty to Daenerys was the one emotional moment. However, there are disappointing elements which generally have been covered already. There are no real surprises or shocks, the only shock being one of the show's biggest character losses. Other episodes do a much better job advancing characters and progressing the story in general. There is nowhere near enough of that here, other episodes even do far better setting things up and putting things into place with one here being too distracted by the writing issues than notice whether the episode did this aspect at all let alone do it well. "Beyond the Wall" is far too rushed, making events feel choppy and jumpy. Too much of the story is not developed enough, with ridiculous implausibility and logic-defying present to maximum effect (and this is excluding everything to do with the much criticised time line) that affects the coherence and ability to take it seriously. It is very bland too, very little intensity outside of the aforementioned scenes and the same with the emotional level (which is very low too). Stakes seem to be incredibly low here, due to an uncharacteristic over-obviousness, almost everything being predictable, and things happening and resolving far too easily.For a show whose scripts are generally thought-provoking, layered, passionate and sensitive, the writing here majorly disappoints once again and actually the complete opposite. Here, like in "Eastwatch", the writing is forced, repetitive, bland, simplistic and far from subtle. The character writing has been far meatier, nuanced and complex, here apart from Tormund and Daenerys the characters are either out of character (Jon for example) or have lost what made them so great (especially Tyrion).Overall, watchable but underwhelmingly average. 5/10 Bethany Cox
reviews.author: ur20552756

reviews.content: BEYOND THE WALL is a very good episode that just lacks the level of greatness thanks to a few problems. Getting all of the likeable hero characters together in a group for an epic quest is a very smart move, but I do wish there had been more wit in terms of the dialogue, which too often resorts to playground humour of the sort that's been overwhelming this show for the last two seasons. When you have actors of this charisma and calibre, you want more. Still, the visuals are wonderful and the special effects superb, and there's genuine menace, eeriness and tension throughout in the White Walker scenes. I do find the Arya/Sansa scenes ridiculous in their conception and Maisie Williams laughable when she tries to do menacing. Still, the climax of this episode is a shock I found even more upsetting than the Red Wedding, and that counts for a lot.
reviews.author: ur0482513

reviews.content: I'm always amazed at the pain suffered by the audiences of virtually any presentation; but when it involves a fantasy based on a book, watch out. I admit this is weak. First of all, having to bring one (count it, one) of the walkers back seems like a silly strategy. Did anyone realize they are an endless hoard? That little circle of guys going into the den of the dead is absurd. Their survival for as long as they could was itself pushing the limits. How they saw themselves coming out of this alive is preposterous. Dany is possessed and she pays a price for it. We know Cersei. How is this whole thing going to change anything. Kim Jong Un is a minor leaguer compared to her. Anyway, there's a long battle sequence and I guess some really go for that So be it I'll be interested to see what the narrative hook will be as we end the next to last season.
reviews.author: ur0278527

reviews.content: The precision of each level of episod could be the first virtue. But not the last. Because the mix of love story, proof of the real menace, the interests and apparences and desires and the fantastic scenes of the wight capture and fall of dragon and the terrible demonstration, front to Cersei court, of the wight are more than impressive. A splendid work and inspired storytelling.
reviews.author: ur61197531

reviews.content: Arya shows the letter she found and has an argument with Sansa at Winterfell. Jon Snow and his group capture Wight but ad horde of Wights hunt them down. The escape to a frozen lake and Jon sends Gendry to return to Eastwatch and to warn Daenerys. Jon and his group are under siege of the Wights that decides to attack them. Out of the blue, Daenerys come with her dragons to help Jon Snow and the hunting party. Will they succeed in escaping?"Beyond the Wall" is another spectacular episode of "Game of Thrones". The segment of Arya and Sansa is promising, but the hunting of a Wight by Jon Snow and his team is magnificent. The attack of Daenerys and her "sons" is also great and the final plot point is totally unexpected. My vote is ten.Title (Brazil): "Beyond the Wall"
reviews.author: ur2488512

reviews.content: The battle sequences were fun to watch, even though aesthetically GOT has given us better, and you kind of had to throw logic out the window with what 6 people were able to do against an army.They further established the White Walkers as a serious threat, and for those of us that love the dragons we got hit in the gut not once, but twice by the end of the broadcast.A little long, and the Arya and Sansa scenes were weak, but overall another strong episode.
reviews.author: ur62702709

reviews.content: This episode is dominated by Jon, and his band of men, as they head north of the wall intent on capturing a single Wight to prove their existence only to be forced to battle an army of them. Back at Winterfell Arya confronts Sansa about the message she found in Littlefinger's room; then Sansa makes a disturbing discovery in Arya's room. Meanwhile at Dragonstone Tyrion counsels Daenerys.I really enjoyed this episode; while we didn't get the best battle of the series it was still pretty good even if we have to suspend disbelief as the main characters survive virtually unscathed when outnumbered hundreds to one. That doesn't mean there were no losses; in fact one will almost certainly become very important when the final battle between the living and the dead eventually takes place. Before we get to the battle scenes these characters have some enjoyable interaction as the chat and goad each other. The events at Winterfell are less dramatic but no less interesting; Littlefinger is clearly scheming to turn the Stark sisters against each other but to what end currently isn't clear. The scenes between Arya and Sansa were a highlight of the episode for me; Maisie Williams and Sophie Turner were both on fine form. As expected the special effects were great and the scenery impressive but strangely the thing that impressed me most was the way it captured the feel of being in a blizzard with its grey/blue tinge; one could almost feel the cold. Overall an impressive episode.
reviews.author: ur13977076

reviews.content: This episode they go beyond the wall with surprising results
reviews.author: ur76062573

reviews.content: Beyond the Wall is the weakest episode of the season, with almost the entirety being the groups retrieval of the Wight.Sansa fears for her safety from Arya. Daenerys comes to rescue the group, but loses a dragon to the Army of the Dead in the process. The whole venture seems unnecessary. Jon and Daenerys get closer.Jon, The Hound, Arya and Daenerys the standouts.
reviews.author: ur25775215

reviews.content: Season 7, episode 6. Jon and men want to prove to the two queens the White Walkers are real - they go out to capture one but things go wrong, Daenerys shows up with her dragons and one of them dies north of The Wall. 6/10
reviews.author: ur35635716

reviews.content: It's extremely hard for this show to match the anticipation from week to week. Beyond the Wall is one of the most highly anticipated episodes of this show's storied history, so it's not a huge surprise that not everything lived up to expectations quite as much as one would hope. With that said, the Night King has a frickin dragon on his side now, that's just about as monumental of an event as this show could have ever given us thus far, so I won't sweep that under the rug.Beyond the Wall mostly played out how we thought it would, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but a lot of the surprise was gone. The idea of bringing a 'White' back to south of the wall was one of the dumbest ideas I can remember, but I bought into it strictly based on the validity of the actor's performance's. However, they pulled it off. They lost Thoros of Myr in the process, and had Gendry walk all the way, only to have him run back and send a raven to Daenerys. It wasn't an entirely successful trip, considering all that happened but the production was certainly something to behold.How gorgeous were those wide shots of them walking in wastelands filled with ice and snow? Which brings me to the other thing I loved about this episode, those conversations between Tormund & The Hound, or Jon and Beric, or Jorah and Jon. Just so many untapped dynamics at play tonight, and they all played out wonderfully. That is, up until the point in which an undead bear attacked the group, nearly taking out Thoros. That was only a taste of what was to come at the arrowhead mountain. Fighting each 'White' off one by one, it was only a matter of time until they all died, as Tormund nearly did, only to be saved by Dany and her three dragons. A rather easy fix you may say, until Daenerys loses one of her children, in one of the saddest Thrones' deaths of all time. Rest in peace Viserion.The very thought of having an Ice Dragon on the Night King's side is terrifying. Isn't it funny though that we all thought there may be a chance Jaime or Bronn were going to kill one a few weeks back? But the tables have turned. No longer can the people of Westeros think about the Throne, this is a time to set our eyes on what the Night King is doing. He has Walker Giants and now an Ice Dragon. How will anyone survive. This didn't stop the show from throwing in a few hints at things to come as Tyrion gave Dany a speech about succession and Jon held Dany's hand like he wanted to be her King. It's those things that are going to lay the groundwork for what's to come after the Night King is over and done with.On a different note, Arya and Sansa had a mental sparring session this week as the former lectured Sansa on how she should be acting and questioned her true intentions. At this point, these little fights seem entirely pointless and frustrating considering we know they aren't going to kill each other. Which is why it's unfortunate that there wasn't much movement on the Littlefinger front this week, other than him essentially asking Sansa to get rid of Brienne? I don't know, that whole side arc was weird and disappointing. Hopefully, next week will provide some clarity.Overall, it was yet another brutal week of Thrones, if only there was a little more surprises and less goofy sister talk. But as I said, having an Ice Dragon kind of tops everything.+Battle+Ice Dragon+Jon & Dany progressing+All the dynamics+Jon's resilience-Arya/Sansa stuff a little disappointing9.5/10
reviews.author: ur39517558

reviews.content: Greetings from Lithuania.So "Game of Thrones" have finally hit the Hollywood in every meaning of this word in "Beyond the Wall". "Beyond the Disbelieve" - this is how this episode should have been named. As much as spectacular and at some points breathtaking this episode was, i was like "NO FUCXXX WAY THIS IS POSSIBLE" constantly during second half of this episode. I won't spoil it (although i would like to), but it is NOT possible any way it turned out here, even in a fantasy genre. I mean do they have like a GPS and teleport in that world? How much time it takes to simply travel in there?Now for 4 seasons "Game of Thrones" was the only show that almost literally could shock my and pulled a rug from viewers - it was unpredictable like anything out there. But from last season and especially this one, i do believe we will see a happy ending in this show overall. Sure some side characters will die, but it won't be as effective as in the past, because they don't have time to properly show it! This season is rushed as hell and i do believe that future book / books will be even more popular by simply telling this story in non rushed way.Overall, as much as spectacular "Beyond the Wall" was, i can not rate it any higher then 8 (and that is only because of great craftsmanship of the scenes) because of how unbelievably predictable it all turned out. And predictable in a most simple "Hollywood style", like we have seen in countless forgettable great looking movies. As it looks now, happy ending is not far away.
reviews.author: ur4405474

reviews.content: A super-sized episode that never came across as underfed, Beyond The Wall delivered on some of the iconic moments that we've all been waiting for since the series' inception.
reviews.author: ur91222832

reviews.content: Excellent episode from Game of Thrones. The story and scenes with the Wight Walkers are always captivating and chilling, no pun intended. The Night King is arguably one of the greatest foes in a TV History, without saying a single word and using his presence and gaze he has spoken volumes about the danger and harm he brings. The scenes, camera work with the Wight Walkers surrounding the small crew were great to watch. Arguably the best scene was the Night King using a glass spear to take down the dragon. Despite being a top episode I was also slightly disappointed. I found the close calls and scenes with Jon Snow and his men somewhat predictable. We somehow knew Jon Snow wouldn't die, that Danaery's would come to the rescue just in time and some even called it that the Dragon would be resurrected by the Night King since they took it beyond the wall. Not to mention the absurd plan to take a few men out to army of the dead to capture one soldier. As if they would stand idle while they took one. The King in the North who won the Battle of the Bastards should have known that was not the best of ideas and a suicide mission. My only hope is that it is a false sense of security and we can see some shocking events and even deaths. This is what makes GOT stand out for years, shocking deaths and big twists. I will off course await with eager anticipation for the finale which is where no punches are pulled.9/10
reviews.author: ur51094543

reviews.content: I actually quite enjoyed Beyond the Wall; I'm not gonna lie though, the pacing was fine at times and others it was too uneven. But in the end though, this episode along with its follow-up The Dragon and The Wolf proved to still be a very good slice of television. Beyond the Wall has some impressive fight scenes but the sense of Deux Ex-Machina is noticeable (or maybe Lord of Light Ex-Machina); however there are set-ups for some of the things that happen. It's not all just coincidence, with the exception of Benjen Stark saving Jon Snow from the White Walker 'zombies'.Is this Season Seven's best? No. Is it the worst Game of Thrones episode? No. Is it flawed but still competently done storytelling? Yes; I'd certainly say so.The following episode is undoubtedly stronger in my eyes, but this one provides the set-up of a re-animated dragon set to blaze Westeros.
reviews.author: ur24085266

reviews.content: Beyond the Wall isn't exactly a terrible episode. In fact, there are some things that saved it. As usual, the visuals/scenery is gorgeous, the performances are still good though not in the same league as in the previous seasons, the character interaction is nice, and some of the sequences particularly the White Walkers and the dragons along with Jon Snow and the others fighting the White Walkers are well done and Ramin Djawadi continues to compose some beautiful music.Unfortunately, there are some problems that made the episode more disappointing and my least favorite episode of the season next to Eastwatch. That episode was my least favorite too along with the sixth season episode No One, but at least they tried to do something interesting and while Unbowed, Unbent, Unbroken is also my least favorite, it was from my standpoint marginally better thanks to it's intensity and atmosphere. Sadly, the same thing can't be said here. The writing is bland and lacks the complexity that made the previous seasons so interesting, the pacing dragged on a bit too longer, the dialog isn't as fresh as the previous episodes, and most importantly, there weren't many surprises and plot twists.Now, this review isn't going be popular in the next few years and i'm very sorry to disagree with the rating on this website and the critical acclaim this episode received, but Beyond the Wall, despite some good moments, is my fourth least favorite (I might re-review No One from the sixth season someday to see if it holds up or now because many people didn't like it) and a disappointment to the seventh season. Hopefully the season finale might improve in my next review.

reviews.content: The wight hunt plan in this episode look stupid. but thought the director and writer make it seems smart. there are a lot of plot holes in this episode. but those plot holes are must and make the story fun to watch.

reviews.content: I will say a little differently from everyone else, I was reading the reviews, most people said that the episode is not good. I just want to ask them why this episode is not good. I think this episode is better than that. We saw some things change. Some of the changes that are justified will be understood in later episodes. So look at my advice very carefully, there are family quarrels in this episode, there is death, there is transmission of life, there are monsters, there are monster oppressors. Awesome Dialogue Delivery Awesome Writing and Awesome Management All in all an awesome episode.

reviews.content: Some things don't make sense!Jon Snow keeps fighting a bunch of low level enemies for no reason instead of jumping on the dragon and he goes under the ice and manages to free himself from the white walkers.Uncle Benjen Stark does easy kills with his super effective fire weapon on his horse, but why didn't he and John Snow rode the horse together?At the end, one dragon would be resurrected by the Night King after crashing in the ice was also predictable.Still, a bit more interesting after the 'unwatchable' Episode 5.

reviews.content: Well this was predictable. What you might ask...EVERYTHING. YEt there were zombies, so I am torn.The whole season seems to be a pointless romantic engagement between the fake blond tiny dragon queen and lil johnny snow. There's not even any real intrigue or good amount of progressive story to make it all feel worthwhile anymore, I just want it to end. The previous season had better pacing and more grit, and I began to dislike the show beforehand. Still we got what we expected, some more shots of the undead, a bit more cold north country, blah blah blah. And then came dragons, and what a disappointment they were. They stood no chance, when they could have easily burnt away the night king, but oh no they had to pull an "eagles" like move like the LOTR did to ferry the protagonists away in the nick o time. Then the undead somehow managed to find and use, as if outta thin air, enough giant steel chain to wrap around a small cruise liner, pulling the felled dragon from under the watery ice where it died. RIP OFF of World of Warcraft Lich King expansion much? Perhaps the scene is from a book in the franchise that was written and printed before WoW came out, but as this episode is near the end of the tale, I doubt it. BUt it is a TV adaptation, and I didn't read the book ( thank goodness)And in the end: ice dragon. There's only one more episode left in this short season, and though the zombies were cool, thats about all I am rating this so highly on. What happened to the ta tas?! T.T

reviews.content: Wow. Wow. So Jon and some others go behond the wall to grab a white walker btu stuf hapens. I mean zoom and boom and plot twists. Wow. Possibly the best episode of game of throne sso far. You have to see it to believer it. Watch in Full HD to get the full experience. Wow. Sorry, I can;'t stop saying wow. It was amazing.
reviews.author: ur55532299

reviews.content: That time of year has come when Game of Thrones is up to their big second to last episode of the season, the spectacle of the season. This of course comes some 3 week earlier than normal due to the shorter season, but my excitement for it was tanished by that. For me the show has really started to vamp up in recent weeks so I couldn't wait to se what they could give us.It's rare I do this but I am going to start with some negatives of this episode, and by that I mean just one negative. This episode was amazing as expected, however there was two sides to this episode and one of them simply was not strong at all. The side I am talking about is of course Ayra and Sansa, more specifically Ayra herself. I said last week that I liked how Littlefinger was starting to build tension between the two sisters, however in this episode I didn't really like how it played out. There is always a chance that Ayra is playing Sansa and everything she said was all a game, but at this point I don't think this is the case. I thought the scene we got between the sisters were terrible. Ayra's writing was sloppy and it felt very unlike of Ayra. I know it is Littlefinger's job to start unnessarsary drame but in this episode I thought that Ayra really took that ball and ran with it.Negatives aside, and into the meat of this episode, the second side of the episode did enough for me to not only save this episode but make it memorable. In many ways we got what we wanted in a human vs dead fight but we got so much more than that.This episode did what Game of Thrones does great and throws in the unexpected. While I don't think things like Daenarys, Jon not dying or even Benjen coming to the rescue were completely unexpected, it is other things like the taking down of a dragon and being reborn to the dead that was completely unexpected. Like many people I was on the edge of my seat in shock like many others around the world. This changes the landscape of Game of Thrones. There are still three dragons out there, but one is the living dead.While still on the dragon attacks, the attack itself was a spectacle to watch. While I don't think it quite matched up to the first attack we saw earlier this season, it was great to see all the dragons in action for the first time.The end battle was always going to be the highlight of this episode but I thought there were still some great dialog scene, excluding that of Ayra and Sansa. I thought the scene with Tyrion and Daenarys was fantastically written and for me is going to be remembered as one of my favourite scenes of the season.Before wrapping up I want to talk about a theory that has been going around that Bran is the Night King. While I believe that in some way, Bran does have a connection to the Night King, I personally don't want it to happen. For me it is a situation of making the world feel too small. We already have a lot of intermingling between the families and everyone is connected to someone else in some way which I am okay with, just I want there to still be a part of Game of Thrones that is the unknown. We have seen Bran discovering stuff about the White Walkers and that has been interesting, but Bran being the Night King is a connection I do not want.Overall, another great penultimate episode of Game of Thrones. While I thought some of the B story line fell a little flat, it is hard to overlook three dragons killing a bunch of White Walkers, only for one of them to die and be reborn to the dead.8.5/10
reviews.author: ur63772799

reviews.content: The very end of the episode is great; the battle is quite spectacular. But this episode is the culmination of everything that has gone terribly wrong with GoT ever since it went full Hollywood. You have great action, drama, a powerful ending, and yet everything happens in such a void of logic that it ends up being laughable and infuriating at the same time. To me anyway - a friend expressed the view that if you take it for what it is, just d&d (the other kind) low fantasy with battles between adventurers (+1d6 fire damage longswords) and undead it's still very enjoyable. But I think one ought to judge a show by the standards it sets.Most of "Beyond the Wall" is about Jon and his companions (plus a few extras who play the role of red-shirts) trying to capture a wight. In the only non-related plots, Tyrion tries to convince Hitler not to be a pyromaniac mass murdering tyrant, but she, expectedly, refuses to listen, while in Winterfell the showrunners have turned Arya into a really annoying person. There is honestly little reason for her animosity towards Sansa. On a sidenote, Jon, king in the north, declined to inform his people that you know what, I'm not on Dragonstone anymore, going north of the wall for a bit, brb.Anyway. The motley crew of adventurers starts off with some rather poor dialogue between Tormund and Sandor, and some trite, but better written, exchange between Beric and Jon. Soon after, they encounter a patrol of wights with one White Walker. He is easily killed, revealing VBI (Very Bad Idea) number 1: killing the white walker also destroys all the undead they have "created". A plot device which is usually a poor gimmick to heal vampirism or something is here turned into huge foreshadowing as later someone says "if you kill the Night's King...", pretty much telling us how the final battle will be resolved in disappointing fashion. Conveniently, one of the undead remains un- alive allowing the heroes to capture him, but his screams alert a much larger host to their presence. Then, Jon tells Gendry to run back to Eastwatch and send word to Daenerys that they got their prisoner. When this happened I was scratching my head, thinking this makes zero sense, as telling her you succeeded in the mission is only useful if you survive to produce him to the meeting. As events unfolded, I began to realise the point, as I reached the inescapable conclusion of just how shamelessly the situation would be resolved. You see, the undead surround the group, who reach an outcrop in the middle of a frozen lake. The lake collapses beneath the pursuers, trapping the group in the middle. But wait - there is hope in the form of VBI 2. Gendry reaches Eastwatch, sends a raven to Dragonstone, Daenerys comes pick them up. There are more things wrong with this than I can fit in an IMDb review, but let's start with the glaring obvious:1. an army of undead can arguably cross the lake. In fact, they later emerged from beneath the water. Besides, it's supposed to be really, really cold. They could probably guess that after a while, they're good to go. If not them, their bosses.2. Speaking of really, really cold. Our heroes were trapped for...under normal circumstances, it should be a week at the very least. In the distorted time-space continuum of D&D's terrible writing, it was let's say a day. Heck, make it 15 hours. They were standing almost still, exposed in Antarctic winter, for 15 hours, but hey, no problem. Ready to fight.3. Speaking of distorted time-space continuum, spare us. It would take longer to send a message and receive reinforcements if they were using cellphones and fighter aircrafts. Yes, I should be used by now to how the writers are unable to fathom distances and time, but it seems like things are getting stupider with every episode.4. As if that was not enough, Jon is left behind, because, for reasons beyond anyone's understanding, instead of climbing on the dragon with everyone else, he spends a few minutes fighting skeletons and then shouts "leave without me".5. But wait! There is more! He then falls into the frozen lake, but, you guessed it, climbs out. In fact, when he wakes up afterwards, he doesn't even have a running nose.6. Not done. Eagles in the form of dragons was not enough Deus ex Machina for one episode, so after climbing out of the lake, Jon is saved by Benjen Coldhands Stark, who just appears, gives him his horse and then re-dies(?) undeservedly.7. Bonus. Since it takes her 5 minutes, wouldn't "let's just fly there so you can see the white walkers exist, and maybe grab a wight on the way" have been a vastly better plan?Of course, the important thing is that when Daenerys comes to save them, the White Walkers throw a javelin and casually kill a dragon (Viserion, named after the disliked brother - even there they couldn't be original). A powerful scene, but the set up to it was so annoyingly lame that it loses strength.After the battle (and somewhere in the middle, talking with Tyrion) Daenerys shows she's falling for Jon, in a way more disgusting, cheesy and cheaply fan-servicing that I could believe. The actors are OK, they may even have chemistry. But it's so devoid of sense, so obviously made to appeal to the unthinking majority (and no other reason) that the whole thing seems like a parody.Of course, at the end, we get the White Walkers dragging the dragon out of the lake and turning him undead. Given that and the ease with which they killed him, one is inclined to believe them unstoppable. Sadly, obvious foreshadowing already spoiled the end.

reviews.content: WHAT HAPPENED!!!!!!!!!!!!! last season this show was great! THIS SEASON IS THE WORST STORYTELLING AND WRITING I've SEEN IN AWHILE!!!!!!!!!!! especially because there is no reason for the dip in decline except a stupid decision to fast forward the plot and simultaneously hitting the PAUSE on several others that shouldn't be treading water, what bran could tell us for example, yet the farting showrunners and writers gotta keep those reveals for the last season because now that it's become a mainstream generic, just like all the other predictable mainstream shows, it has to now follow the formula that it spent 6 years trying to destroy.OH HEY GUESS WHAT BENJEN STARK OUT OF NOWHERE TO SAVE JON FOR THE SECOND TIME IN A DEATH FAKE OUT THIS EPISODE! talk about plot armor jebus
reviews.author: ur17658515

reviews.content: From the people who use to bring you creativity and shock, thanks to mainly having great source material to write from. Now that the show has surpassed the books, we can clearly see the change in quality and not in the good way. You would think now that everyone is on the same plain field, one would think it would be easier to please everyone. Which is not the case, as the writing is just taking all the fans and anyone who has a brain for a joke. There is no longer time or distance in the show, no essence of danger, no shocks, no patience for the audience to understand or let the story progress in a normal way. Everything has to happen now and in each episode, with no time for the audience to feel anything. Now with this episode I have to call it, this is stupid. After looking into the game of thrones maps, and taking on board the distances between certain places have come out with the most shortest and fairest distance between Eastwatch and Dragonstone is around 1700-2000 miles. An average speed of flying bird is between 20-30 mph... Assuming here that the G.O.T ravens fly at 55 mph it would take the raven 31 hours just to get to Dragonstone. now also allowing the dragon to fly at 155 Mph with someone on their back not falling off, would mean that Daenerys flight back would be 11 hours if she flew with no stops and a map of exactly where to go to Eastwatch, not to mention where they are in behind the wall. Remember she's never been up north nor behind the wall. So in total that's 42 hours of straight flying with no breaks, stops or looking around for directions. In the episode we see the guys walk out of Eastwatch in the morning, they walked before capturing the walker, and when they told Gendry to run to Eastwatch it was evening. They got stuck on the frozen lake, and the next day they started to fight and got saved by the dragons. Now that means that less then 24 hours have had to pass. Assuming that they didn't start to fight in the early hours of the morning, at most 16 hours had past since Gendry left them. 16 hours vs 42 hours?? Come on G.O.T get your act together! If you need a new writer, feel free to contact me. Not to mention the fact that the whole surprise ending was not even funny. We know from previous episode that whatever dies get turned into the walker, they killed a polar bear at the beginning of the episode, and we have seen other animals be undead too. So why did fans were in shock when it happened? and didn't even ask the questions where the chains came from?...
reviews.author: ur65362228

reviews.content: Came to 'Game of Thrones' fairly late in the game and due to being so busy the binge-watching was gradual. Have found myself truly loving the show, very quickly becoming one of my favourites. It totally lives up to the hype and not only does it do the brilliant source material justice (a rarity in television) it is on its own merits one of the finest, most addictive and consistently compelling shows in recent years and quality-wise it puts a lot of films in recent years to shame.Season 7 was by far the weakest and most frustratingly uneven season of 'Game of Thrones', with the only great episodes being "The Queen's Justice" and especially "The Spoils of War". The season sadly also boasted two of the show's worst episodes "Eastwatch" and "Beyond the Wall". "The Dragon and the Wolf" is certainly better than those two episodes, but it doesn't end the season with a bang, is the very meaning of an uneven episode and easily the weakest season finale of all the seasons. Of course "The Dragon and the Wolf" certainly has good things. Visually, it looks amazing, as one would expect for 'Game of Thrones'. The scenery is throughout spectacular, the sets are hugely atmospheric and beautiful on the eyes with a real meticulous eye for detail and the costumes suit the characters to a tee. The make-up is beautifully done. As well the cinematography and editing, which are cinematic quality as well, while the special effects are among the best of the latter season episodes.One cannot not mention the thematically, orchestrally and atmospherically multi-layered music scoring and the unforgettable main theme. Again, worthy of a high-budget fantasy/action/drama film. The acting is, considering the material, quite good, though no tour-De-force performances. Like with all episodes, there are good moments in "The Dragon and the Wolf". The best being the powerhouse scene between Tyrion (given his best material in a while) and Cersei, the dragonpit meeting, the demolition of the wall and Cersei's decision. There are moments of passion and sensitivity in the writing, some character and plot advancing and a few revelations and answers provided. The acting is some of the best of the season, the standouts being Peter Dinklage, Lena Headey and especially Aidan Gillen. However, some other moments do not work. The worst being the dull, forced and childish romance between Jon and Daenerys, with a sex scene that served no real point and was just a cringe-worthy watch and Jaime's reaction to Cersei's decision which was out of character. Littlefinger deserved a much better final scene than the anaemic one he had, considering how great a character he was, while Jon and Euron are not very well written (Euron has been poorly written all season and Jon has gotten duller with each episode). The lineage revelation was not that much of a surprise. Pacing-wise, "The Dragon and the Wolf" felt rushed and jumpy, a general problem with Season 7, the characterisation has been meatier in other episodes and the writing continues to have what was particularly disappointing about it in the previous two episodes.Overall, not bad at all but uneven, that could have been grander and more fire-blazing considering it's a season finale. 7/10 Bethany Cox
reviews.author: ur20552756

reviews.content: THE DRAGON AND THE WOLF is a strong closing episode for season seven, perhaps a little overlong here and there but with much to recommend it. The scenes in King's Landing have more style and intrigue than in recent episodes and the meeting of pretty much all of the major characters is handled in a strong, efficient way that's true to each character in turn. You feel that the actors are given more to do in this episode, and although I don't like this season's Littlefinger sub-plot, at least Aiden Gillen and Sophie Turner have material to get their teeth into. The season also concludes with the best cliffhanger - almost literally - of its entire run, thus finishing things on a real high.
reviews.author: ur0482513

reviews.content: So much is being made of this episode, I can only humbly add my two cents worth. With all the evil at work, we are shown forces for good and an effort to salvage the world. The wight is brought to Cersei and supposedly she is going to agree to fight for the common good. I wonder if she could sell used cars. Like truly benevolent people, those who met with her take her at her word. We have an interlude where Littlefinger's reign of dishonesty is put to the test. We find that blood is thicker than water when it comes to Arya and Sansa. Jaime, who has always been a truly complex character, shows us an honorable side. Jon Snow's lineage is revealed. Being a bastard is often what paints the good with a brush of evil when one looks at classic literature. How many good bastards are there in Shakespeare? Get my drift? But in any series, we have to have a hook to get us thinking about the next episode. I have to say that the final five minutes of this episode was as powerful as anything I've ever seen in cinema, any cinema. The cinematography, music, and special effects are nonpareil. And the writing, allowing us to match up forces that must settle everything is truly pregnant. It will be hard to match what happened here, but I have faith it will all be settled in the most professional way possible.

reviews.content: It defines not only the episode but it is the key for the next one. Like the fall of Lord Baelish. Like the meet between Arya and Sansa as parts of the same Stark coin. The basic virtue of episode- to build, in wise manner, the truth - seed. And, sure, the return to Winterfell as a new beginning for Stark power with new , strong, roots.And, sure, the great end.
reviews.author: ur61197531

reviews.content: In King's Landing, Daenerys, Jon Snow and Cersei have a tense meeting where they show a wight to Cersei that does not accept the proposed armistice. However, Tyrion has a private encounter with her and she changes her position. At Winterfell, Sansa brings Arya to accomplish a death penalty for murder and treason. Then Samwell has a meeting with Bran and they discuss Jon Snow's lineage. At Eastwatch, the Night King riding his dragon and the White Walker army attack the Wall. "The Dragon and he Wolf" is another excellent episode of the Seventh Season of "Game of Thrones". The only remark is the discussion of on Jon Snow's lineage that deserved to be longer and better explained. But every segment is great and shows surprises, like Cersei and Sansa's decisions. My vote is ten.Title (Brazil): "The Dragon and the Wolf"
reviews.author: ur2488512

reviews.content: I don't think that I'm alone in thinking that this truncated seventh season of Game of Thrones is not as good in many ways as those that have gone before. In previous seasons I always enjoyed how they kept so many plots going, so many plates spinning, and were able to create engaging threads/characters with comparatively little screen time. They seemed to be able to make big things happen with short but meaningful interactions, while also allowing plenty of breathing room for some scenes or set pieces. That situation is very much reversed in this season, although it does have a lot to help balance it.The examples of this are numerous. They range from threads that don't really work because they lack detail of the character motivation, through to the 'fast-travel' element where characters seem to jump all around the map in hours rather than months (an element made more obvious by all of the previous seasons playing out most journeys over many episodes or seasons). Enough has been said about this, and I do sort of agree with those that question why viewers can suspend disbelief in dragons and undead armies, but can't just go along with the timelines – but for me it is that it undermines a solid base on which the fantasy show was built, and makes it broader and weaker.This broader and weaker elements do at least have plenty of good to counter it. The base of previous seasons, and investment in characters do help of course, but the compression of events has been used to cram a lot of large set pieces into the 7 episodes. These big moments are as memorable as they are narratively weak; again there are many examples, but the one that stuck with me was the field of fire – a brutal battle which does a great job of flipping us emotionally to feel for the Lannisters, but then ends with Jamie somehow surviving and then swimming underwater for miles to pop up at the start of the next episodes (and seemingly nobody thought to try to capture him or check if he was dead). This sort of thing is common in big moments and small interactions – in the bigger picture it is still good and engaging, but there is also something, or some omission, that undercuts how effective it all is.I don't see the problem going away soon; the final season will only be 6 episodes, although I hope they will not all be limited to 60 minutes. Looking at the scale of what remains to be played out and resolved, it looks impossible (unless they use the same 'on-screen text' device that Quantum Leap used to tie it all up). Of course I will be there to end the story and enjoy the scale, spectacle, and drama of the bigger picture – but the years in-between will also send me back to watch previous seasons again, where characters had more time, and drama played out at a more satisfying pace.

reviews.content: Game of Thrones concluded its penultimate season with an episode that featured reveals, callbacks and some remarkable visuals.The final battle scene with The White Walkers and their new secret weapon was incredible. We know they won't prevail, but we have to see how the good guys come up with a way to beat them next season. It was a heartbreaking moment to see such an iconic character to this world be used for evil. We saw an individual who evaded punishment and death so many times finally meet his maker.This had drama, some action, it was everything a season finale should be.
reviews.author: ur62702709

reviews.content: As season seven comes to an end most of the protagonists have congregated in King's Landing to discuss a possible truce so that the living can, if not fight together against the dead, at least not fight each other until the dead have been defeated. It is not as easy discussion as certain people refuse to make promises they cannot keep and others make promises they don't intend to keep. Back in Winterfell Lord Petyr Baelish is attempting to poison Sansa against her sister leading to a trial that doesn't quite go as expected. Also at Winterfell Sam arrives and a conversation with Bran about Jon leads to a surprising revelation. Further north the Army of the Dead have arrived at The Wall and the war between the living and the dead finally begins.This episode got off to a fine start; there was good some verbal sparring as various antagonists meet before the captured Wight is shown to the assembly. We then get some interesting negotiating as we see how much various characters value their word... not that this is too surprising. The events at Winterfell did provide a surprise and those complaining that no long serving character has died for ages should be pleased... unless of course they think the wrong character died. It looked as if the action would be limited to the demonstration of how to kill a Wight and a one on one fight between Theon and an Iron Islander who didn't agree with his plan to rescue his sister... then we get the attack on the wall; even though the 'big surprise' was not that surprising it was still spectacular. If there was a weakness in the episode then it was probably the sex scene between Jon and Daenerys as it didn't really add anything and took us away from more important matters. The cast were on good form, most notably Aidan Gillen who was great as Lord Baelish, one of the series most enjoyable characters. Overall a great season conclusion; I can't wait for season eight.

reviews.author: ur35635716

reviews.content: It's not like tonight provided any classic Game of Thrones 'shocker' moments. In reality, we knew Cersei wasn't actually going to go along with the truce, we figured Littlefinger would meet his end sooner rather than later, it was all but confirmed that Jon was the son of Rhaegar and Lyanna, and it was inevitable that the wall (or one section of the wall) was going to come down by season's end. So really, the 4 biggest shocks or twists from the episode weren't all that surprising, but it's the execution that counts. If there's one thing that Game of Thrones always does right, it's the execution.Starting off in King's Landing, because everything always comes back there, we got at least a half an hour of extraordinary direction and writing. I think a lot of people have complained about this season revolving around dialogue instead of things actually happening, but I eat all this dialogue up. How can you not appreciate all of the brilliant blocking in the dragon pit? There's so many dynamics, so many reunions, and so many important meetings. The Hound and The Mountain, Theon and Euron, Jaime and Brienne, and of course the long- awaited meeting between Daenerys and Cersei. There's so much to cover in such little time, and I thought the writers handled it brilliantly. We didn't get Cleganebowl, but everyone did finally see the real threat that's out there. The moment that everyone sees that wight is probably the most significant thing to happen on this show to date (which has been said a lot the past two seasons). All the back and forth, including an emotional discussion between Tyrion and Cersei, led to the result of Cersei ultimately agreeing to fight alongside Dany & company in the great war. Only to then secretly betray them. Classic Cersei. Luckily, Jaime finally gathered up the strength to go against his sister and love of his life, to head north to fight. It's the redemption we've all wanted from him from the get-go. By the way, where's Bronn? I don't believe I saw him join Jaime so we can only assume he's chilling in some brothel somewhere. Meanwhile, everyone made their way back up north traveling via boat (and not dragonback). This is where we find Jon and Daenerys doing what some people have wanted them to do for a very long time. I'm honestly not sure how I feel about it. It's disgusting for one, but this is a fantasy show that has presented such intimate relationships more of the norm than it should be. Plus, it's not like these characters know that they're related.yet. Yes, Bran has finally spilled the beans. God knows why he told Sam of all people and not his own siblings. But I guess they had their own quarrels to worry about. Speaking of which.Rest in peace Littlefinger! Well, sort of. It's not like he was a good person, in fact, he rarely ever did anything of value. But I will definitely miss his character, and I'll certainly miss Aidan Gillen, who's one of the few original cast members to die in the past few seasons. Which brings up that "issue" if you can call it that. How is this show going to service all of the remaining characters and their inevitable deaths in a mere 6 episodes next season? I think there's maybe a dozen characters, maybe, who are safe till the end of the show's run. But I can imagine at least a couple every episode being killed off next season. I don't think I can wait 2 years for that.Things to look forward to next year: Jaime fighting with the good guys! Jon finding out the truth. Cersei messing everything up. The Night King kicking a**. The inevitable queen-slayer moment. Arya crossing a few more names off her list? And of course, Jon being too damn honorable. Oh and by the way, it's snowing in King's Landing. It was a quick season, but definitely one of the best ones yet, if not the best. Let's hope next season gets here faster than we think.+Starks finally stick together+Everyone in King's Landing+Cersei stays evil+Jaime's redemption begins+Jon & Dany+Baelish says farewell+Down goes the wall10/10

reviews.content: A decent finale to end season 7. I won't go into detail as another person wrote a great review which summed the finale as an episode of great execution. We kind of expected certain moments such as Cersei going back on her word and Jon and Daenery's becoming an item but it was the beautiful execution and delivery that made this a great finale. Perhaps the best moment was the end of Littlefinger, this death was satisfying and overdue. A number of fans loved this character but it was good to see him finally taken out and by the dagger he used to lie and set two major houses against each other. The Night King and his army of the dead taking down part of the wall and marching past was well executed and a treat to watch. While we knew about Jon Snow's lineage it was nice to add more to the theory, he is not a bastard after all. Season 7 has now sadly concluded. It contained 7 quality episodes, some were far better than others. I and I'm sure many other fans felt the pace and/or intensity would increase but we didn't see this so much. With only 6 episodes to go now to wrap the show up it seems the final season will have to convey volumes and intensity could be the constant. Now the long wait begins for our beloved show, I thought waiting one week for the next episode was bad but 1.5 years seems brutal.9/10

reviews.content: Extra Warning: MEGA Spoilers Follow:This episode was 'fucking amazing'! Where do I start? This could be screened at the cinemas and could passed up for a feature film thanks to its cinematic pacing, 81-minute runtime and scale of an epic movie. The Dragon and The Wolf had so many great moments in it, from Cersei seeing the white walker, to the revelation that Jon Snow is the heir to The Iron Throne, this episode is chock full of moments sure to become classics in television history; and I haven't even mentioned Petyr Baelish's death scene, which was beautifully satisfying stuff.If there's anything wrong with this episode, it's that we may have to wait until 2019 to see television's best show finish its ambitious story. That'll be a sad day when Game of Thrones is finally over. Until then, we can rewatch the previous seasons over and over and speculate endlessly as to what will happen in the end.10/10; a modern classic.

reviews.content: I understand that some people didn't like this season finale despite being well received by critics when it premiered on tv, but for me, this is one of the best episodes even though the other season finales were much stronger. Yes the sex scene between Jon Snow and Daenerys felt out of place and the pacing was quite uneven this time around, but there are other things to like.The scenery is still gorgeous, the visual effects are still beautiful, the directing and editing is sharp, and Ramon Djawadi continues to make more beautiful music. And most of all, the acting is still great with the best coming from Lena Heady, Peter Dinklage, and Aiden Gillen in great scenes including the conversation between Tyrion and Queen Cersei about what happened in the fourth season which and Littlefinger finally getting what he deserved ever since the first season where he manipulated everyone including the Stark family. With him gone, however, who else will survive in the battle against the White Walkers for all the seven kingdoms? That question will be answered when season 8 comes.Overall, a great episode and while it's not as strong as the other season finales, it's still worthy for those who continue to love this show. Thumbs up!

reviews.content: After finishing its seventh season, I've reached the point where I'd name "Game of Thrones" as the best fantasy I've ever read or seen. It's also among the best television I've ever seen, period. I'd cheerfully rate this penultimate season a perfect 10.I do understand some of the criticisms I've read from other fans. Yes, this shorter, more eventful, seven-episode arc could seem a little rushed when compared with prior seasons. And certain plot points in the last several episodes here are easy to nitpick.But I can't give less than a perfect rating to a show that I enjoyed this much. Season 7 added great action and special effects, lots of momentum, frightening horror, and some long-awaited conclusions to story arcs that began back in Season 1. And the show still has the best dialogue of any current television show that I'm aware of, usually supported by terrific acting.I won't say more for fear of spoilers. But I obviously loved this season.
