reviews.content: SO here it is, yet another nail in the coffin of jerk around cliff hangers that have made Game o Thrones the pinnacle of lame wannabe suspense that is all too obvious to predict. When I want to be messed with, I go see a film by M. Night shama however you spell his name. Though I keep watching G.o.T. , there is so little tangible fantasy content in other media I cant tell why I am still watching. Cause it is not to say that Thrones really has that much magic at all.If you look at the Lord of the Rings franchise, it is bland compared to some things that have come in recent years, but as the progenitor of modern fantasy, its still chock full of more magic and fantasy elements than Game of Thrones. Yet why is G.o.T so popular with lackluster season finales like this?!A conference to speak is held between the remaining powers of the continents, except for the one central bank in the world that is happy sitting back and growing fatter off of whomever is left to do business with. Oh but don't fret, there's undead and an ice dragon, yes. At the end of the entire episode. It seems like way too much of this franchise is just spent with frivolous banter that is little more than verbal masterbation. Whole seasons are little more than cheap stepping stones to a single pivotal season, that then transitions back into a season of little consequence once more. This is poor plot creation. At least put some more ample sized breasts on some 20 something year old women. We don't need more male appendages in an HBO show, hell throw some lady parts in there, my eyes are thirsty :P. This show had better end by season 8, because if I wanted to get jerked around, I would just do it myself watching something that actually promises boobs and lady parts.
reviews.author: ur57088858

reviews.content: Absolutely love 'Game of Thrones', which at its best made for one of the best and most addictive shows in recent years and one of my favourites. This was when gradually binge-watching when first starting watching the show, just under two years ago, with so many of my friends recommending it to me. The source material is brilliant and wholly deserved to be adapted in a way that did it justice, and the show more than does that and stays true to its written roots.When at its best, so Seasons 1-5, one had to actually check that it was made for television when everything is done to such a high level that it puts many films made today to shame. For me, and many others it seems (some people even dislike it, didn't think it was that bad myself), Season 7 was uneven and frustratingly so, boasting the only great episodes being "The Queen of Justice" and "The Spoils of War" but also two of the show's worst episodes ("Eastwatch" and "Beyond the Wall"). It is too early to tell how Season 8 is as a season as it has only just started. On the most part, "Winterfell" was not a bad episode at all from personal opinion. It is nowhere near 'Game of Thrones' at its best and has a few big problems that were present in Season 7 and had the opportunity to be corrected here but weren't, but at the same time there is a lot to recommend and it serves its purpose well.Starting with the things that could have been done better, one of "Winterfell's" weaker assets is the writing. It is not terrible, but underwhelming. It is thought-probing and has passion and sensitivity in parts but lacks nuance and felt childish at times and didn't always flow. Didn't think the attempts at humour were welcome and instead were out of place.Momentum was not always there either, it can be slight structurally and at times feels like the show's running out of material and over-stretching itself. It is a deliberately paced episode, purposefully, and did have times where it did feel too slow and could have done with more tension. The characters are still interesting, serve their purpose in the episode well and are well acted (a great job was done with Samwell), but to me the way they were written was far meatier before (Tyrion being a big example), actually did not think there was quite enough time to get to know or familiarise with them properly with so many of them and their subplots.However, there is an awful amount to recommend "Winterfell". Even if the episode didn't do much for me, it still would have gotten a personal rating of 5 at least because the good things were so brilliantly done. Visually, it looks amazing, as one would expect for 'Game of Thrones'. The scenery is throughout spectacular, the sets are hugely atmospheric and beautiful on the eyes with a real meticulous eye for detail and the costumes suit the characters to a tee. The make-up is beautifully done. As well the cinematography and editing, which are cinematic quality as well, while the special effects, while not the very best of the show, put many recent shows and films to shame. One cannot not mention the thematically, orchestrally and atmospherically multi-layered music scoring and the unforgettable main theme. Again, worthy of a high-budget fantasy/action/drama film.It has been said that the writing and characterisation has been much better before, but as said too the writing was far from a mess and the characterisation did interest, with Sam showing a lot of complexity and a wide range of emotions and a lot of it is down to John Bradley's intensely deeply felt performance. He is the standout when it comes to the writing, which was good and even more than that throughout and all round, though only he really comes close to being a tour de force. The storytelling does well in achieving its aim, which was to set up the season, introduce chess pieces and put them into place. This is not a bloodthirsty and full of action sort of episode, there is a quieter and more reflective tone and although some may not think so perhaps to me 'Game of Thrones' has excelled equally well in the quieter episodes as it did in the more action-heavy and weightier kind of story-lines. Alliances are formed, any reunions are nostalgic, nothing really felt padded and there is story advancing if not quite character advancing (this is not a filler episode and is an important one for setting the season up). Furthermore, it was great to feel refreshed in re-knowing the characters and what had happened to them before instead of spending the whole time confused, something that is something of a miracle considering how long it's been since the previous season (Season 7) and my increasing problems with memory recently. The standout was Jon and Arya's meeting, which was also the highlight of the episode and was surprisingly tender.On the whole, not a bad episode at all but an uneven one. 7/10
reviews.author: ur20552756

reviews.content: Season 8 is the most divisive in the whole history of GAME OF THRONES, but so far we're off to a good start with this opening episode. Generally it works well, although Arya's still oddly off and there's at least one childish and stupid interlude, the dragon flying sequence between Jon and Daenerys, which feels like it belongs in a Disney film - a shame that CGI budget didn't get added to episode three. Otherwise, this is well directed and entertaining, with lots of interesting meeting and dialogues between characters who haven't seen each other for years. A set-up episode, for sure, but one that works.

reviews.content: After the events of season seven we are told the Army of the Dead are now south of the wall. Forces are grouping in Winterfell preparing for the battle that is sure to come. As the episode opens Jon Snow and Daenerys arrive; they don't get quite the welcome they hoped for... many there aren't happy that Jon has bent the knee and accepted Daenerys as the rightful queen of all of Westeros. The meeting of forces means that several characters who haven't seen each other for a few seasons are reunited. Back in King's Landing Euron Greyjoy arrives and meets with Cersei; while he is ashore Theon moves to rescue his sister Yara.In many ways this episode feels like it is there just to remind us of who all the key characters are and how they feel about each other... something few fans will need even if it is a while since they watched the previous episode. Apart from Theon's rescue operation there is little in the way of violent action; this was one of the episodes main highlights. Other highlights include Daenerys telling Sam that she had executed his father and brother for failing to support her; Arya and The Hound meeting again and some banter between Tyrion and Lord Varys. As one would expect the acting is solid and special effects are top notch. Overall a decent enough season opener that acted to set things up for what is to come and nicely raised tensions between some characters who are allies for the time being.

reviews.content: Well, we've made it, it's finally here! Game of Thrones has finally arrived once again, after almost 2 years on hiatus. It returned for what was for all intents and purposes a slowly paced episode, but one that needed to be that way. I mean heck, we got Jon riding a flipping Dragon and no one is even talking about that, instead, we are discussing the endless amount of reunions this week.Tyrion & Sansa, Jorah & Sam, Arya & Jon, Arya & Gendry, Arya & The Hound, Theon & Yara, Sam & Jon, Jon & Bran, and finally Jaime and Bran. That's a whole heck of a lot of screen time dedicated to dialogue between characters.Let's begin with where the season, and quite frankly the show, begins, which is at Winterfell. I love the callbacks via aesthetic to the first episode when King Robert arrives at Winterfell, just as Jon & Dany arriving side by side, come North. They even used the exact same theme that Ramin Djawadi used for Robert's arrival all those years ago. One shouldn't be surprised that Dany didn't receive the warmest of welcomes from Sansa and crew. Sansa in these scenes reminds me a lot of how Cersei acted around Margaery, does she not? Cold, cautious, and weary of what it could mean for her family, and she is clearly taking what she learned from Cersei and using it against Dany right now. I can't imagine that will stick, but it's worth mentioning.Speaking of Dany, she went through quite a bit last night. Finding out, ever so briefly, that one of her dragons is a part of the Night King's army now amidst finding out that Jon's best friend is the brother and son of two Tarly's she burnt alive last season. I love that this sequence comes right after Jon tells Sansa "she will be a good Queen, she's not her father" just as Sam finds out the horrors that his family went through via fire and blood.Arya & Jon had a sweet moment together, a clear callback to Season 1 Episode 2 in which Jon gives Arya 'Needle', now having Jon show her his sword, Longclaw. She also ran into Gendry & The Hound once again, both quick but well handled snippets of screen time that I sure hope we get more of this season.Jon rode a dragon! Admittedly way sooner than i figured and not in the same context as I thought, but it will still neat. The scene was the only one I felt a little bit off about, as it was merely there to re-establish their romance, not all that necessary to the plot as of now.Have we talked about how creepy Bran is? What was there like 5 scenes in this episode where he was just lingering in the background staring at people? "waiting for an old friend"....ahhh very unsettling. Lastly a few other tidbits worth mentioning: Theon save Yara (that quickly?), Yara provided us with context as to where everybody may stay after the Battle of Winterfell is inevitably lost, Cersei bed with Euron, The Night King sped through Last Hearth, Bronn received an offer from Cersei to kill her brothers, and Jaime arrived in Winterfell. I cannot wait to see how that plays out next week.9.5/10

reviews.author: ur40127150

reviews.content: At its very best, so the best of Seasons 1-5 mainly, 'Game of Thrones' made for one of the best and most addictive shows on television and even when gradually binge-watching it became a personal favourite. The source material is brilliant and wholly deserved to be adapted in a way that did it justice, and the show more than does that and stays true to its written roots.With Seasons 1-5, one had to actually check that it was made for television when everything is done to such a high level that it puts many films made today to shame. Season 7 was disappointing and frustratingly uneven, with only two great episodes (especially "The Spoils of War") but two of the show's worst episodes came from that season too ("Eastwatch" and "Beyond the Wall"). Am aware that many fans were disappointed by the eighth season premiere "Winterfell", to me although the writing and pacing could have been much better there was a lot to recommend it. Despite being dismissed as another filler episode by some, "A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms" was a big improvement.It was the pace that was "A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms" weakest element. It has been said by people criticising the pacing that the writers were running out of material, although it is an improvement over "Winterfell" in this regard momentum is not always there and felt over-stretched in parts.Yet "A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms" did a great job putting what was introduced in the previous episode into place and setting up what is to come in calm before the storm fashion. It may lack forward momentum narratively but personally do not consider it a "filler" episode. It does equally well at distinguishing the battle's two sides, bringing all the major characters together in one setting (Winterfell in this case), character advancing, subtly tense reconciliations, tying up loose ends and providing emotional intimate moments.Visually, it looks amazing, as one would expect for 'Game of Thrones'. The scenery is throughout spectacular, the sets are hugely atmospheric and beautiful on the eyes with a real meticulous eye for detail and the costumes suit the characters to a tee. The make-up is beautifully done. As well the cinematography and editing, which are cinematic quality as well, while the special effects, while not the very best of the show, put many recent shows and films to shame. One cannot not mention the thematically, orchestrally and atmospherically multi-layered music scoring and the unforgettable main theme. Again, worthy of a high-budget fantasy/action/drama film.Writing is a big improvement here over "Winterfell". It flows much better and is far less chilidish and has more nuance. The pace is not perfect, but the story is intriguing enough and there are some lovely character moments. The standout is Brienne's knighting, which was for me the most emotional 'Game of Thrones' moment in a long time. Like "Winterfell", there is a quieter and more reflective tone and although some may not think so perhaps to me 'Game of Thrones' has excelled equally well in the quieter episodes as it did in the more action-heavy and weightier kind of story-lines. As well as being a set-up putting things into place episode, "A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms" is also character driven, and it's this that's one of the episode's strongest assets. Some lovely character development, especially Jaime and Brienne and the tension between Sansa and Daenerys intrigues highly, the reconciliations are nostalgic and the interactions intense and emotional. All the acting is strong.Altogether, not a perfect episode but a big improvement over last week, made me eagerly anticipating the next one and for me it's one of the better episodes since the show became uneven. 9/10

reviews.content: Jaime Lannister's arrival at Winterfell is not welcomed by all; Daenerys has vowed to kill him because he famously killed her father but after an intervention from Brienne of Tarth Sansa agrees that he should be allowed to fight alongside them. It soon becomes apparent that the Army of the Dead is approaching and will arrive sometime before the next dawn. As that time approaches the characters prepare, knowing that for some, possibly all of them it will be their last night alive.This episode may feature none of the violent action associated with the series but instead we are treated to a great character driven episode. Time is given to each of the characters assembled at Winterfell as they ready themselves for battle. They discuss their prospects and some wonder what will happen next should they survive. This leads to some genuinely touching scenes; most notably the scene which culminates in the knighting of Brienne. The cast are all on great form; it is impossible to single out any of them for specific mention without listing all the main cast, and some of the secondary cast. As I write this I've not seen the next episode so have no idea who will survive but this episode left be wishing they all could even though it wouldn't be 'Game of Thrones' if they did! Overall a really fine character led episode.

reviews.content: It's come to the point of this show where I can watch reunions and first meetings for hours and never get tired of it. I get it, the show has done 2 straight weeks of "set up", but it seems completely fitting to me. Even after all of the long-awaited reunions we got last week, we still needed some time to breathe with these characters for another week in Winterfell.First thing of note is that this episode was set entirely in Winterfell, no Iron Islands with Yara or King's Landing with Euron/Cersei. And to be honest, do we expect either setting to fit in next week either? If it's supposed to be an episode entirely on the battlefield, than there's no reason to show any other setting. It's safe to say they were not missed tonight.As expected, the episode began with Jaime in front of all the Lords, Kings, and Queens left in Winterfell as he "atoned" for his past sins. It wasn't all that shocking or surprising, we knew the people who would stand up for him (Tyrion & Brienne), the people who would not (Sansa & Daenerys) and the one in between (Bran), but it was nonetheless thrilling to watch. There were two lines that specifically stood out to me. The first being Brienne saying Jaime is a "Man with honor", which is a touching callback to the episode in season 2 titled "A Man Without Honor" in which she refers to Jaime as such. The second being Bran ending the conversation with "The things we do for love", talk about callbacks. I truly can't get enough of this.Jaime and Brienne had quite a week together (which really worries me for both of their fates in the coming weeks), with Jaime asking Brienne to serve under her in the battlefield, and then him knighting her later in the episode in what was one of the most touching scenes this show has ever given us. How nice was it to see Brienne smile a bit in that sequence? Of all the titles people receive in this show, making Brienne a knight is at the top of the list.Another quick but touching scene was seeing Theon return to Winterfell and pledge his sword to Sansa once more. I nearly teared up, not going to lie. I truly believe Alfie Allen is one of the best actors on this show, always showing so much emotion with little dialogue over the years. It didn't take much for his and Sophie Turner's reaction to him arriving to move me significantly in this moment. Of course, this comes directly after the "make-up" scene between Sansa and Dany, which was surely welcomed. But it wouldn't be Game of Thrones without those finally few seconds of Sansa asking about what will happen to the North once it's all over. How many times are people going to bring up "afterwards" without realizing that this show never gives us good happy endings/happy "afterwards"!I loved seeing everyone surround the table and plan for the battle, and I also loved that it wasn't just Jon providing insight. It's an Avengers style lineup in this scene, and it was nice seeing everyone from Jaime, Sansa, Tormund, and Bran step up here. Which brings up the next point that we got an answer of sorts as to what the Night King wants, which is Bran. Is Bran's purpose only so that people knew of Jon's true lineage? Does he meet his end at the hands of the Night King in the next episode, thus eliminating the "world's memory"? Is that why Jon told Dany in this episode (because he needed to do it while Bran was still alive)? So by wanting an "endless night" does he need to kill absolutely everyone? Or is he satisfied once he kills Bran? I'm sure that's not the case, but still, so many questions left to answer. Some other notes worth mentioning:-GHOST -the baby is real?? -Tormund is the MVP -Shocked Jon told Dany already -Pod is a singer -Arya got her weapon....in more than one way tonight... -"And now our watch Begins" -Davos & the people -Theon will definitely die next week10/10

reviews.content: With better pacing and more emphasis on momentum, A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms is an improvement over the first episode, which was decent but not without it's problems.After Jon Snow learns of the connection between the Stark family and Daenerys' family, Winterfell recruits Jaime on the battle against the White Walkers while the Hound, Sandor Clegane, reunites with Arya.This episode is the best of the entire final season with better pacing, better writing, and like I said, more emphasis on momentum. reviews.content: There have been so many great episodes in this series, but for me this was the most enjoyable one. It's a wonderful episode largely for the character moments and there are many. The episode was written by Bryan Cogman a series veteran who's been on GOT since season one, and directed by David Nutter the most prolific director on the series who won an Emmy for the episode Mother's Mercy.We start off with Jaime's trial before the leaders of the combined forces at Winterfell. I thought it was a great performance by Nikolaj Coster-Waldau and the rest of the cast, great interplay with Tyrion, Sansa, Daenerys and Brienne before Jon has the final word. This is followed up by the first face to face meeting between Jaime and Bran since the infamous ending of the first episode of the series.Next we have an intriguing conversation between Sansa and Daenerys which goes quite well until the discussion turns to the future after the upcoming battle. It is also interrupted by return of Theon to Winterfell and his offer to Sansa to fight for them. Good moments and strong performances again by all three.The war council scene is important for Bran's revelation that the Night King will be coming after him and because of the mark placed upon he will be easy to find, so he will wait in the God's Wood. This scene did not stand out particularly for me, but is important for the story as it has Theon and the Iron Born vow to defend Bran, while Jon and Daenerys plan to spring a trap.This is followed by a very enjoyable encounter between Arya and the Hound in which she confronts him about his motives, this harkens back to their time together in Seasons 3 & 4 and how much Clegane has changed. This follows the infamous encounter between Arya and Gendry that made complete sense on the eve of battle and allows a very human interaction for a character that has become an instrument of death despite her young age. Good performances again from all three.And then we have the standout scene of the episode with Jaime, Brienne, Tyrion, Podrick, Davos and Tormund together on the eve of battle at the hearth in Winterfell. There are some wonderful character moments, including Tormund and Brienne's awkwardness, some great discussions and an emotional song from Podrick. But the standout moment of the scene and the episode is Jaime knighting Brienne despite the convention that a woman cannot be knighted.The final major scene has Daenerys confronting Jon (who has been distancing himself from her since the revelation in the previous episode) in the crypts in front of the statue of his mother Lyanna Stark, and Jon's revelation of his true parentage which Daenerys recognizes as superseding her claim to the Iron Throne. Another great reaction scene for Emilia Clarke.There are also a number of powerful minor scenes. With the return of Tormund, Beric and Edd we get a brief reunion between Jon, Samwell and Edd reminiscing about their time together with the Night Watch and those they have lost. Another nice scene has Lady Lyanna Mormont informing he cousin Jorah that she will not be retreating to the crypts as she is the leader of her house. Finally we have Samwell presenting his family's Valyrian sword to Jorah because of the influence Jorah's father had upon Sam and because Jorah would be much better suited to the sword which Samwell couldn't wield. himself.
reviews.author: ur3032357

reviews.content: Have always absolutely loved 'Game of Thrones'. When it was at its best, it kept me glued, although it was a gradual binge watch with so much going on, and was seriously addictive. The best episodes were as brilliant as television can get. It did justice to the equally brilliant source material, wholly deserving to be adapted, and mostly stays true to it despite the odd controversial moment/scene.This mainly applies to Seasons 1-5, while Season 7 was uneven with only two great episodes ("The Spoils of War" being the best) while boasting two of 'Game of Thrones' worst episodes. So far Season 8 has a fair share of truly impressive elements, but have yet to be properly blown away as an overall whole. It has so far been a divisive season understandably with strong opinions on both sides for all three episodes, fit in neither love or hate category just to say as indicated already. Am aware that many fans were disappointed by the eighth season premiere "Winterfell", to me although the writing and pacing could have been much better there was a lot to recommend it. Despite being dismissed as another filler episode by some, "A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms" was a big improvement and the best of the three episodes. A distinction that the highly anticipated "The Long Night" should have been and this was the episode that should have blown me away. Yet, although there are things done exceptionally it didn't.Beginning with the faults, ones that are shared with pretty much all of those who didn't care or outright hated the episode, the biggest one is the lighting. Even when advised to alter the settings on my television to maximum effect, much of the episode, especially in the action, was far too dark which did induce some squinting and confusion. The conclusion of the White Walkers is too premature and the Night King (looks great and sinister enough in his too limited screen time, but there was a big missed opportunity in making him more interesting) exit also underwhelms massively, much too rushed, introduced too abruptly, very anti-climactic, almost incomplete and done in a way that's too convenient.After improving quite a lot in "A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms", the writing takes a nose-dive. Not the dialogue, which is far less childish than in "Winterfell", provoked thought and was sincere, but more in how the characters behave and what they are given to do. Too many either being underused or being seemingly invincible in an implausible way. Bran is completely useless, if you are going to have a character at least give him something to do and have a story-line that is interesting, neither the case here. Again, there is a sense of running out of material.However, all those faults aside, "The Long Night" does have exceptional qualities. Visually, it looks amazing, as one would expect for 'Game of Thrones'. The scenery is throughout spectacular, the sets are hugely atmospheric and beautiful on the eyes with a real meticulous eye for detail and the costumes suit the characters to a tee. The make-up is beautifully done. As well the cinematography and editing, which are cinematic quality as well, while the special effects, while not the very best of the show, put many recent shows and films to shame. The dragons are extremely well rendered here. One cannot not mention the thematically, orchestrally and atmospherically multi-layered music scoring and the unforgettable main theme. Again, worthy of a high-budget fantasy/action/drama film.Regarding the action, despite the lighting it is thrilling and does shock and wrench the gut. The quieter moments of the episode don't drag and handled sincerely and with a lot of thought. The episodes handles both well, great to have both action-packed and quiet rather than one or the other. On an emotional level, there is a lot to digest and will admit that tears did well up in my eyes. The characterisation is interesting, one can really see the effort in the direction and the acting is dead on from all.On the whole, "The Long Night" did not blow me away but can totally see the monumental effort that was put into it and it is not an episode that will be forgotten by me. 7/10
reviews.author: ur20552756

reviews.content: While I agree with pretty much all of the criticisms I've read about THE LONG NIGHT, for me these don't detract from what is one of the most epic-feeling GAME OF THRONES episodes of all time. It's magnificent stuff, superbly shot and with excellent visuals throughout, visuals that stun particularly when watched on Blu-ray as compared to the spotty streaming version I originally watched back in 2019. The siege warfare is handled adroitly and the character beats are just fine, but it's the special effects which really make this zing. Sure, there aren't enough character deaths here - main contenders like Tyrion, Arya, Sam and Brienne should have all been for the chop at least - and it's all tied up a little too neatly at the climax, but generally this works a treat as a truly cinematic viewing experience.

reviews.content: The time has come; the Army of the Dead has arrived at Winterfell and the living are prepared for their most important and toughest fight to date. Once the action starts it is almost none-stop as the battle rages around, and later within, Winterfell.I found this to be one of the best episodes of the series so far; the action is spectacular and I genuinely had no idea who would survive... I had a good idea but still feared for all the key characters as they face potentially overwhelming odds. One might argue that too often key characters survived when they should die but that didn't bother me too much. The way the action moves from location to location within the battle meant things never got monotonous as well as keeping us up to date with all key characters. It was great seeing Arya Stark battling as hard as anybody and Theon Greyjoy fighting to try to protect Bran from the Army of the Dead and even the Night King himself... not to mention how a dead-giant was dispatched! The battle scenes, particularly those early in the episode were a little on the dark side but that just added to the confusion and chaos one would get in a pitched battle at night. Overall I'd say this was a great episode... just try to watch it in a very dark room so it is easier to see what is going on!

reviews.content: For all of the predictions I made about The Battle of Winterfell, the only one I was absolutely spot on about was that the episode would be titled 'The Long Night'. This show from the very beginning (and the books too for that matter) has always been about subverting expectations, so I really do appreciate the showrunners sticking to that notion for what may be their biggest episode of all time. I knew before the season based on the directors announced that episode 3 and 5 would be battle weeks (Miguel Sapochnik is directing after all), but I figured in some way shape or form, The Night King was going to be involved in both battles. I mean the show wouldn't miss out on the opportunity to bring 'Winter' to King's Landing right?Rian Johnson's tweet last night summed up fandom pretty nicely as he said "god***it I had this whole amazing Night King theory", which is essentially a nod to Star Wars fandom overreacting to Snoke's death in Episode 8. Alas, they actually did it, they won The Battle of Winterfell and killed The Night King, in all its shocking glory. After seeing Hardhome so many times, I thought there was no way it would be anyone else but Jon to kill him, but the Arya twist was welcomed to me. Especially since they've pretty much been setting it up for awhile now. Arya sneaking up on Jon and getting the dagger she used (Catspaw) right in front of the tree, as well as her conversation with Melisandre all the way back in season 3, all leading to the moment where she did that bada** knife move.The battle itself was nothing short of remarkable. Much like in The Battle of the Bastards, Sapochnik wants you to feel like you're in the heart of the battlefield. Whether it's seeing The Unsullied getting smothered by waves of walkers, the winter storm that blinds the dragon's sight, the oner's on the ground following several characters, or even Arya's haunted house moment, this was excellently shot. And yes, I'm acknowledging that those first 20 minutes were on the harder side to actually see what was going on. But that was entirely on purpose.The fallen included Beric, Ed, Melisandre, Lyanna, Jorah, and Theon. All important characters in their own right, but the big ones were really Jorah and Theon. Both going out protecting the people they love and in beautifully tragic fashion. My heart breaks for Jorah who will never get to see Dany on the throne and Theon who finally got the acknowledgement of Bran that he was a good man. Yes, I certainly expected there to be even more deaths, but if you have too many, then it loses its impact.There's so much more I could dig into, like the Sansa & Tyrion stuff, Jon charging The Night King, Grey Worm's survival, and all that Dragon on Dragon fight, but my overall thoughts were that I really enjoyed how this episode was handled. I legitimately can't remember the last episode of television that had me jumping up and down and yelling at the screen. But that's Thrones for ya.10/10

reviews.content: I survived the Lord of the rings: the two Towers 40 minute Helm's Deep battle scene.I survived this. This episode is much longer.I love that this episode doesn't get right into the battle, there is a buildup. Armies are put into position, It's more like a game of chess. What is the night king going to do? How is he going to attack?The Dothraki Are like pawns on this board, placed out in front. It does not seem like it went well for them. Ironically it was "the red woman" that gave the Dothraki some protection, and protection for Winterfell. When I first saw her character in the first episode of season two, I despised her. But she evolved into into the great tragic figure of the show. She realizes the harm and damage she has done, and this is the best she can do to make amends. It is not a lot but it is enough.But the irony here is when I realized that Daenerys had named her dragons for three influential men: Kahl Diogo, and her brothers Viserys and Rhaegar.Guess which dragons Jon Snow and the Night King are riding?So it turns out that the namesake of Viserys returns from his golden crowning to wreak revenge on his sister.While Jon rides the dragon named after his own father...I haven't seen this episode since it aired. I loved it then, I still love it. But it was upon watching it for the first time in a long time last night I realized the relationship between the names of the dragons and their respective riders. I thought that was a nice touch, very appropriate.The music is probably the best music ever written for the series, especially at the very end where it starts with a few piano notes and builds into a beautiful fugue.It is difficult to watch this episode during the daytime, you can't have one speck of light in the room otherwise it spoils the effect.Nevertheless, it's probably the most powerful episode of the entire series. And I respect the work that went into making it happen, which was on par with filming the Helms Deep battle in lord of the rings.

reviews.author: ur18723110

reviews.content: Like many fans I hugely anticipated this episode. I also wanted more than anything for it to hit it out of the park. It sadly didn't. This was still a good episode but not epic and certainly not full of twists that has made GoT what it is. I found it difficult to keep track of what was going on, it seemed the White Walkers were moving just too fast to observe anything. When Ser Davos waved his torches in the air for Jon and Danny and yelled they can't see us I yelled to the screen 'Neither can we'. Despite claims of realism it fails to recognize a basic rule that the audience must be able to see the whole thing. There were some mesmerizing scenes and good moments but this episode left too many questions. How did Arya get past the generals, why was the Night King so drawn to Bran?The end to one of the greatest and mysterious villains was also a huge anticlimax. To be taken down in one episode after 8 seasons of build up and in a somewhat dull fashion. Also most of our main characters were too protected as usual. GoT is a show where when you make mistakes you die. Sam, Jaimie, and Ser Brienne all were safe despite Wights surrounding them. People have said that not everyone would be pleased with the battle. But the difference with GoT is we have seen them execute epic battles such as Hardhome and the Battle of the Bastards. It can be done. A different style and artistic choices were made that led to a lackluster episode. I am really hoping they nail the final 3 episodes.

reviews.author: ur80693802

reviews.content: I have not commented on this show since I stopped enjoying it a few years ago, although I love the source material and the first three seasons. I'll break my silence now because this episode represents everything Game of Thrones has become since season 5: magnificent visuals and production values, splendid soundtrack, excellent performances (even Harington and Clarke, who were a bit shaky in the first couple of seasons, have grown solid), some effective moments (Theon's last stand, for example, is legitimately moving)... and disappointing writing.Martin's books are not Crime and Punishment but at least he can write coherent characters and themes; the show, on the other hand, ignores themes (it got Martin's romanticism exactly wrong, turning it into garden-variety nihilism), keeps pushing the reset button on character arcs (see Jaime after season 3) and gleefully ignores any logic that gets in the way of the desired outcome (the absurd Sansa-Bolton marriage, Dany's hilariously suicidal campaign against Cersei, the grotesque "wight hunt"...).With this episode, the whole point of the series - selfish people waste time and lives in petty dynastic wars while the apocalypse is coming - falls apart. Cersei becomes the ultimate villain to defeat; the Night King (a bad guy manufactured by the show to be the "face" of the White Walkers) goes down like a wimp halfway through the last season.And is killed by Arya. Don't get me wrong, I love Arya. Well, LOVED her in the first seasons, as she has become increasingly smug in the last years.But why Arya? She has no connection to the Night King and the White Walkers plot. The three meaningful choices were Jon (involved in the Wall storyline since season one), Bran (whose subplot has the stronger ties to the supernatural) or Dany (as a foil to the Night King, the "fire" to his "ice", the good dragon rider versus the evil one, the messianic figure versus the diabolic one). All the build-up about prophecies becomes pointless gibberish now.Arya killing the Night King is like Han Solo killing the Emperor; like Legolas riding to Mount Doom and destroying the One Ring; like Ron Weasley defeating Voldemort; like Hicks confronting the Alien Queen. It's pleasing in a "Yay, a character we like kills the bad guy!" way, but it doesn't go beyond that. It's shallow, empty, meaningless. There needs to be a deeper connection between the villain and the hero who defeats him.Well, Arya was chosen for two reasons. One, because of fanservice, as she is loved by both fans and writers. Two, to subvert expectations.Let me get this straight about "subverting expectations" (see also The Last Jedi). Any hack can "subvert expectations". Just throw in stuff that comes out of nowhere (Varys kills the Night King! Euron joins the good guys!). What's difficult is doing it in a MEANINGFUL way which, in retrospect, makes sense in terms of plots, characterization, themes.The Red Wedding was a brilliant subversion of expectations: everyone was expecting Robb to avenge Ned but he was betrayed and killed. Still, looking back at his storyline, all the signs were there; it was the tragic but somewhat logic outcome of his mistakes and misfortunes."Subverting expectations" just because you can is typical of schlock. If the books will ever come out, I am certain that, for better or for worse, the Others / White Walkers plotline will have a completely different outcome (and Cersei will be toast well before the Long Night).Now I wonder how the good guys will dispose of Cersei. *She* would have been the perfect target for Arya: a political villain defeated by an assassin, just like a supernatural villain should be defeated by a magical character (*cough* Bran *cough*).Maybe now they'll go full circle and have Jon or Bran kill Cersei. You know, to subvert expectations.
reviews.author: ur15445210

reviews.content: Have always absolutely loved 'Game of Thrones'. When it was at its best, it kept me glued, although it was a gradual binge watch with so much going on, and was seriously addictive. The best episodes were as brilliant as television can get. It did justice to the equally brilliant source material, wholly deserving to be adapted, and mostly stays true to it despite the odd controversial moment/scene.This mainly applies to Seasons 1-5, while Season 7 was uneven with only two great episodes ("The Spoils of War" being the best) while boasting two of 'Game of Thrones' worst episodes. So far Season 8 has had a fair share of truly impressive elements, but have not been blown away as an overall whole and by 'Game of Thrones' stands it has been a disappointment. Only "The Knight of the Seven Kingdoms" reached great standards, "Winterfell" was uneven but still good and "The Long Night" understandably was heavily controversial on both sides (had big problems with it while recognising its big efforts and it is not an episode to forget in a hurry). It has so far been a divisive season understandably with strong opinions on both sides for all the episodes, especially "The Long Night" when and after it aired. Fit in neither love or hate category just to say as indicated already.Watching "The Last of the Starks", the last two episodes of the show will really need to step up their game big time because although it did have a fair share of good points this is one of the few 'Game of Thrones' episodes where from my perspective the hate has been completely understandable. Am someone who did genuinely watch it on NowTV with my sisters, also fans, the night after it aired, rather than being one of those who rated it low or rated it high to counter the low ratings before the episode aired, which is immature behaviour and over the top again from personal opinion. Needed time to gather my thoughts and make every effort to be fair. As of now, "The Last of the Starks" is the lowest rated episode here and also the most hated episode, "The Long Night" also got a huge amount of hate but it was more controversial than near-completely panned. As for me, did not think the episode was that bad, there are good points that are enough to give it at least a 3 and am not sure as to whether it is the very worst episode. But there are a lot of flaws here and sadly they are not small, it is definitely one of my least favourite 'Game of Thrones' episodes (bottom 5) and have seldom been this disappointed/conflicted in an episode of a show that at its best is one of the best there is in a long time.Good things are here in "The Last of the Starks". Visually, it looks amazing, as one would expect for 'Game of Thrones'. The scenery is throughout spectacular, the sets are hugely atmospheric and beautiful on the eyes with a real meticulous eye for detail and the costumes suit the characters to a tee. The make-up is beautifully done. As well the cinematography and editing, which are cinematic quality as well, while the special effects, while not the very best of the show, put many recent shows and films to shame. The dragons are extremely well rendered here. One cannot not mention the thematically, orchestrally and atmospherically multi-layered music scoring and the unforgettable main theme. Again, worthy of a high-budget fantasy/action/drama film. The opening credits are beautifully designed.A few good scenes, though too far and between. The opening scene was very emotional to me and beautifully staged and shot, to me Emilia Clarke was very moving and expressive in this scene. The ending had a tense build up and shocked me to the core and brought tears to my eyes. Some occasional nice banter, political intrigue and character interaction reasonably early on that felt like 'Game of Thrones'. The acting as always is strong, it is very hard to be disappointed in Peter Dinklage for example and Lena Headey makes much of her short screen time. There is the right amount of broodiness and expressiveness from all, Clarke giving her best performance of the season so far.However, there is also a lot wrong in "The Last of the Starks". For one, the pacing was very spotty here. There are too many dead spots that drag early on, while towards and at the end the episode felt rushed and like it was trying to pack a lot in with little time to breathe. The script was also messy, there are intriguing moments (Jon Snow's speech being the best written scene by default) but some of the writing really made me cringe at its cheesiness and near-immaturity and turn round to my sisters in disbelief, like for example the writing for Brienne in one of the episode's most awkward scenes that was an insult really to 'Game of Thrones'. The story lacked tension and suffered primarily from feeling like two or three episodes packed into one, while there was a lot of draggy pacing the episode felt bloated and like the writers had run out of material too.In terms of character and story progression, that was a very mixed bag. There is signs of story progression, but that came too late into the episode and should have been more interesting. Character progression though was not there, if anything rather than advancing it went backwards and saw characters behaving out of character and behaving nonsensical decisions. Also found Jon Snow incredibly dull, other than his speech. Many others have mentioned the dragon ambush, completely share their opinions of it being intelligence-insultingly ridiculous and it not making sense in any shape or form, also found it rushed as well. Other than the heavily problematic pacing, writing and storytelling, another huge problem is the emotional emptiness. A vast majority of 'Game of Thrones' episodes had tension, poignancy, thrills, fun and thought-probing. Other than two scenes, got very little of any of those here.Summarising, a disappointment in too many respects while having its moments. It underwhelms as an episode for anything but by 'Game of Thrones' standards, which is usually very good to exceptionally high, this doesn't cut it. A perhaps generous 5/10

reviews.content: Some big problems here in an overlong episode, but I still found myself enjoying things regardless. Sure, the death of her second dragon is handled in a ridiculous way, and there's THAT sub-plot between Jaime and Brienne which never should have been explored. Plus there's Bronn speed-talking his way through a rushed scene which comes across as nonsensical. Apart from these moments, the rest is focused, momentous, and an able set-up for the next instalment.

reviews.author: ur62702709

reviews.content: The Army of the Dead has been defeated and it is a time of celebration and remembrance in Winterfell; it is also a time of trepidation as the survivors of the battle know it is only a matter of time before they must head south and face Cersei's forces at King's Landing. Jon's popularity is bothering Daenerys, especially now she knows that he has a valid claim to the Iron Throne... even if he assures her that he has no desire to be king. With the funerals and then the celebrations over protagonists discuss what to do next; many advise caution but Daenerys is determined that they will head south as soon as possible. En route to King's Landing her forces are ambushed and suffer a defeat to Euron Greyjoy's fleet during which one of the people closest to Daenerys is captured. Ultimately her forces arrive at King's Landing... Tyrion wants to find a peaceful solution but will Daenerys or Cersei want to listen?Perhaps, having heard others' comments, it is because I was prepared for a really bad episode I ended up being pleasantly surprised. It started well with a funeral for those who died in the battle followed by the celebrations. These proved to be entertaining, with much drinking and joviality tempered by Daenerys's obvious annoyance that everybody seems to be praised except for her. Tensions then rise nicely; particularly between Sansa and Daenerys. When the move south begins the ambush comes as a real surprise and will clearly have major repercussions in the series final two episodes. There are some weak points; people seem to travel across Westeros much more quickly; journeys that took half a series in earlier times now take less than half an episode with no real indication of time passing and I've lost count of how many times Tyrion has been nearly killed in battle only to survive! The battle scene may have been short but it was certainly exciting and set things up for the episodes shocking ending. Overall I certainly enjoyed this more than most... maybe because I went in expecting worse; maybe I'm easily pleased or maybe it is actually a decent episode.

reviews.author: ur35635716

reviews.content: Wow. For all the people last week complaining about The Great War being over and that Game of Thrones was making the wrong decision about the real big bad of the show, this episode did a whole lot to swing the tide. Much like last week, my legs were shaking with angst and stomach constantly turning, waiting for the inevitable to happen. Waiting for characters I love to die. RIP Missandei and Rhaegal. Dany's team gets smaller and smaller as the weeks pass.Dave and Dan (showrunners) are right, Dany is now at a similar point in her life to how she was at the start of the show, alone. And as Maester Aemon once said "A Targaryen alone in the world is a terrible thing". That makes me really worried for her, although technically Jon is one too, but we all know where that situation stands.I really loved the first 20 minutes or so, mourning the dead but also celebrating the fact that they actually won the great war. Tormund was his usual self, Gendry was proclaimed Lord of Storm's End, and even Tyrion got Jaime, Pod, and Brienne to play his drinking game. But the real thing of note here is how Dany feels during all of this. Everyone is getting praise and celebrating with their friends and loved ones while Dany sits alone and watches as her claim gets diminished in the process. I know we've all been hard on her the past few seasons, but I really felt bad for her tonight. Think about all she's gone through and lost, just within the last few episodes. She's the definition of a loner.After Jon went against Daenerys' desire and told his family about his true heritage (which admittedly I really wanted to see on screen), the truth inevitably found its way to Tyrion and Varys. The latter of which I could of sworn was going to die this week. The truth about Jon gave those two a few scenes in which we're meant to believe they will eventually betray Dany to support Jon's claim, which of course means nothing because he simply doesn't want it. Even in this episode I keep flipping back and forth as to who I believe will die between Dany & Jon, or even both at this point.I should probably mention just how nice it was to finally see Brienne and Jaime acknowledge their love for one another, even if the former surely loves him way more than he cares for her, which makes it even more devastating when Jaime decides to leave her at Winterfell and head south. I tend to believe he's going back to try and stop Cersei and fingers crossed kill her, but the scene could be interpreted multiple ways.A few other goodbyes seem to indicate that Jon will never return North, he says goodbye to Sam, Tormund and even Ghost. That broke my heart, but at least Ghost is still breathing, I was a little worried after last week.The only problem I had with the episode was that it didn't handle Danerys' arrival to King's landing all that well. So we're just going to ride the Dragons right up to the coast and risk getting them taken out, which Rhaegal did? Logistically it didn't seem to make much sense, though i guess at her emotional level, she may make some irrational decisions, much like Jon does when his emotions get the better of him. It was also a weird choice for her to walk that close to the walls of King's Landing with her *very small* Unsullied army and expect anything good to happen. But that final sequence was marvelous nevertheless.A few other tidbits worth mentioning:-The Hound and Arya back together again-That Bronn scene actually had me very nervous-Jon saying the dead heroes were the shield that guarded the realms of men was a nice addition-Gilly and Sam naming their kid Jon was heartwarming10/10

reviews.author: ur75193729

reviews.content: After the Battle of Winterfell, Daenerys and the others have to make a plan to fight against Euron Greyjoy and Queen Cersei once and for all.The 1st half of Season 8, while not without it's problems, was at least very good, but The Last of the Starks is where the final season declined in quality. It's not particularly awful or anything, but it could've been so much better.The writing is bland and lacks the spark of the previous episodes (I know many people hated Season 5 and 7 but at least they had more momentum), the characters that used to be interesting and complex have now been reduced to one-dimensional, the pacing drags on for way too long, and the overall dialogue isn't quite as strong.However, there are still some good things in the episode. The cinematography and costumes continue to be well made and impressive, there are one or two moments that were heartfelt (which I won't spoil to those who haven't seen the episode), the music score from Ramin Djawadi is still beautiful and compliments the atmosphere, and the acting, despite the bland writing and dialogue, is still good at least with Peter Dinklage, Kit Harrington, and Emilia Clarke doing their best.Overall, The Last of the Starks had potential but exactly ended up bland to me. Thumbs down :(

reviews.author: ur118977607

reviews.content: When 'Game of Thrones' was at its best, it made for utterly riveting television and was the best television could possibly get. Very easy to get into, even though it did take me a while to get through the episodes with a lot going on and the watch and review list increasing all the time and now gradually decreasing, and one of the most addictive shows ever from personal opinion. This is especially true for the best of Seasons 1-5 and there were shining moments too in Season 6. Season 7 was uneven, with only two great episodes to me.Am going to agree with those that have said that Season 8 has been disappointing. It started off quite well, though "A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms" was the only one to reach great standard while not being top-tier 'Game of Thrones'. "The Long Night" was by 'Game of Thrones' standards disappointing and the controversy is understandable, but still really appreciated the huge effort that was put into it and it is not an episode to forget. What was a major disappointment was "The Last of the Starks", which has been panned by a lot of fans and it is not hard at all to see why. Did say in my review for that episode that the last two episodes would need to step up big time. Something that "The Bells" did not do, didn't think it was that bad to warrant a lot of one star votes, some before the episode was aired, but it in my mind is not deserving of the 10/10s which seem to have been awarded for knee jerk reactions rather than merit. Also, can those who have given the episode 7 and above please actually write proper reviews for the episode and not be so immature and insulting to those who didn't like the episode in comments that read more like rants."The Bells" flaws do outweigh the cons by quite some way, like "The Last of the Starks" this is one of the two of the worst 'Game of Thrones' episodes (except this is worse, as that episode had a little more emotion and didn't have as many character inconsistencies) and doesn't do the show justice in any way. One of those examples of an episode that has completely lost what made its respective show so great in the first place, and that is just shameful. It is also like that episode one of the few where the hate is completely understandable and for valid from personal perspective reasons. And this is coming from someone who genuinely did see it earlier this week, and my siblings who are also 'Game of Thrones' fans expressed even more intense dislike than me. After this and the previous episode, hopes for the final episode are not high and am not sure as to how the show is going to pull off a final episode when "The Bells" itself felt like a show finale in its second half that was heavily problematic and the actual final episode may feel one episode too long. It would have actually been better that the first portion of the episode at Dragonstone was an episode of build up, namely for Daenerys, and all the events at Kings Landing being the final episode, and that would have solved the two or more episodes in one feel that the episode had.Lets start with what "The Bells" did well, as there are good things here that are enough for the episode to warrant a 2 at least. Visually, it looks amazing, as one would expect for 'Game of Thrones'. One of the best looking episodes of the entire show actually, with some truly mind-blowing and cinematic-esque photography that was so immersive throughout. The scenery is throughout spectacular, the sets are hugely atmospheric and beautiful on the eyes with a real meticulous eye for detail and the costumes suit the characters to a tee. The make-up is beautifully done, while the special effects, while not the very best of the show, put many recent shows and films to shame. The dragon is extremely well rendered here.One cannot not mention the thematically, orchestrally and atmospherically multi-layered music scoring and the unforgettable main theme. Again, worthy of a high-budget fantasy/action/drama film. The opening credits are beautifully designed. There are great moments here, the best being with Jaime and Tyrion, Sandor and Arya (both heartfelt) and a little tension in the Sandor/Gregor duel. The acting is very good considering the material, with Lena Headey, Nikolaj Coster-Waldau and Emilia Clarke coming off best. Peter Dinklage also does his best, despite his material being beneath him.Sadly, there is so much wrong with "The Bells". It has a lot of the same flaws "The Last of the Starks" had, except executing them worse, and also having more problems. Everything felt very rushed and like 2 episodes at least in one, with little breathing space and a lot of the latter half of the episode came over as very muddled in what was happening. There are not as many dead spots as the previous episode, but too much is packed in but at the same time one can really tell that the show had run out of ideas and material as moments do feel like padding. The script is also an absolute mess, there is no intrigue and much of it is childish and forced, the cringe factor was high here. "The Bells" should have been an episode with the most tension and emotion of the series, both came in spades but unfortunately was distracted by the insulting lack of logic, the complete lack of sense, nonsensical character motivations, pointless moments, deux ex machinas, coincidences and inconsistencies that are too numerous to list and have been summed up already by others.Found the ending to be too much of an anti-climax, leaving more questions than answers and doing an injustice to such great characters. Just to say, was not expecting a happy ending, that actually would have jarred and been too pat and many others would feel the same. This would have been the right way to end actually, but it was a case of the right ending being executed wrongly which is what people mean when criticising the ending. Saw no point in the overlong and truly ridiculous to the point of unintentional silliness scene between Jaime and Euron, and Euron here and in the previous episode was a waste of time as a character, one with no real threat and was rather cheesy instead, that could easily have been left out of the episode and nobody would miss him. The layered and complex characterisation and development is cast to the wind here, there is no character progression other than with the often spoken about Daenerys which was as others have said handled badly. If anything the character development has gone backwards in Season 8, not only are the characters cliched and pale shadows of their former selves behaving nonsensically or for little reason they are out of character and this was apparent from the very beginning of the episode. Too many have too little to do as well, Jon Snow is especially now a complex blank.Regarding Daenerys, there was foreshadowing definitely throughout the show of how she would become the way she was here, which those that disliked the episode have not disputed. As they have not disputed that it was brought on by grief and hatred. But still the build up to the descent in the episode felt very rushed and another episode would have helped make it more gradual, and her actual actions were extreme in my view. Can understand taking revenge on Cersei and those who supported her, but not when it came to taking it out on entirely innocent people. That was not the signs of a conflicted and complex character who had lost everything, and instead one turned with little build up into a one-dimensional villain introduced in a way that made no sense. That's what people are getting at when considering what was done to Daenerys in the writing as a character assassination, in an episode full of them.Altogether, hugely disappointing and instead of having high anticipations expectations for the final episode are now very low. 4/10
reviews.author: ur20552756

reviews.content: THE BELLS is, somewhat inevitably, the most controversial episode in GAME OF THRONES history, yet I for one absolutely loved it. Miguel Sapochnik's direction really blows this out of the water and the second half of the episode really lets loose in a fierce, explosive and completely destructive way that far surpasses even the likes of THE LONG NIGHT. I had no problem with the ways the characters acted at all, as it all makes perfect sense to me. There are crowd-pleasing moments like the long-awaited 'Cleganebowl', Arya suddenly snapping back and becoming the lovable character she was for the first six seasons, and an ending for Jaime and Cersei that I initially hated but have grown to love. The extensive and endless CGI effects are quite brilliant - and I say that as somebody who's no fan of computer graphics in general - and the sense of epic destruction quite breathtaking. A true climax for the show.
reviews.author: ur0482513

reviews.content: Since all most of the people can do is complain, I'm wondering if we saw the same episode. Dany goes berserk. She is so caught up in her power that she ignores the fact that these are living beings. She strafes the entire city, killing anyone in her way. I guess they killed one of her kids! This was a non-stop action piece. The problem was that so much went on, there was little cinematic focus. We had no sense of where people were and what they were involved in. There were some titanic battles (mostly for their own sake) but at times I wondered where is the rest of the regular cast. Anyway, I suppose the final episode will answer some questions. By the way, you naysayers have every right to give a "one" to these shows, but why don't you just watch something else?
reviews.author: ur0278527

reviews.content: For many reasons, this episode is a deep disappointment. The basic cause is the option for visual effect more then for a reasonable, logical, coherent story. The illustration of the word of Missandei and the return to the image of Mad King in another version is, maybe, not enough. Because it seems a terrible kick against a construction of 7 seasons. Not the happy end is expected but some logic and respect for characters, actors and public. Because this episode becomes a sort of Fahrenheit 451 or Nero Rome in flames. But, sure, it is the vision of hurry team The only sin - this season could be do not exist.
reviews.author: ur61197531

reviews.content: It is easy to criticize it. To be dissapointed . To see the fall of a so careful constructed serie. But, maybe, an another perspective, could be useful.Because it is an realistic episode. Sure, it is not the expected one because you hope discover the fairy tale. But the episode is about us, its viewers, more then about the characters of GoT. Is it the fury, angry, high desire of revenge of the Mother of Dragons far by ours ? Our frustrations, our desilusions, our hard work who could be transformed in tool by others is so rare ? So exotic or eccentric ?Sure, it is easy - the episode 5 is awfull. Cersei deserves a better death, Lord Varys deserves a noble end. But the "Dracarys *" of the end of episode 4 was an ilusion ? No ! It was the resume, the seed of this simple, dramatic, boring - maybe- , for a part of public. A blasphemy for others. But a decent job. Because it is not about a Mad Queen. It is just about us. We, the viewers who, in so many occasions are looking for the perfect dragon for the most powerful, convincing, out of mercy, revenge.Season 8 has many sins . But , maybe, this episode, ione. s its the best
reviews.author: ur61197531

reviews.content: The second to last episode of "Game of Thrones", "The Bells", is visually stunning, but absolutely disappointing. The destruction of King´s Landing is amazing and the best the episode can offer. However the expectation of the viewer is frustrated by the awful storyline. Along the years, Daenerys was built as a fair woman. Out of the blue, she goes completely crazy after defeating Cersei´s army that had surrendered in an absolute nonsense attitude. The fight of Jaime and Euron is boring and too long. The end of Cersei is also disappointing. My vote is six.Title (Brazil): "The Bells"
reviews.author: ur2488512

reviews.content: A lot of the behavior of the characters didn't make sense. Why would Cersei not bolt earlier? How did Arya survive everything? How did the superior army still lose the head to head battle?But you can't think too hard about this stuff. This was still a fun episode with a lot of big moments.
reviews.author: ur62702709

reviews.content: The armies are amassed; the battle for King's Landing is about to begin. However Daenerys has not got over the losses of Missandei and another of her dragons. She considers those who don't do what she says to be betraying her... that includes Jon for telling his sisters about his real parentage. There are two possibilities of averting a massacre; Jaime will persuade Cersei to flee the city and live in exile with him or Arya will get to her and kill her before the assault begins. Neither seem that likely and it is of no surprise that the battle is not averted. Soon the battle turns into a rout and then a brutal massacre.This was a genuinely shocking episode; there have been many times when bad people have done terrible things and times when good characters do bad things but here one who always claimed to be seeking justice committing an act that makes the hated Joffrey seem like a bleeding heart liberal! I can see how this would disappoint some viewers but for me it was 'Game of Thrones' at its most 'Game of Thrones'. It isn't just one character that does bad things; once the attack begins many of the 'liberating' forces run amok killing surrendering soldiers and civilians alike. While there is fire raining down on the city and pitched battles taking place there are also times for individual battles as Jamie faces Euron and Sandor Clagane and his long-hated brother. There were a few weak points; most notably how Arya nearly died so many times. As always the acting was great and the special effects top notch. Overall I really enjoyed the episode and can't wait to see how the series ends.
reviews.author: ur13977076

reviews.content: Another final battle. But will this one be the final final battle? Only time will tell
reviews.author: ur76062573

reviews.content: ... although I am relatively new to this TV show and have been binging back episodes to catch up. Yes, the writing and plot development seems rushed compared to previous seasons. I think I understand where you are coming from because I was a long time fan of Buffy The Vampire Slayer only to watch it go off a cliff in seasons six and seven. From great character development and dialogue that rolls trippingly off the tongue to flat dialogue, sudden developments that come out of nowhere and a final big bad that seemed neither. All because Joss Whedon wanted to go off and write a space western that was cancelled after 13 episodes. But I digress.Looking at previous episodes of GOT, I think I know where you are coming from. It is not that the dialogue is bad it is just not present like it was in past seasons. That being said "The Bells" was visually stunning if heart breaking. And stop looking for "the reason" for Dany burning King's Landing to the ground with her one remaining dragon - who apparently does not need time to refuel. Loss of advisors, betrayal by the ones who remain, personal losses, and the madness that was probably always genetically embedded in her have turned her into the "Mad Queen". Just how mad is symbolized by the occasional puffs of green fire that ignite through the city, the wildfire planted by her father "The Mad King", seemingly impotent next to the destruction of Drogon's breath.Then there was just one big "Huh??" moment for me. Arya, intent on getting revenge, accepting that she will not come back from that revenge for ages and will pay with her life, is given exactly two lines of admonition from the Hound to forget about revenge and live, and she just says "Okay!", oh, and "Thank you!".We did need her view of the carnage on the ground, but the set up for her change of heart just was not there. So it must be a disappointment to see your brilliant TV show become just above average, because I've been there before. But that doesn't mean I'm not watching the last episode.
reviews.author: ur15148330

reviews.content: The Bells is fairly ho-hum, slaughter without reason, little dialogue, though epic.Forces arrive at King's Landing for the final battle and Daenerys sets everything ablaze. Not much of a battle at all, Daenerys has had it with mercy. The betrayal and death of Varys is a bit of a time waster and not all that interesting. Unlike Arya to be dissuade merely by the words "do you want to end up like me?" Just to have a main character from within. I like the two titans fighting on the steps. The Mountain just won't die, so The Hound decides to rid the world of the both of them. Cersei's death wasn't really a worthy exit, she should of been eaten or killed by a random peasant. Will Arya let those innocent lives taken go unpunished... we will see.The Hound, Cersei, The Mountain and Tyrion the standouts.
reviews.author: ur25775215

reviews.content: Season 8, Episode 5. All this build up for 8 seasons to lead to this final battle - some of it is predictable, some of it shocking. I can tell you I want Daenerys dead. I've been sick of her for several seasons and now I hate her more than ever -- I want to watch her die. That's all I will say about this episode because I don't wanna give it away.7/10
reviews.author: ur35635716

reviews.content: Remember when The Red Wedding happened and how shocking that was but then you re-watch and realize it was all entirely inevitable and ultimately unavoidable? To me, the same can be said for Daenerys' ultimate turn into the 'Mad Queen'. It's always been in her. It was in her when her brother died, when she burned the Tarly's, or really every time she's ever said the word "Dracarys". Whether you like it or not, this was her endgame and it was always going to be that way. If only Rhaegar didn't love Lyanna right?This episode was beyond extraordinary, it was brutally devastating, shocking, tragic. All of the above, to be honest. I can't truly put into words how epic tonight was. Miguel Sapochnik did it again, in what may be the best episode he's ever done, possibly topping the Battle of the B*st*rds. The Battle of Winterfell/The Long Night was one thing, this was something else entirely. In a way, fulfilling Dany's dream sequence from season 2 at the House of the Undying, Dany will now walk into the Throne Room (not covered in snow, but rather, ash) after nearly the entire city of King's Landing gets burnt to the ground and thousands of civilians burnt to the crisp.Much like the best battles this show has ever done, it rarely goes the way you think. Wildfire, The Vale appearing, Dany saving them beyond the wall, or Arya's last second strike, I was on the edge of my seat the entire night, and that goes to show you just how impeccable this episode is directed. We got Cleganebowl and Jaime dying in the arms of Cersei, both things fans wanted to see, and this is all amidst the destruction of King's Landing with Arya's trek through the streets.In the words of the horrible Ramsay Bolton in season 3 "If you think this has a happy ending, you haven't been paying attention".So what is that ending now? We have one episode left and half the main cast is gone. Does it come down to Jon fulfilling the Prince Who Was Promised prophecy (in a roundabout way) and kill Dany, with a sword through her heart? Like I was saying a few weeks back, does the power leave King's Landing now that it's in ash and go to the North? Does Jon ultimately sit on whatever's left of 'The Throne'? I would bet money he leaves it all behind and goes North, but who knows. That's why we love this show.10/10

Isn't game of thrones supposed to be more difficulty and not that simple? It made one of the best TV series name not for the same story as all series. There's no authentic part in this episode. It's blank and basic.

reviews.content: Greetings from Lithuania."The Bells", 5th episode of currently the most hated season by its fan of "Game of Thrones" just might have been one of the best this show has ever pulled of. Many, many plots have came to an end here, and i loved every single one of them. And how surprisingly it turn out to be - for me personally, who does not theorize everything and just enjoys this show for what it is. Visuals of this episode were outstanding to say the least and direction was superb.Overall, i highly enjoyed "The Bells" - one of the very best episodes of this show. Amazingly staged, emotional and brutal - this is the highlight of this season. Can't wait for last episode.
reviews.author: ur4405474

reviews.content: Riveting pernicious mind boggling episode! Definitely was expecting much magnitude in a 2nd to last episode; as with the last few episodes, I don't understand the hate, then again I appreciate things more than most!
reviews.author: ur34836174

reviews.content: Game of Thrones (5 out of 5 stars). Episode 8.5This episode might as well be the ultimate climax to the series. With the final battle taking place at Kings Landing. Enough said about the plot without spoilers which they have done a great job in keeping this one a secret. I have loved how every character development and story has reached up to here. Characters are tested, reached their potential for making the better choices. When it comes to this final battle. The episode was intense and spectacular. The battle sequence was great. And it does not stop there. There are a couple of surprises and twists and turns which gets very dark. That will leave you feeling a little haunted from this episode. Sure, some complained about The Long Night battle for being too dark. Well this one takes place during the day. And it leaves you on the edge.Overall, this episode is one of the best in the season so far. And it is chaotic, crazy, insane, and it does get emotional with characters. The battle was intense and the fight sequences with characters are just fantastic. It ends with you feeling haunted and speechless and really excited to see how the last episode will end.

reviews.content: Written by David Benioff & D.B. Weiss, and directed by Miguel Sapochnik, it's one last, epic hurrah for Game of Thrones as pure spectacle, while still making way for some strong character work, even if there are still issues therein.

reviews.content: My Rating : 6/10I am a huge GoT fan but after watching this episode I can safely say that my fantastical-epic- GoT-finale-dreams are almost over - this was a badly-written episode. The execution was great but I'm a tad disappointed with everything since the last episode and now this.Hope for a decent finale. Please. I just want a 9/10 or 10/10 finale episode preferably, don't we all?
