reviews.content: Hopefully the last episode will tie all the loose ends that this season has unfurled this year in the biggest tv show in the world. Look for a cameo by Aaron Rodgers as one of the minor characters near the end.
reviews.author: ur18723110

reviews.content: Thank god this is almost over. Its like having the flu, and I am almost well. Everything, and I do mean everything, so, very, very predictable! Enough already! Later, folks.
reviews.author: ur55513445

reviews.content: Hard to use words to describe how much this show has changed. GOT became iconic because its complex characters drove the plot. You were shocked when you saw the red wedding or the origins of Hodor but you could trace it back to its origins. I'm not going to be extreme and have a huge go at this show because the truth is I'm saddened by its current path. Now we have characters being forced to fit within a plot, character development tossed aside as if it meant nothing.The story arc for Dany becoming the mad queen was not only forced it was illogical. Dany has been suffering her whole life and come out stronger, hard to believe a few recent bad turns would turn her mad. Lets also not forgot how the Night King and White Walker story line still remains the biggest missed opportunity. It was also anticlimatic to see Cersei die the way she did after all she's done. Shock value can only carry you so much. When season 8 started I said how are they going to wrap up this universe in 6 episodes. Now I'm thinking what's left?Drogon is a metaphor in a way. The city and buildings that he took down so fast without thinking can be how the show runners have mindlessly torn down years of character development, potential and fan goodwill.
reviews.author: ur51094543

reviews.content: Based on this episode, bloodlust must run in the Targaryen bloodline. Dany proved she's full of it and won't leave the world a better place. What was her reason for slaughtering innocents? That Cersei had Missandei killed? Lame excuse. How come all of a sudden, all of those hundreds of Scorpions couldn't hit her? Euron survives again to be engaged in a lame battle with Jamie? Seems like the writers are rushing to finish. I hope they don't do the same thing with Star Wars. Dany deserves to die in the next episode. And I expect Tyrion will no longer want to serve her, which will get him killed. Hopefully Arya will cut her throat, leaving Jon - who by virtue of not wanting to rule - will be a better ruler. The best part of this was Sandor Clegane getting closure by killing his brother (one of the dumber ideas in the book and movie), and his brother crushing Qyburn's head. Over all, most of the main cast is dead and rather than looking forward to this season ending, I'm glad it is. Oh, and I'm still pissed that Jon couldn't take two seconds to say goodbye to Ghost. Screw Dragons, Dogs are man's best friend and Ghost proved it time and again.
reviews.author: ur22761455

reviews.content: The scenes of battle in this episode were epic. The problem is they are not in the right context. If you have watched it from the beginning you would know that even though Daenerys could be as ruthless as her enemies, her actions were just and out of revenge. There is no way you can create a character over many episodes and this is the pay off. It makes absolutely no sense. Kill the soldiers and head to the tower. It's that simple. You don't kill thousands of innocents for no reason. Especially Daenerys. I understand GOT has many plot twists but was really the wrong move. If Daenerys was killed in her quest for the throne you would accept it because this is the show. You will never accept her death because Daenerys would never have done this. Not only has it ruined the season it's ruined the complete series as you will not want to rewatch it knowing how it will all end. It really is a shame as other scenes such as The Hound and The Mointain's fight were excellent. You probably know what happens in last episode and this makes matters worse. I was going to buy the complete series when it has finished but unfortunately now I feel like it has been ruined and it's disheartening.
reviews.author: ur69864183

reviews.content: I thought this was far and away the best episode of season 8, after what had been a very mixed, though largely disappointing final season.I'll acknowledge some parts of The Bells felt rushed. Could certain things have been built up better? Sure. Is this where people wanted the show to go? Certainly not everybody.But I can confidently say that this episode shook me and got me even feeling emotional for the first time since maybe season 6's final episode, and a lot of it reminded me of why I liked Game Of Thrones in the first place.Technically this episode is masterful, and far more coherent and well-filmed than the now somewhat infamous episode 3 of this season. Plus, there were certainly more casualties and a whole lot less plot armour.There are things here I've wanted to see happen for years and years, and honestly, while I won't argue that this is perfect or even one of the show's best episodes, I think some people are being far too harsh on The Bells (and this is coming from somebody who agrees with many of the criticisms piled on the last few episodes).Go in with an open mind and let the show do its thing. Some of the scenes here are truly spectacular, and I think this particular episode deserves a little more credit, because it made me feel things I haven't felt Game Of Thrones give me in ages.
reviews.author: ur26226712

reviews.content: 'Game of Thrones' very quickly became one of my favourite shows. Seasons 1-5 at their best made for some of the most riveting television for any show in recent years (and ever). So much so that it left me amazed that it was television and not film, with its best components being cinematic quality. Season 6 wasn't as consistently good to outstanding but still had a lot of great elements, while Season 7 was more uneven, with two great episodes and also two of the weakest episodes of the show.Not as much though as the worst of Season 8, which to me actually started off solidly, with "A Knight of the Seven Kingdoms" being the season high point, but from the climax of "The Long Night" (a heavily flawed episode but did appreciate the effort that went into it on namely a scope level) onwards it became one big disappointment. With it getting worse with each episode when it became more rushed, increasingly ran out of ideas, the writing worsened to the point that by "The Last of the Starks" it was a complete and utter indefensible mess and more characters were assassinated in terms of writing. Only the production values, music and acting remained good or more, as well as the odd memorable scenes or character moments. When you compare it to when the show first started and now, it is hard to believe that the slap in the face that is the season and show finale, by far the show's worst episode and worst show finales for any show, "The Iron Throne" came from the same show. One of the few episodes, the only perhaps, where my sisters, brother and me were all in agreement over our thoughts on a 'Game of Thrones' episode, resulting in an over-an-hour phone conversation sounding off all its flaws which was actually more entertaining and fulfilling.And no condescending defenders, whose "comments" mostly read more like rants attacking/insulting those that disliked the episode rather than any kind of review saying what was good about it, while those that disliked it mostly actually gave valid reasons for doing so, we were not trying to hate it from the very start with the season being so overall disappointing. Do think that it is not quite as bad as to warrant 1/10s, which is a bit disrespectful to the production team and actors' hard work, though and the negative reaction has been on the extreme side, to me there were a few great things about it, but the disappointment is completely understandable. We were not expecting a Disney-like happy ending, we wanted an ending and final episode that had good writing, made us connect to the drama emotionally, properly tie things up, show a return to form in quality and show signs of remembering what made the show so great in the first place and did justice to such great characters and their arcs. "The Iron Throne" did not do that in any shape or form and failed to do all those things. It was clear that it had completely lost sight of what made the best of 'Game of Thrones' as great as it was, and too many questions begging to be answered were not fully answered and more questions were raised instead.Lets start with the few good things "The Iron Throne" had. Visually, it looks amazing, as one would expect for 'Game of Thrones'. With some truly mind-blowing and cinematic-esque photography that was so immersive throughout. The scenery is throughout spectacular, the sets are hugely atmospheric and beautiful on the eyes with a real meticulous eye for detail and the costumes suit the characters to a tee. The make-up is beautifully done, while the special effects, while not the very best of the show, put many recent shows and films to shame, especially Drogon.One cannot not mention the thematically, orchestrally and atmospherically multi-layered music scoring and the unforgettable main theme. Again, worthy of a high-budget fantasy/action/drama film. The opening credits are beautifully designed. There were hardly any great moments, but did find the very beginning powerful and the Tyrion and Jon chemistry and their big scene also stirred the emotions. The acting was very good considering what was given to them, with the best performance coming from Peter Dinklage, who said his lines with authority while telling a lot with his eyes and face in wordless parts too.Did think that there was an exception, and that was Kit Harington, Jon is dull as dishwater and acts stupidly here and Harington's performance here is indicative of indifference and that he had lost faith in the character, writing and show. It is the writing and story single handedly sank "The Iron Throne". The script is far too talky, is very stilted, like very stale soap opera and the worst of it is truly embarrassing. When the most memorable dialogue is in a scene concerning talking about brothels, of all things, you know you are in trouble, found myself truly cringing then. The latter half of Season 8 saw such great characters, complex ones, reduced to one-dimensional caricatures behaving irrationally or out of character. Here they are assassinated beyond recognition, Tyrion (a contender for my consistent favourite 'Game of Thrones' character) especially. And their arcs finishing inconsistently and anti-climactically. The only ones to be in character or so it felt were Ghost and up to a certain point Drogon, am not kidding here.Having shown my dislike of the writing/script here, the story was an absolute mess, with only a couple of decent moments. What should have been emotional and powerful moments, so Tyrion's grief and the part with Drogon as primary examples, were ruined by truly questionable and clumsy lapses in logic that could easily have been avoided, wasting two of the episode's best scored scenes and in the former Dinklage's affecting acting and the latter seeing a rare chance of Drogon being shown to be a non-human character with soul (the build up was promising and then squandered by Drogon's actions in the rest of the scene). The pace was deadingly dull, with much of the first half being uneventful with a sluggish pace and filled with "get on with it and to the point" talk, and then it rushed through everything at the halfway point when the writers realised that they still had a lot to cram in, trying to tie up unanswered questions and failing abysmally in doing that. The outcome of the exchange between Jon and Daenerys was predictable from the very start of the scene and throughout there was very little emotional connection, moreover almost nothing made sense with so many inconsistencies, ridiculous parts (with characters getting off lightly) and things happening for no reason at all. As for who was chosen as ruler, that did not ring true or make sense, neither did the reason for it, and felt more of an excuse to finally give them something to do in the season, after being useless for most of it.Summarising, not irredeemable but by show finale standards of such a fantastic show for much of its run "The Iron Throne" was an intelligence insulting disgrace and disrespectful to fans. 3/10
reviews.author: ur20552756

reviews.content: The final-ever episode of GAME OF THRONES is split distinctly into two halves, and very different halves they are too. The first half is excellent: following on from the shocks of the last episode, this provides a fitting coda to the show, and the throne room scene is one of the most powerful in the show's entire run. Great acting from all involved in scenes that I had no problem with whatsoever. It's in the second half that things fall apart, with a pat, rushed, happy ending for most of the characters. Arya inexplicably swans off to who knows where; Sansa makes unreasonable demands and somehow gets them accepted; as for the presence of Bronn, and a simpering Brienne, and Sam as Grand Maester - what?! I must have been watching a different show. The best thing about the end of the episode is Ghost's reappearance, which at least satisfied me to some degree.
reviews.author: ur0482513

reviews.content: I still believe that this show was one of the five best TV shows in history. It's sad that this tacked on ending was so weak. What was supposed to be heightened and emotional was just plain endless. The whole thing was a lot of talk, with the exception of John's final scene with Danie. I do wish people wouldn't throw all these one's at it. Anyway, I anticipated it would be a disappointment and I was not surprised.
reviews.author: ur0278527

reviews.content: Is it a bad end ? Off course, not ! Is it the worst last episode ? Maybe ! After the final credits, one regret. It could be the best episode of the serie if...If the pause is the end. After Tyron discovers the bodies of his siblings. After the speech of the Mother of dragons. After the expected gesture of Jon Snow. After... . So many occasions to save a season and a serie ! Ignored . Or wasted. After eight years : a dragon more wise than all human characters in a fire show. Stark in each corner of Westeros. A pink murder. The most eccentric king , ruined so fast by three lines defining as dumb. Or as so ironic becoming cynical. And, as prize, few humor moments. Childish, vulgar, but humor. A Stark ship, a queen of the North - so independent than seems the real master of Westeros, A punishment who, in essence, is just the prize or returning to his old duty, a Wall against who ? builded when ? by who ? And a last trip in the forest, like a migration. The happy and so active Kings Landing, Samwell as Great Master and the impression than , after decades after the death of Daenerys, Westeros has a king.So, one regret. It deserves be the best episode. But, unfortunatelly, it is not.
reviews.author: ur61197531

reviews.content: After so many debates, reminding me the state viewing it, the fair conclusion is - "The Iron Throne" was the decent end. For an awfull season. Its sin - or, maybe virtue - to be a political lesson. A sort of island far by land , reflecting dictatorship, pink love stories in the genre of cinema of 20 decade, expression of hurry from two pragmatic and superficial scriptwriters . Few scenes of this episode are touching; another crazy; few absurde. Expression of good intentions, in same measure, it is bitter - sweet. And it sucks, like each episode of eight season. After its end, as teacher of history, I preserve the silhouettes. Caligula, many mothers of kings, Tommaso Campanella and Niccolo Machiavelli, Giorolamo Savonarola and the deep roots of each of us. In same measure, the Utopic Socialism and the minor price of the lives of ordinary people.The serie ends with the 6 season. The last seasons are parts of a sort of essay, in which the ambition to challenge the public using the special effects for visual shock and to propose a game of absurde and shocking, at the level of young child , is the purpoise. The compensation- I hope the last novels of Mr. Martin. The 8 season is just a house with children when the parents and adult relatives are far by the home.So, a decent end. Hppy, crazy, unrealistic, comfortable and provocative in same measure. Sure, I am not exactly a fan of serie. But I am profound grateful for discover good actors, admirable performances, nice scenes and promissing serie for better sequels.
reviews.author: ur61197531

reviews.content: Disappointment. My vocabulary in English cannot find a better word to describe the feeling (I believe) of most of the fans of "Game of Thrones" after all these years. Considered by many as the best TV show ever, the writers messed up with the two last episodes in a rushed and senseless conclusion. The attitude of Daenerys Targaryen in the last episode burning down to ashes King´s Landing was the opposite the fans could expect from that character. But the attitude of Jon Snow toward the woman that loves him is senseless and absurd. The characters and the fans and even HBO deserved better writers. My vote is three.Title (Brazil): "The Iron Throne"
reviews.author: ur2488512

reviews.content: The pile-on about season 8 had begun before the final episode had confirmed all the leaks and rumours, and I don't see the need to join it. It was interesting for me to look back on my comments over the last 8 years and see that they did fit with the greater opinion that things started slipped around season 5, and that the rush was evident in particular in season 7. In that season though, it felt very much like the characters were being forced to jump around in time and space to make everything happen that needed to happen but that the show no longer had time to do in a way that made sense. This was problematic, but nowhere near the problems caused by jumping the characters around emotionally - because this is really what kills the season.In terms of plotting, watching it felt like someone telling me the basic plot of a show I don't watch - "he hates her", "she is doing x", "they've got to go and do y"; all of it factually correct but yet I don't have any foundation in the characters so it is really just information more than something I am invested in. This didn't happen overnight, and the rush in season 7 is part of it, but in this season it very much feels like the story was written in bullet-points, without any connection or worry about flowing characters between states. The on-line fighting about it seems to take the side that everything was foreshadowed, or that none of it makes sense at all, but I think it is in the middle somewhere. Almost all of it could make sense if the show had the time to do it, but it doesn't. The result was that I approached the final episode almost like a duty, to tick off the final few bullet-points, which is a terrible way to feel about the final episode of a show that has run for this long and made its mark mostly on the basis of great story-telling.Aside from the character issues, season 8 repeats the 7th's approach of making things happen because they need to happen even if they don't make sense the way they came to happen. These are not as bad as the overall character problems, but they still annoy because seeing the convenience (or laziness) quite so brazenly on-screen tended to break me out of the moment. In terms of the actual production, it remains hugely impressive from a technical and scale of design point of view. The bottles and coffee cups aside, the money is all there on the screen, and the show is at its best when it is only about these things. The scale of the battle sequences are terrific, the cinematography mostly brilliant (but yes, like everyone, I watched that one episode with every light in the house out, and the brightness up as high as possible on the TV), the effects great, sound, music, costumes, locations - all of that remains of a very high standard.Likewise, the cast work with what they are given, and make it work as best they can. Dinklage, Clarke, Harington, Turner, Flynn, Hivju, Coster-Waldau, and on and on - all good, except you have to caveat that by then saying "despite it all". So for Clarke it is that the sudden gear change must have been hard for her to sell; likewise for Coster-Waldau. And for Harington his dialogue became so sparse for so many episodes that he must wonder what he did to deserve it - did someone try to Tom Baker his Adric?For all of its scale, for all of the work that the thousands involved in the production put in, for all the spectacle on the screen, in the end it too often feels like a to-do list more than a story. Deaths of major characters, something the show once managed to show us were coming, but yet still took us by surprise, are delivered almost without comment, pause, or reflection, and it all gives us a final episode where almost nothing has an emotional impact, and it peters out before it ends, the final half of the final episode being all the worst of the season, robbed of all the good parts.

reviews.content: Was it a great finale? No, but there were a few interesting moments. I think people thought we would get some epic battle or something particularly memorable and maybe that is the problem when you have those wars in the middle of the season like Game of Thrones often did.It was an amazing ride, but I doubt too many people loved the way it ended.
reviews.author: ur62702709

reviews.content: Everything must eventually come to an end and so it is with HBO's epic 'Game of Thrones'. The penultimate episode saw the destruction of King's Landing by Daenerys and her dragon. Now as she addresses the Unsullied she promises to similarly liberate the rest of the world... Tyrion realises that Lord Varys had been correct about her. Perhaps it isn't too late but if Daenerys isn't too sit on the Iron Throne who is to rule the kingdoms of Westeros and what will happen to those who opposed her?I know this is a much derided episode but I thought it was a solid enough conclusion to the series. It may have been a bit rushed but it gave most characters a proper ending before they get on with the next stage of their lives. Most people watching will have a personal choice as to who should rule so it isn't surprising that many viewers weren't pleased with the choice... similarly the episode doesn't feature too much action or the 'edgy' material the series became known for. The cast was one fine form and I was pleased to see most of the survivors given enough screen time to bid favourite characters good bye. As it drew to an end I was left wanting to know what will happen next in the hopefully more peaceful times. Overall I'd say that, even though I know I'm in the minority, I enjoyed this conclusion and thank all of the creators for this great series.
reviews.author: ur13977076

reviews.content: An embarrassing final portraying the violently graphic and strong facing off among various families in an undetermined time and set in the aftermath of the devastating attack on King's Landing in which dragons used their unlimited power and Iron fleet utilized the scorpion weapons . Forces have arrived at Kings Landing for the final battle and Daenerys Targaryen , Emilia Clarke , must face the survivors.Here writers David Benioff, D.B. Weiss failed in delivering enough and interesting surprises to enjoy the hardcore fans . This is sixth episode , eight season , of the popular series that takes its name from the first novel in the book series "A Game of Thrones" - which is actually known as "A Song of Ice and Fire",",and most of the show is largely faithful to the books , being this last chapter a free adaptation .This final epic dealing with nine noble families battle for control of the mythical land of Westeros results to be a spectacular ending series dealing with friction between the houses Stark, Lannister, Baratheon and Targaryen and with the remaining great houses Greyjoy, Tully, Arryn,Tyrell and Martell , but turning to be a disenchanment , that's why the surprises are absurd and disconcerting . A real disappointment that has been panned by a lot of reviewers .The dragon attacks are imaginatively brought to life on groundbreaking images when some buildings explode with the green fires , including great production values and outstanding scenarios , adding colorful computer generator images , but all of them falling short . However , the rousing and impressive musical score by Ramin Djawadi is frankly sensational , as usual . As well as the colorful and glimmer cinematography , though some dark , by cameraman Jonathan Freeman . This final episoce was regularly directed by Miguel Sapochnik .

reviews.author: ur76062573

reviews.content: This final episode had great acting, great production values, but, oh, that writing! Dany just turns on a dime into the "dragon lady"? I get where they are going with all of these characters, but they just went there too fast. Hey, D&D that rushed woke writing style will serve you well at Disney where they seem to ruin everything they touch. First the good - Drogon mourning Dany, Tyrion mourning his dead evil siblings. Now the bad. Grey worm only has one expression - a grimace. Tyrion is a prisoner who is told he is not there to speak and then winds up making a speech that determines the outcome of the series?? Oh, and he picks the new king too! Jon is given a life sentence but in a place where nobody really knows if he stays or goes? And the unsullied are going to be happy with Green Acres when they had their heart set on fighting an unending war?Well, at least Arya's arc turned out OK. She becomes an explorer and sails off the edge of the maps until she finds a vast continent with the remains of a statue of a lady holding a torch stuck in the sands of a beach. She would have stayed there but for the odd lone inhabitant who keeps going on about prying something "from my cold dead hands". Annoyed by this person, she sails back to Westeros, never to speak of the place again.

reviews.content: The Iron Throne starts out intense, but doesn't go out with a bang. Once Daenerys is gone, it has little to say, not warranting the run-time and containing unnecessary goofiness.I thought Arya would of been the one to do it, but Jon stepped up. The Dothraki just accept her assassination do they? They're just going to go, did they not fight for anything but her? Bran's a poor choice and mostly just annoying.Tyrion, Jon, Daenerys and Arya the standouts.
reviews.author: ur25775215

reviews.content: Episode 6, Season 8. I thought I had it all figured out before I watched this episode - I only had part of my guess right, the rest of it was wrong.Without ruining the ending: I can say I'm not disappointed in who ends up being crowned for the Iron Throne but I really thought someone else was going to get it.It's not the greatest of episodes but it's not all that bad. I'll admit the last season felt rushed as if they were trying to hurry up and end the series, yet they had 2 years to film it. Over all, I'm not that disappointed with Season 8 but I do wish more was added to it and it felt slower.All this mess over Robert Baratheon. He fell in love with Lyanna Stark - she told him NO because he already had bastard children all over - he would have cheated on her too. She met Rhaegar Targaryen - Robert got jealous and started the rumors that Rhaegar had abducted Laynna (untrue she left willingly to be with Rhaegar) -- all that led to Robert's rebellion which lead us into the reason for the story: Democracy is now the order of Westeros - it has become a Democratic Oligarchy (still run by a small group of people, but who runs the 7 Kingdoms is now voted on. 7/10
reviews.author: ur35635716

reviews.content: I can't even begin to count how many hours I've spent watching the show, reading articles, looking for interviews and set photos. Game of Thrones has consumed by life for the better part of the last decade, and now it's over. It's all over. And regardless of what the internet thinks, I think this finale was absolutely perfect. I couldn't have asked for a better end to the journeys of all my favorite TV characters in one hour and a half long night of television. In a divisive and cynical time, I love that Game of Thrones' last big "twist" was that it ends in a somewhat predictable and hopeful way.Of course, the episode didn't necessarily start that way, as we see the city in pieces following Daenerys' destruction last week. Watching Tyrion stare Dany in the face, call her out on her BS and throw the Hand of the King pin to the side was brilliantly bold and bada**. If they were going to kill Tyrion, that was a pretty awesome way to end his arc. Luckily, we had a scene with Jon & Tyrion that was just what Jon needed to do what had to be done.I think we all figured Dany's days were numbered after last week, we just weren't sure how exactly she would be killed. It was always expected to be Jon, but having him do it right before she was about to sit on the Throne she spent SEASONS trying to reach, was devastatingly tragic, but absolutely fitting. After all that, ultimately no one gets to sit on the Iron Throne. The next sequence, showcasing all of the Lords of Westeros gathered around Tyrion at first is a bit jarring, but you knew there had to be a nice way to wrap everyone's stories up, especially since there was merely 30 minutes to go. It becomes even more jarring when Tyrion pleads for Bran to be the one to take the Throne, but it all starts to click after that. He is the only one that can't possibly fall into the same sort of poison the throne brings upon everyone who desires it. He is the memory of this world.Drogon takes Dany away, Jon takes the black once again, Tyrion is the new Hand of the King, Sam is grand maester, and Davos, Bronn, Brienne all sit on the new small council. I loved watching Brienne finish Jaime's page in the history of the Knights of the Seven Kingdoms book. Seeing the new small council argue over the small things in the world was fittingly bittersweet. Podrick alive and well and wheeling Bran around! Even seeing Grey Worm going to Naath felt right, though if I was a betting man I could have sworn he would have been toast this season.This show started with the Starks, and I'm thrilled that it ended with the montage of the 3 remaining Starks (we don't count Bran anymore) and their new lives. Sansa as the new Queen of the *Independent* North, Arya going West of Westeros like I hoped, and finally Jon going home, going North. And YES he got his pets to Ghost! It's truly only fitting that we see that one green plant North of The Wall, A DREAM OF SPRING. Thank you Game of Thrones, for everything.10/10

reviews.content: Well it was basic simple ending of every ordinary film. It's not supposed to end like this. Series name is Game of Thrones... But where are the Games? Everything finished how it supposed to be. Nothing to be surprised for. If you wouldn't watch last episode you wouldn't lose anything. Feeling disappointed.
reviews.author: ur64160263

reviews.content: Greetings from Lithuania."The Iron Throne", THE last episode of "Game of Thrones" wasn't the best episode of them all, but it had it great moments. Actually i highly enjoyed first 43 minutes of it very highly - great cinematography, mood, music and directing - it was all there where it left us in "The Bells" (probably my favorite episode of them all). And then the ending came. And i won't spoil anything but i will say it was surprising for me a bit, so say the least - didn't expected that. It was kinda logical conclusion of the events this show brought us to.Anyway, whether you liked it or not (and from 4,7 IMDB rating i see that you didn't), the show has finally ended. I wasn't the biggest fan of it, yet i highly enjoyed it. First 4 seasons were brilliant in my opinion, and last 4 season stared to be a bit predictable and to "Hollywood'sh". What this last season needed the most is more episodes - not more battles but episodes that would have fleshed out situation we were into and actions some main characters took.Last thing - no matter how did it ended - i highly enjoyed the show. Thank you very much HBO for an amazing ride and memories, plenty of them, which will stick with me till the end. Great show.
reviews.author: ur4405474

reviews.content: Positive: Good hard work to prepare locations, sets, makeup, CGI, etc. Minor negatives: Excessive emphasis on killing, most of which came across as not too believable even for a fantasy. Seemed modern daytime soap opera like in clearing up romantic hook-ups - hasty & artificial. Major negatives: For seven seasons we have Daenerys portraying a fantasy God like goodness & courage. Season 8, right off the bat, I sensed something wrong when as she enters the city, dragons flying over & frightening people, I see her smirking in a self-indulgent, petty, "Aren't I great pose." Humans are consistent over a period of time as to their personality & values - they don't suddenly turn 180 degrees. More inconsistencies followed. The other discomforting characterization, most all the females were flawed even Arya abandons helping to go off on her own personal quest. Main example is Cersei shown as raised in spoiled wealth; illicit & immoral sex; narcissistic; dispassionately abandons allies; avoided military service so lacks remorse/understanding in her slaughtering innocents - very Trump like for her era. Tyrion sums it up - "What unites people? Armies? Gold? Flags? - Stories!". For me, yes stories, thus the final year let 8 seasons of story down.
reviews.author: ur18044142

reviews.content: Great epic finale, I'm satisfied with everything despite the ridiculous amount of hate it's getting! I love everything this show has done, I even disagree about the complaints towards the writers. I think it's well crafted and the crew put a vast amount of effort into everything - that should be appreciated! My opinion - it most likely will have mixed vibes and I'm ok with that. I loved this wild show through everything! Haters gonna hate but lovers will appreciate.Also I had this review up already last night not sure what happened I'm not a bot definitely real I wanna put my positivity out there and it'd be great if others could check out my other reviews!
reviews.author: ur34836174

reviews.content: Game of Thrones Episode 8.06 (4.5 out of 5 stars).The final episode and the finale of the series all come down to this. Without giving away spoilers. The post event of the last episode left everyone shocked with a twist on a character. This episode is about that event and how everyone is trying to resolve with what just happened. It got dark and intense with the opening half of the scene. People walking through a burnt and destroyed King's Landing. The build up suspense in this episode is kind of left disappointing. When it resolves the climatic situation a little too quick with its emotional send off. I predicted with what was going to happen. I loved how it went. There was not much of a battle or an epic climatic fight. All of it was in the previous episodes. With this episode feeling like an epilogue exposition. The new future of Westeros and the direction it can take. There is one shocking WTF scene that is mind blowing that refers back to an earlier season which comes back to this. The last hour of the episode does take itself in a new direction which I did not see coming. And kind of left speechless about it. It does end in the most satisfying conclusion with characters having a full circle with their story arc. Being in the position were they are suppose to be.Overall, Game of Thrones season 8 (5 out of 5 stars). An epic finale of an awesome series which delivered exciting battle sequences, a great complex story with the characters, and it is one fast paced season that messed with your emotions and left you on the edge.
reviews.author: ur57691865

reviews.content: Or, "Many partings"Look at Lord of the Rings: The beginnings of that story are as complex as this, but the end of that tale is very much like the end of this version of "A Song of Ice and Fire".And one thing about that ending frightened some people, and that is the concept of "Democracy". Daenerys did not like that word, but Jon did. In fact the word did not have very much use in this tale, until this episode. The former Lords of the Seven Kingdoms did not have much use for it either. But of all of the complaints about this ending, that is probably the most prominent. Oh, the word was never used in this series at all. But the underlying concept was part of this episode. And that concept was, "Which contender for King would have listened to his constituents?" And the answer to that question is here.I watched part of the very first episode of this series on the night it was first broadcast. I thought, "Neat, but who needs another show about stuff that happened during the Dark Ages?" - I did not realize at the time that this was an Alternate Reality, a different world even, where winter does not come every year but at intervals that can't be predicted. I was not interested in this at all, until I was given a free month of HBO one summer, and with nothing else to do, I watched the whole thing.Of course it did not take long for me to get sucked in to Westeros, and like everyone else, I became invested in the story being told, or rather, the many stories about the many people, places, gods, and Priestesses, some that gained power by burning people at the stake or sucking their blood out with leeches. Soon I realized that there was as rich of an alternate history as there is in ay Ur-Fantasy Novels, with the added benefit that George R R Martin is still writing this tale and produced part of this version of it.In the course of this show, a variegated assortment of characters and families had been paraded in front of us - Some of them removed from the story in the first season, others hung in there for a lot longer. But as I watched the last season of the show and then went back and watched key episodes and seasons, I realized that there was a pattern: this show was very populated at the start and there was a lot of dialogue because there were a lot of people having discussions. But each season of the show had less and less of these people talking, many of the main characters were killed off including whole families.We were introduced to two families at the start: The Starks and the Lannisters. There was a 3rd family, the Baratheons, which had a relationship to both Stark and Lannister due to friendship and marriage. But we learned right away of improprieties within the King's own family. As viewers we knew it, the other characters in the show were mostly oblivious to it.We know now that the whole conflict between Stark and Lannister was the result of manipulations by "Lord Littlefinger Baelish" - And the tale of his treachery spans 7 seasons. Treachery which spread across all of Westeros, affecting the remaining Baratheon family, the Starks and Lannisters, the Boltons, the Targaryen's, The Freys, even the Ironborn Greyjoys- Every one of them affected by Baelish' original act of Treason and Heinous Murder.We were introduced to other cities, continents and cultures, particularly the Dothraki, led by Khal Drogo, and this was where we got our first glimpse of the disrobed figure of Daenerys Targaryen, sister of Viserys, and we start hearing a lot of talk about Dragons- Until we got 3 of them.MEANWHILE, up at "THE WALL", a vast construct of Ice and Magic, we get our first encounter with a "White Walker", as we see a whole village of "Wildings" slaughtered and then rise from the dead with Blue Eyes. This is our introduction to the Watchers on The Wall, an elite group of men, usually former prisoners, who guard the Realms of Men. Against what?For seven years, we watched the ranks of Westeros thin out. The Baratheons, dead. The Boltons - dead. The Freys, dead. Whole houses, wiped out, either by treachery or by trickery, or by the machinations of Cersei Lannister.It was not extraordinary that at the start, we had complex dialogue, sometimes verbatim to the books this tale is based upon. But what happens, if the writer of the books, has not written any since 2011, and the show still has to move forward?With the significant amount of major characters killed off season by season, and not replaced with new, of course the level of Dialogue was reduced somewhat, which is what happens when you have roughly less than a third of the characters you started off with. And then we had significant story and character development, unlikely relationships between unlikely characters: As we entered into the 8th season, the ranks had decisively been thinned out. So all we really have left is Tyrion with his wisecracks, The Hound and Arya fellowshipping on the taste shared revenge but also mutual respect, and the huge reveal as to the identity of one of the most major characters.And let us not get started in the unfortunate events that brought the Night King his very own pet Ghoul-Dragon.As I view these episodes again and again, I saw the mistakes that were made. Tyrion, smart as he is forgot the very nature of his own sister. And Daenerys had been victorious with every campaign and erringly thought she was invincible with three whole dragons, forgetting twice that Dragons are susceptible to flying projectiles.So my take on this final episode, and this final season has to be this: Even the best stories have an ending, and a denouement. Seven seasons of one of the finest stories ever televised had to come to an end. Was I happy with all of the decisions? No, but I was happy that most of the main plot elements had been solidly wrapped up. From the first to the last, Game of Thrones has delivered one whopping kick in the buttocks after another. I think the level of hurt rump for this season is due to the creators providing plot twists and reversals that did not involve their favourite characters, and I am guilty of that as well. "The season was sparse, the episodes less complex, the dialogue more simple?" Naturally, because this is what happens when you start off with 100 characters and end with maybe 20. So no complaints, I got the see most of the show in one sitting, so I'm certainly not going to complain about it.I will admit that as I watched the series, I became invested in it, and of course I wanted to see certain things. That I did not get to see those things? I'm not going to pan the whole season and the showrunners because of it. Because look at what I did see:1-Three Dragons destroying a fleet of Slaver Ships.2-The Watchers on the Wall using a huge scythe on a chain to repel thousands of Wilding Attackers.3-The same Wildings besieged by an Army of The Dead at a port far beyond the Wall.4-Cersei using secreted explosives to destroy the Sept of the Seven and all of the little Sparrows.And the most incredible: Arya becoming one of The Faceless Ones.Not to mention the sheer vastness of the imagery I was exposed to, and to this date I can't tell what was real and what was not. But it was all real I suppose, in some ways.This was indeed, "Many Partings"- All stories come to an end sooner or later. But this ending was more hopeful than I expected. An Unexpected King, the coolest people on the Small Council, Samwell Tarly given position as a Maester above all of the maesters that dismissed him, and Jamie Lannister's story finally written in the Book of Knights by the very woman that he Knighted.I'm really going to miss these people.

reviews.content: My Rating : 5/10RIP Daenerys' eyebrows.I'm a hardcore fan and I'm writing this just to express my disappointment at the finale.FAR TOO RUSHED.One of the greatest TV Shows ever laid to rest so abruptly. I'm heartbroken.
reviews.author: ur45390749

reviews.content: "The Iron Throne" concludes this epic series in a most satisfying way.Any ending to this behemoth would be controversial and disappointing to many fans, who've had years to speculate and dream of their ideal finale. However, this episode makes sense and provides a logical closure to the proceedings.The tension in the opening thirty minutes or so is so thick you'd need Valyrian steel to slice through it. In the whole of the series, never has the sheer size and terror of a full sized dragon been captured as impressively as this.Beautifully shot and solidly directed, this is a fitting end to an impressive series.10 out of 10.
